SUMMARY:
The placebo effect is particularly potent when it comes to the perception of pain.
In the experiment, patients who received the stent didn‚Äôt show any difference in chest pain symptoms or enhanced exercise performance compared to patients who underwent a sham procedure.
When people think about placebos and the ‚Äúplacebo effect,‚Äù they‚Äôre generally thinking of a drug trial that tests an experimental medicine against a harmless sugar pill.
And that‚Äôs exactly what happened in the stent experiment.
Bhatt, who is an executive director at Brigham and Women‚Äôs Hospital Heart and Vascular Center, has also conducted an experiment with a sham procedure in Europe.
TEXT:
A groundbreaking new experiment reveals that stents, which are mesh wire tubes inserted into narrow or weak arteries to widen them and increase blood flow, are no more effective than treating people with medicine when it comes to relieving stable angina, or chest pain, The New York Times first reported.

While stents can save lives in the aftermath of a heart attack, the results from this study suggest people who get them inserted for chest pain ‚Äî estimated at over 500,000 people every year around the globe ‚Äî may be benefiting more from a placebo effect than from the device itself.

Experts praised the study, saying it highlights just how crucial it is to test certain therapies with a placebo group, even if that placebo treatment may mean a minimally invasive sham procedure.

The placebo effect is a psychological phenomenon in which a person who is tricked into receiving a fake treatment begins to perceive an improvement in symptoms because they expect the therapy will work. The placebo effect is particularly potent when it comes to the perception of pain.

In the experiment, patients who received the stent didn‚Äôt show any difference in chest pain symptoms or enhanced exercise performance compared to patients who underwent a sham procedure.

While the experiment, which was conducted in the U.K., only followed up with participants after six weeks ‚Äï a relatively short time when it comes to evaluating a chronic condition ‚Äï experts expect the results may influence cardiologists in the U.S. to recommend that patients who can control their pain symptoms with anti-anginal medication should hold off on a stent insertion.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a really interesting trial and it should make people pause,‚Äù said Dr. James Slater, an interventional cardiologist at NYU Langone Health who estimates that he performs hundreds of stent insertions every year. ‚ÄúFor the knee-jerk stenters out there, it‚Äôs just one more piece of evidence that maybe they should be a little more reluctant to do that.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll change me somewhat because for some of those people where I‚Äôm on the fence, I think I will move toward not doing as much,‚Äù said Dr. Paul Thompson, chief of cardiology at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut. ‚ÄúEven though I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve been aggressive about it anyway, I would move toward not recommending it.‚Äù

While the study could lead to a change in how American cardiologists approach angina treatment, arguably more important than the results of the study is the way the experiment itself was conducted, said Dr. Deepak Bhatt, a spokesman with the American Heart Association.

When people think about placebos and the ‚Äúplacebo effect,‚Äù they‚Äôre generally thinking of a drug trial that tests an experimental medicine against a harmless sugar pill. In this scenario, the sugar pill presents virtually no risk to the study participant who swallows it, and scientists go on to compare their results with people who received the active medicine, in the hope of being able to separate its true physical effect from its placebo effect.

But to test the effectiveness of a device inserted into the body against a placebo, patients who receive the placebo treatment must be led to believe that they could have been operated on ‚Äï what‚Äôs known as a ‚Äúsham‚Äù procedure. And that‚Äôs exactly what happened in the stent experiment.

Participants who were randomly picked to receive the placebo were sedated, and a catheter really was inserted into their body, up a blood vessel close to their heart. But instead of depositing the stent, doctors instead just withdrew the catheter. Some may consider this kind of ‚Äúdeception‚Äù in the name of science to be unethical, Bhatt said.

‚ÄúSince we don‚Äôt have a good word for a placebo device, ‚Äòsham‚Äô is used, and that just puts people in a bad frame of mind already, because it sounds like something illicit is going on,‚Äù said Bhatt.

Another reason U.S. scientists and institutions are reluctant to approve experiments with sham procedures is that they are still real, invasive procedures. This means they expose the patient to a slight risk with arguably no payoff, as they aren‚Äôt receiving the actual treatment.

Indeed, in this stent experiment, four of the 95 participants who were supposed to get the sham procedure ended up experiencing artery disruption during the insertion, which required doctors to insert the stent anyway, even though it was unplanned.

‚ÄúThe authors poo-pooed that and said well, this is the price you pay for this, and none of those people were really hurt,‚Äù said Slater, who reviewed the trial but was not involved with it. ‚ÄúBut I think in America, where the lawyers are quick to pounce, you might have a little trouble doing something like this.‚Äù

Despite the complications, the stent experiment reveals there‚Äôs a dire need for scientists to figure out if certain devices or operations really are delivering the results promised to patients ‚Äï or whether it‚Äôs just a placebo effect due to undergoing some kind of procedure.

Bhatt, who is an executive director at Brigham and Women‚Äôs Hospital Heart and Vascular Center, has also conducted an experiment with a sham procedure in Europe. He demonstrated that a promising therapy that zapped kidney nerves to lower blood pressure did not produce results that were any better than a sham procedure. While he was accused of unethically exposing patients to unnecessary invasive procedures, Bhatt‚Äôs results instead showed that it would be unethical to keep trying to treat people with an invasive procedure that didn‚Äôt work.
TITLE: A Controversial Experiment Upends The Conventional Wisdom On Heart Stents

SUMMARY:
The Dalai Lama said science should be used for the benefit of all.
Tibetan spiritual leader His Holiness the Dalai Lama has warned the world is in for another century of "violence" and "suffering" if science isn't used to create peace.
Speaking at a one-day conference on Science, Religion and World Peace in the north Indian town of Dharamshala, the 14th Dalai Lama called on world leaders to use science for the "oneness of humanity" instead of creating weapons of mass destruction.
The Dalai Lama fled from Lhasa, Tibet into India after the failed 1959 Tibetan uprising against Chinese rule.
Reuters reported China recently warned world leaders against meeting with the Tibetan leader.
TEXT:
The Dalai Lama said science should be used for the benefit of all.

Tibetan spiritual leader His Holiness the Dalai Lama has warned the world is in for another century of "violence" and "suffering" if science isn't used to create peace.

Speaking at a one-day conference on Science, Religion and World Peace in the north Indian town of Dharamshala, the 14th Dalai Lama called on world leaders to use science for the "oneness of humanity" instead of creating weapons of mass destruction.

SBS reported the Buddhist monk said it's time to reconsider how we use technologies created to kill.

"Science brought the powerful instruments to kill ... (If) situation of the world go continuously then this 21st century also will be similar century of violence, century of suffering," he said.

The 82-year-old also spotlighted religion as a factor causing divide across the globe and said we must act with a "sense of concern of other's well-being and oneness of humanity."

The Dalai Lama fled from Lhasa, Tibet into India after the failed 1959 Tibetan uprising against Chinese rule. He continues to live as a refugee in Dharamshala, India where a small Tibetan Government operates in exile.

The Tibetan monk won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989 and continues to travel the world to advocate for Tibet's autonomy, as well as promoting the Buddhist ideals of peace and compassion.

Reuters reported China recently warned world leaders against meeting with the Tibetan leader.

Zhang Yijiong, who heads the Communist Party's Tibet working group, said "I hope governments around the world speak and act with caution and give full consideration their friendship with China and their respect for China's sovereignty."
TITLE: Dalai Lama Says World Leaders Should Use Science To Create Peace

TEXT:
Der katalanische Ex-Regierungschef Puigdemont hat sich in Belgien den Beh√∂rden gestellt

Die belgische Justiz hat nun 60 Tage Zeit, √ºber die Auslieferung zu entscheiden

Der abgesetzte katalanische Regierungschef Carles Puigdemont hat sich in Belgien den Beh√∂rden gestellt. Dies best√§tigte die Staatsanwaltschaft in Br√ºssel am Sonntag. Die Regierung in Madrid hatte einen Europ√§ischen Fahndungs- und Haftbefehl gegen den 54-J√§hrigen sowie vier Ex-Minister der Regionalregierung erlassen, die sich nach Br√ºssel abgesetzt hatten.

Die f√ºnf Katalanen sollten noch am Sonntag einem Untersuchungsrichter vorgef√ºhrt werden. Dieser habe dann bis Montagmorgen Zeit zu entscheiden, ob die Beschuldigten festgehalten werden. Sp√§tester Zeitpunkt sei 9.17 Uhr am Montagmorgen, sagte ein Sprecher der Staatsanwaltschaft auf einer Pressekonferenz in Br√ºssel am Sonntagnachmittag.

Das weitere rechtliche Prozedere k√∂nnte sich √ºber Wochen hinziehen: Wird der Haftbefehl aufrecht erhalten, hat das Gericht dann weitere 15 Tage Zeit, √ºber eine Abschiebung zu entscheiden.

Belgische Justiz hat 60 Tage Zeit, √ºber Auslieferung zu entscheiden

Sowohl die Staatsanwaltschaft als auch die betroffenen Personen k√∂nnen dann Einspruch einlegen. √úber den Einspruch muss ebenfalls binnen 15 Tagen entschieden werden. Ein weiterer Einspruch beim belgischen Revisionsgericht ist m√∂glich.

Nach den EU-Regeln hat die belgische Justiz 60 Tage Zeit, √ºber die Auslieferung zu entscheiden - lediglich in Ausnahmef√§llen kann die Frist um weitere 30 Tage verl√§ngert werden.

Puigdemont und seinen Mitstreitern drohen in Spanien lange Haftstrafen. Ihnen werden von der Justiz Rebellion, Auflehnung gegen die Staatsgewalt und Unterschlagung √∂ffentlicher Gelder vorgeworfen. Grund daf√ºr ist die einseitige Unabh√§ngigkeitserkl√§rung, die das katalanische Parlament am Freitag vor einer Woche beschlossen hatte.

Die Zentralregierung von Ministerpr√§sident Mariano Rajoy hatte die katalanische Regierung daraufhin abgesetzt. Die wirtschaftsstarke Region im Nordosten Spaniens steht nun unter Zwangsverwaltung aus Madrid. F√ºr den 21. Dezember setzte Rajoy Neuwahlen an.

Puigdemont war bereits vor der Anklageerhebung nach Br√ºssel ausgereist.

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: Der Katalonien-Konflikt gilt als demokratischer Freiheitskampf - doch er ist vor allem ein Duell rigoroser Nationalisten
TITLE: EIL: Katalanischer Ex-Regierungschef Puigdemont stellt sich Beh√∂rden in Belgien

SUMMARY:
Often associated with veterans returning from war zones, Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) may not seem like something that might affect a child.
Like adults, all children will have different reactions to a traumatic event, and how they react may depend on a combination of their age, personality and previous life experience.
The charity PTSD UK says that at the most basic level, PTSD is a ‚Äúmemory filing error‚Äù caused by a traumatic event, which and can affect anyone, regardless of their age.
‚ÄúYou may notice that they are less able to concentrate or they become easily distracted,‚Äù said Dr Rosan.
‚ÄúThere may also be changes in their behaviour such as becoming jumpy, finding it hard to sleep, having temper tantrums or being disobedient, or being overly clingy compared to usual,‚Äù said Dr Rosan.
TEXT:
And the risk of them subsequently developing the anxiety disorder PTSD is particularly high if the child‚Äôs family is facing poverty, unemployment or housing issues.

But actually more than two thirds of children in the UK are likely to have experienced a traumatic event by the age of 16, according to chartered clinical psychologist Dr Camilla Rosan, who helped to write the guide for social workers looking after the families affected by the Grenfell Tower fire .

Often associated with veterans returning from war zones, Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) may not seem like something that might affect a child.

Like adults, all children will have different reactions to a traumatic event, and how they react may depend on a combination of their age, personality and previous life experience.

But children are unlikely to know that they are suffering, and so will require parents to help them understand what they are going through.

Why might a child suffer from PTSD?

The charity PTSD UK says that at the most basic level, PTSD is a ‚Äúmemory filing error‚Äù caused by a traumatic event, which and can affect anyone, regardless of their age.

In fact one in three teenagers who survives a serious car crash and 40% of people who have lost a loved one suddenly will experience PTSD.

According to PTSD UK the defining characteristic of a traumatic event is whether or not it has the ‚Äúcapacity to provoke fear, helplessness, or horror in response to the threat of injury or death‚Äù so consider the event in those terms.

Young people are just as vulnerable to these triggers as adults.

‚ÄúPTSD can occur after directly or indirectly experiencing a traumatic event that puts you or someone close to you at risk of serious harm or death,‚Äù said Dr Rosan, programme lead at the Mental Health Foundation.

‚ÄúThis can be anything from a road accident, to experiencing or witnessing violence or human accidents.‚Äù

What are the signs of PTSD in a child?

As with adults, the way children react to a trauma is likely to be individual to them as a person, but there are some tell-tale symptoms of PTSD that parents can be alert to.

Dr Rosan advised that it is likely children, who are older than toddlers, will experience a physical response, with symptoms such as an increased heart rate, sweating, rapid breathing and changes in appetite.

Your child might also become preoccupied with thoughts or images of the event or start experiencing nightmares and worrying that it will happen again.

‚ÄúYou may notice that they are less able to concentrate or they become easily distracted,‚Äù said Dr Rosan.

‚ÄúA sudden onset of intense emotions is also to be expected ‚Äì such as fearfulness, increased anxiety, anger or irritability.‚Äù

For younger children, physical symptoms might not be reported in these terms and instead they might tell you they have a headache or stomach ache.

‚ÄúThere may also be changes in their behaviour such as becoming jumpy, finding it hard to sleep, having temper tantrums or being disobedient, or being overly clingy compared to usual,‚Äù said Dr Rosan.

‚ÄúRegressive behaviours are common, such as a resurgence of bedwetting or thumb-sucking.‚Äù

If you are worried your child is displaying any of these behaviours, visit your GP.
TITLE: Post Traumatic Stress Disorder In Children: These Are The Symptoms Parents Need To Look Out For

SUMMARY:
As pressure grows on Theresa May‚Äôs government over the spiralling Westminster sexual harassment scandal, it fell to Amber Rudd to face questions on the Sunday morning political programmes.
Chris Grayling says as a former Whip he doesn't believe they blackmail people or suppress allegations of sexual harassment.
Let‚Äôs give him time and the inquiry time to put it straight,‚Äù Rudd told Paterson.
And interesting Rudd suggested those found guilty of sexual harassment should face being kicked out of parliament altogether.
Away from sexual harassment, there was still time on the shows to squeeze in a bit of Brexit.
TEXT:
As pressure grows on Theresa May‚Äôs government over the spiralling Westminster sexual harassment scandal, it fell to Amber Rudd to face questions on the Sunday morning political programmes. On the Andrew Marr Show, the Home Secretary was pressed on what the Tory party Whips knew. And when did they know it. The allegation is that Whips, the enforcers that maintain party discipline, collected information about sexual abuse by politicians in order to ensure MPs voted how the prime minister of the day wanted. But Rudd said this was not the case. ‚ÄúThere was no black book,‚Äù she insisted. ‚ÄúI was a Whip myself and I don‚Äôt recognise some of those more lurid stories that are told about the sort of things Whips knew and did.‚Äù

"There was no black book" ‚Äì Amber Rudd says she doesn't think whips were sitting on information about sexual harassment claims #Marr pic.twitter.com/ozNjJMWc5y ‚Äî BBC News (UK) (@BBCNews) November 5, 2017

Rudd was backed up by Transport Secretary Chris Grayling. He told ITV‚Äôs Peston on Sunday that ‚Äúthe idea there is some kind of Whips Office conspiracy is wide of the mark‚Äù.

Chris Grayling says as a former Whip he doesn't believe they blackmail people or suppress allegations of sexual harassment. #Peston pic.twitter.com/XkNe43BI1U ‚Äî Peston on Sunday (@pestononsunday) November 5, 2017

Home Office minister Sarah Newton, who has served as a Whip in the past, told the BBC‚Äôs Sunday Politics she had heard ‚Äúrumours‚Äù about a ‚Äúblack book or a black spreadsheet‚Äù of secrets, but had never seen it herself. ‚ÄúIf anybody had brought a complaint to me about the behaviour of one of the MPs that were in my flock, I would take that really seriously. But no, that didn‚Äôt happen,‚Äù she added.

Home Office Minister and ex-whip @SNewtonUK tells #bbcsp no complaints were made to her when she was a whip, nor did she hear rumours #bbcsp pic.twitter.com/h2WmDPt5pA ‚Äî Daily&SundayPolitics (@daily_politics) November 5, 2017

Tory MP Anna Soubry told Marr the prime minister should call in Tory whips and find out what information they have on MPs. ‚ÄúAll the stuff that they know must be given to the Prime Minister and we must do things properly, and not behind the scenes, in some instances covering up, which is totally unacceptable,‚Äù she said.

People shouldn't have to "go to the press" to complain about sexual harassment in Westminster, Conservative Anna Soubry says #Marr pic.twitter.com/Zu20HYefyZ ‚Äî BBC News (UK) (@BBCNews) November 5, 2017

Rudd used her appearances on Marr and Sky News‚Äô Sunday with Paterson to notionally defend her cabinet colleague Damian Green, who has denied allegations that pornography was found on his parliamentary computers in 2008. ‚ÄúHe strongly denies the allegations. Let‚Äôs give him time and the inquiry time to put it straight,‚Äù Rudd told Paterson. ‚ÄúI really look forward to him clearing his name.‚Äù However the Home Secretary revealed the inquiry in to the first secretary of state‚Äôs conduct, launched after he was accused of making inappropriate sexual advances towards a young female Tory activist, would now be expanded to include the claims about pornography.

I know that the Cabinet Office is going to be looking at this tomorrow along with the wider inquiry about Damian Amber Rudd reveals inquiry will include new claims

Rudd‚Äôs intervention came as Tory MP Heidi Allen became the second backbencher to call for Green to stand aside from his job as de facto deputy prime minister until the inquiry was completed.

.@heidiallen75 says it'd be sensible for @DamianGreen to stand down from Cabinet role whilst there is an inquiry into his actions #Peston pic.twitter.com/5K1I9Rq7Yr ‚Äî Peston on Sunday (@pestononsunday) November 5, 2017

On Sunday morning, Daniel Kawczynski became the third Tory MP to be referred to the party‚Äôs disciplinary committee over allegations he pressured a young woman who worked in parliament into meet a wealthy businessman. He denies anything inappropriate took place. The scandal has already forced Sir Michael Fallon to resign as defence secretary. However he remains an MP. And interesting Rudd suggested those found guilty of sexual harassment should face being kicked out of parliament altogether. She told Sky News she would ‚Äúencourage‚Äù a review into how parliament operated to ‚Äúlook at‚Äù whether MPs could be kicked out mid-term. And she said there would be a ‚Äúclearing out Westminster of that sort of behaviour‚Äù which would make both parliament and government ‚Äúbetter for it‚Äù.

"It's wrong for us to have a knee-jerk reaction based on the past week. We need to look at the whole issue," says @AmberRuddHR #Paterson pic.twitter.com/R7b6eKmx0G ‚Äî Sunday with Paterson (@RidgeOnSunday) November 5, 2017

It is, of course, not just the Conservative Party that has been rocked by allegations of sexual harassment. Jeremy Corbyn is under pressure to explain why Kelvin Hopkins was promoted to the shadow cabinet even though allegations, which he denies, had been made about his behaviour towards a young female activist. Former shadow cabinet minister Clive Lewis has also denied allegations he groped a woman during an event at the Labour Party conference in September. Appearing on Sunday with Paterson, Emily Thornberry said she was ‚Äúashamed of what‚Äôs been going on‚Äù within Labour.

"What are we going to do without youngsters coming into politics?" Shadow Foreign Secretary @EmilyThornberry tells @skynewsniall #Paterson pic.twitter.com/s2UpDDDz5H ‚Äî Sunday with Paterson (@RidgeOnSunday) November 5, 2017

But during the combative interview, the shadow foreign secretary also said she was ‚Äúhappy to go‚Äù and walk out of the studio after Paterson pressed her on Hopkins. not in a position to be able to comment on these matters in detail because they are under investigation. ‚ÄúI am not in a position to be able to comment on these matters in detail because they are under investigation,‚Äù she said. After Paterson said Labour perhaps owed a ‚Äúdebt of gratitude‚Äù to the media for exposing claims of abuse within the party, Thornberry told him: ‚ÄúI think that the people who we owe a debt of gratitude to are those who have come forward with these allegations and who have been brave in the way that have.‚Äù Over on BBC Radio 5 Live‚Äôs Pienaar‚Äôs Politics, shadow cabinet minister Cat Smith said ‚Äúthe rules internally within the Labour Party were not appropriate‚Äù to deal with the problem of harassment. Smith, who has said she was on the receiving end of unwanted behaviour from a Labour councillor, said ‚Äúrules were not fit for purpose‚Äù to deal with the problem. Away from sexual harassment, there was still time on the shows to squeeze in a bit of Brexit.

Governor @bankofengland Mark Carney explains how the "Brexit effect" has limited the strength of economic growth. #Peston pic.twitter.com/yI0a2U5lCS ‚Äî Peston on Sunday (@pestononsunday) November 5, 2017
TITLE: Sunday Shows Round-Up: Amber Rudd Denies Whips Keep Black Book Of Tory Sexual Harassment Secrets

Trying to get clean was at the center of ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live‚Äôs‚Äù cold open as Alec Baldwin‚Äôs Donald Trump ended up naked in a cold shower with a dirty Paul Manafort (Alex Moffat).
It‚Äôs too late, the ‚Äúpresident‚Äù concedes, to help Harvey Weinstein extricate himself from a burgeoning sex harassment and assault scandal.
‚ÄúWhat an idiot that Harvey Weinstein is,‚Äù Baldwin tells Moffat.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs shame you‚Äôre going to prison,‚Äù Baldwin‚Äôs Trump tells his former campaign manager.
She gets to talk for a change, her hubby actually seems presidential, and his ‚Äúbicep‚Äù feels like he‚Äôs been working out.
TEXT:
Trying to get clean was at the center of ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live‚Äôs‚Äù cold open as Alec Baldwin‚Äôs Donald Trump ended up naked in a cold shower with a dirty Paul Manafort (Alex Moffat).

They both get their backs scrubbed by an eager Kate McKinnon as Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Beck Bennet‚Äôs Mike Pence (wearing a suit because he‚Äôs not ‚Äúmarried to water‚Äù) ‚Äî and ‚ÄúTrump‚Äù can make certain Manafort isn‚Äôt wearing a wire.

It‚Äôs too late, the ‚Äúpresident‚Äù concedes, to help Harvey Weinstein extricate himself from a burgeoning sex harassment and assault scandal. ‚ÄúWhat an idiot that Harvey Weinstein is,‚Äù Baldwin tells Moffat. ‚ÄúHe could have gotten away with it all if only he had gotten himself elected president.‚Äù

As for Manafort, Baldwin suggests he dress up like a turkey so the president can pardon him at Thanksgiving ‚Äî but warns the family might bungle it and end up eating him. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs shame you‚Äôre going to prison,‚Äù Baldwin‚Äôs Trump tells his former campaign manager. ‚ÄúI was about to give you a yuge tax break.‚Äù

McKinnon warns that maybe they should all get used to ‚Äúwearing strips.‚Äù That‚Äôs ‚Äúwhy I‚Äôm wearing a bathing costume that I got from my favorite place ‚Äî the 1890s.‚Äù

If he gets in trouble ‚ÄúSessions‚Äù plans to ‚Äúroll over and play dead like the half-possum I am.‚Äù

Trump is supposed to be on his way to his Asia tour, but has replaced himself on Air Force One with a Donald doll. Cecily Strong‚Äôs Melania, sitting next to the big dummy, is delighted. She gets to talk for a change, her hubby actually seems presidential, and his ‚Äúbicep‚Äù feels like he‚Äôs been working out.

Check out the video above.
TITLE: Weinstein Should Have Been President, Says Alec Baldwin's Trump In 'SNL' Skit

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTAs President Donald Trump makes his journey to Asia for a 12-day, five-country trip, international security experts are urging him to ‚Äústick to the script‚Äù and avoid making incendiary comments while discussing North Korea.
The ‚ÄúAmerica first‚Äù leader has engaged in an escalating war of words with North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un in recent months.
She‚Äôs not optimistic that Trump‚Äôs visit to Asia will serve to improve relations with the North Korean regime.
Jeffrey Lewis, director of Middlebury‚Äôs East Asia Nonproliferation Program, also frets that more hostile statements or tweets from Trump about North Korea could exacerbate an already-tense standoff between Washington and Pyongyang.
‚Äú[North Korea] could totally do that.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

As President Donald Trump makes his journey to Asia for a 12-day, five-country trip, international security experts are urging him to ‚Äústick to the script‚Äù and avoid making incendiary comments while discussing North Korea. The ‚ÄúAmerica first‚Äù leader has engaged in an escalating war of words with North Korean dictator Kim Jong Un in recent months. In September, Trump threatened to ‚Äútotally destroy‚Äù the rogue nation, which is home to an estimated 25 million people, if provoked. Pyongyang has made significant advancements to its internationally condemned nuclear program this year and has repeatedly claimed that it is capable of striking the U.S. mainland with a nuclear-tipped intercontinental ballistic missile. Kim‚Äôs regime is expected to be a key topic of discussion during Trump‚Äôs meetings in China, South Korea and Japan. As tensions rise, experts fear Trump‚Äôs response to the situation is only fanning the flames, not dousing the fire.

Reuters President Donald Trump's taunts and insults directed at North Korean leader Kim Jong Un ‚Äúcreate an incentive for the North Koreans to stage provocations to show him up,‚Äù a nuclear nonproliferation expert said.

‚ÄúTrumpian rhetoric to ‚Äòtotally destroy‚Äô North Korea is not helpful at a time when, alarmingly, the likelihood of all-out war on the Korean Peninsula has moved from remotely possible to almost palpable,‚Äù William Choong and Alexander Neill, senior fellows at the International Institute for Strategic Studies, wrote in a report published Friday. ‚ÄúIt is critically important for Asia-Pacific security that Trump does not fly off the handle,‚Äù they warned. On Thursday, national security adviser H.R. McMaster told reporters Trump is unlikely to moderate his remarks overseas. ‚ÄúThe president will use whatever language he wants to use, obviously,‚Äù McMaster said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think the president really modulates his language. I mean, have you noticed him do that? He has been very clear about that.‚Äù This is hardly surprising to Catherine Dill, a defense analyst at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies, but it is ‚Äúabsolutely concerning.‚Äù ‚ÄúIn my view, with North Korea ‚Äï and to some degree, also with [U.S.] allies in the region ‚Äï there is a real risk of miscalculation and unintended escalation. A lot of that could occur because of sloppy rhetoric,‚Äù she said.

It is critically important for Asia-Pacific security that Trump does not fly off the handle. William Choong and Alexander Neill, senior fellows at the International Institute for Strategic Studies

If Trump makes bellicose comments about Pyongyang during his travels through Asia, Dill worries possible reactions from the North Korean regime could range from moderate, such as a short-range missile test, to severe, like a longer-range missile launch that overflies Japan. She‚Äôs not optimistic that Trump‚Äôs visit to Asia will serve to improve relations with the North Korean regime. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really have any hopes,‚Äù she said with a laugh. ‚ÄúI think the best possible outcome is that it doesn‚Äôt lead to war.‚Äù On the other hand, Dill sees the trip as an opportunity for Trump to ‚Äúreassure Japan and South Korea, and also try to have a measured, constructive conversation with China.‚Äù Due to their proximity to North Korea, American allies Tokyo and Seoul are especially vulnerable to a potential retaliatory attack by Pyongyang if it felt threatened or provoked. Trump has aggressively pressured Beijing to leverage its influence over the hermit kingdom to curb its nuclear ambitions. Jeffrey Lewis, director of Middlebury‚Äôs East Asia Nonproliferation Program, also frets that more hostile statements or tweets from Trump about North Korea could exacerbate an already-tense standoff between Washington and Pyongyang. The president‚Äôs taunts and derogatory nicknames for Kim, such as ‚ÄúLittle Rocket Man‚Äù and other insults, ‚Äúcreate an incentive for the North Koreans to stage provocations to show him up,‚Äù said Lewis. If the situation deteriorates into an acute crisis, such aggravating remarks from Trump could give the impression that a military strike is imminent, he added. ‚ÄúIf that happens, my belief is the North Koreans would use their nuclear weapons first, in order to try to repel an invasion.‚Äù

I think the best possible outcome is that it doesn‚Äôt lead to war. Catherine Dill, defense analyst at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies

Lewis does not anticipate a nuclear test or missile launch by North Korea during Trump‚Äôs Asia trip but notes that ‚Äúit‚Äôs possible they‚Äôll try to upstage [Trump]‚Äù with such a provocation as a form of political messaging. ‚Äú[North Korea] could totally do that. That is the kind of thing that they would do,‚Äù but they tend to scale back their missile tests during the colder months, he explained. The regime has timed several tests to coincide with politically significant events, including Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe‚Äôs visit to America and the eve of Independence Day in the U.S. As to whether Trump‚Äôs inflammatory rhetoric would be more damaging if issued while he‚Äôs in Asia rather than back in Washington, Lewis said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs all bad.‚Äù He likened the scenarios to choosing ‚Äúbetween plague and cholera.‚Äù
TITLE: Experts Urge Trump: 'Stick To The Script' In Asia, Don't Provoke North Korea

TEXT:
Quarantatreesima puntata Instaweek, il racconto fotografico firmato HuffPost. Questa settimana √® stata segnata da un nuovo attentato a New York, nella zona di Ground Zero, sedici anni dopo l'11 settembre: nel giorno di Halloween un furgone √® piombato su una pista ciclabile tra la Houston Street e la Chambers Street travolgendo alcune persone: otto vittime non si sono pi√π rialzate da terra, dodici i feriti. Alla guida del veicolo un giovane di 29 anni di origini uzbeke che aveva ottenuto la green card nel 2010. Sayfullo Habibullaevic Saipov √® sceso dal furgone urlando Allah Akbar, mentre accanto al veicolo gli investigatori hanno scoperto una dichiarazione in arabo di giuramento di fedelt√† all'Isis. Intanto, mentre l'Fbi si metteva sulle tracce di un secondo uomo che potrebbe aver collaborato con Sayfullo Saipov, il presidente Trump in un tweet ha invocato la pena di morte per il terrorista che "era soddisfatto e ha chiesto che la bandiera dell'Isis fosse appesa nella sua camera d'ospedale"; prima aveva evocato l'ipotesi di rinchiuderlo nel carcere di massima sicurezza di Guantanamo a Cuba.

Spostandoci in Europa, la fuga a Bruxelles - da molti definita badogliana - del leader indipendentista Carles Puigdemont e dei suoi i fedelissimi per chiedere asilo politico ha aggiunto un nuovo capitolo alla saga Catalogna-Spagna. L'ex presidente della Catalogna (destituito dai suoi poteri dal governo spagnolo dopo la dichiarazione d'indipendenza catalana) non si √® presentato al processo a Madrid, mentre il vicepresidente Oriol Junqueras e i sette ministri del Governo catalano hanno trascorso la notte in carcere dopo che la giudice Carmen Lamela ha ordinato la detenzione provvisoria. Rischiano 30 anni di carcere per ribellione, sedizione e malversazione.

SUMMARY:
Unfortunately for me, and for everybody else who eats eggs, there are some serious safety issues with the eggs we get in India.
While salmonella contamination is definitely a serious food safety issue, there is another, more disturbing issue with eggs in India; heavy metal and pesticide contamination!
The study noted heavy metal poisoning in children from eating contaminated eggs could result in IQ deficiencies and even mental retardation.
This makes it contamination of eggs a major food safety issue that the Government and the FSSAI need to tackle on a war footing.
The Business Standard article that I mentioned earlier did note that the Food Safety & Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) is in the process of introducing standards for fresh eggs.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

Eggs, in varying numbers and forms (currently 2), have been my staple breakfast for the better part of the last 20 years. In fact, one of my earliest memories is eating my eggs while on the train on my way to school. Eggs are also probably the only reason I got through hostel without becoming too malnourished. It's pretty safe to say that I can't live without eggs. Unfortunately for me, and for everybody else who eats eggs, there are some serious safety issues with the eggs we get in India.

The Business Standard and NDTV recently reported that some Indian poultry rearing farms maybe following practices that aren't upto international standards. Both reports relied on a study, which cited contaminated feed, bad rearing and handling practices, and non-sterilization of egg shells (a common practice in the West) as the reasons for egg contamination in India. The Business Standard report also noted that when eggs were collected from both urban retail outlets and directly from the farms, salmonella contamination, on the shell as well as in the eggs, was far more prevalent in the eggs collected from the urban retail outlets.

The NDTV report listed out a few precautions for people to take in order to avoid infections arising from consuming contaminated eggs. These measures include washing eggs before storing them, consuming them within 2 hours of taking them out of the refrigerator, not consuming raw or half cooked eggs, etc. NDTV also recommends using organic eggs. Unfortunately, organic eggs are ridiculously expensive in India.

Eggs should be making kids healthy, not sick!

While salmonella contamination is definitely a serious food safety issue, there is another, more disturbing issue with eggs in India; heavy metal and pesticide contamination! A 2005 study on organochloride pesticide residue in poultry feed, meat and eggs on a farm in Punjab found hexaxhlorocyclohexane (HCH) and dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane (DDT) residue in the eggs tested. The study noted that the residue content of both chemicals was above the maximum residue limits despite there being a BAN on the use of both chemicals for agricultural purposes in India. While one can always argues that it was an isolated incident and the sample size of the study was too small, I still find it disturbing that residues of BANNED pesticides were found. Another study, published in 2010, found lead and cadmium in the eggs tested. The study noted heavy metal poisoning in children from eating contaminated eggs could result in IQ deficiencies and even mental retardation.

Eggs are a popular food item whose consumption is encouraged, even by the Government, because it is considered a 'superfood'. This makes it contamination of eggs a major food safety issue that the Government and the FSSAI need to tackle on a war footing. The Business Standard article that I mentioned earlier did note that the Food Safety & Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) is in the process of introducing standards for fresh eggs. I think that these standards need to be notified as soon as possible. The FSSAI also needs to come up with an enforceable solution for the heavy metal contamination problem because that can't be dealt with at home through proper storage and cooking practices.

Eggs should be making kids healthy, not sick!
TITLE: Here's Some Bad News If You Live In India And Love Eating Eggs

M√âT√âO - Les Bouches-du-Rh√¥ne ont √©t√© plac√©s en vigilance orange jusqu'√† dimanche matin pour des risques d'orages violents, rejoignant ainsi le Gard et l'H√©rault, en proie √©galement √† des risques d'inondations, selon un bulletin de M√©t√©o France publi√© ce samedi 4 novembre dans la soir√©e.

Des orages violents sont attendus en milieu de nuit de samedi √† dimanche, accompagn√©s de fortes rafales de vent et parfois de gr√™le, dans les Bouches-du-Rh√¥ne, indique le pr√©visionniste. Dans l'H√©rault et le Gard, plac√©s tous deux en vigilance orange depuis 19H00, des orages, s'accompagnant de la foudre et de fortes pr√©cipitations, continuaient de s'abattre samedi soir.

On attend sur ces deux d√©partements du sud de la France jusqu'√† 80 mm de pluie en moins de trois heures, et des cumuls pouvant atteindre 80 √† 300 mm, localement. Pour les trois d√©partements, on atteint des "rafales soufflant jusqu'√† 110km/h", pr√©cise M√©t√©o France.

Le pr√©visionniste rappelle dans son communiqu√© qu'au cours d'√©pisodes orageux, il ne faut pas s'abriter sous un arbre, se promener en for√™ts ou montagne, √©viter d'utiliser un t√©l√©phone et des appareils √©lectriques, et signaler tout d√©part de feux.

SUMMARY:
The joys of this breathtaking and passionate affair is best summed up at the annual Dharamsala International Film Festival, now in its 6th edition.
Free from the tempting vanities that the Mumbai Film Festival seductively pulls off, Dharamsala Film Festival, like the actor Adil Hussain said, is a great festival because 'there is no red carpet.'
In that context, Hotel Salvation is also a very political choice as opening film, even if it's incidental and not deliberate.
Adil Hussain at the 6th Dharamsala International Film Festival.
About the film, Barry said, "A film like Mukti Bhavan is so moving and one is at a loss for words.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

There's nothing quite like the winter romance of mountains and the movies.

The joys of this breathtaking and passionate affair is best summed up at the annual Dharamsala International Film Festival, now in its 6th edition.

Monks, both young and old, dressed in soothing red robes, people the vibrant town, strolling across its long-winding streets. Clad stylishly in what appear Ray Bans, red sneakers, and black backpacks, they make for quite a sight.

Tourists, both local and foreign, walk the streets with the restless enthusiasm only wanderlust can inspire. At the central square is where the cinephiles gather, exchanging notes about what to watch and what to skip, and where to find the most delicious Momos (it's at the Tibet Kitchen btw, a lovely restaurant just around the corner of the square).

Assembled under trying circumstances and functioning with modest resources, DIFF opened Thursday evening at the Tibetan Children's Village (TCV) near the Dal lake, about 10 minutes away from Dharamsala's main town, McLeod Ganj.

Free from the tempting vanities that the Mumbai Film Festival seductively pulls off, Dharamsala Film Festival, like the actor Adil Hussain said, is a great festival because 'there is no red carpet.'

Hussain, a naturally gifted actor, who sprung up on the scene with his layered performance in Gauri Shinde's much-celebrated English Vinglish, was present at the opening ceremony as his film, Mukti Bhavan (Hotel Salvation is its international title), opened the festival.

Hotel Salvation, which translates to 'deliverance from harm', is an uniquely inspiring choice of film for a festival set in Dharamsala, a place that's largely populated by Tibetans who escaped home due to a brutal Chinese oppression in search of a safe place. The festival founders, Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, are vocal critics of the Chinese occupation of Tibet and its systematic cleansing of Tibetan culture.

In that context, Hotel Salvation is also a very political choice as opening film, even if it's incidental and not deliberate.

The film has been often cited as the best film of the year. At least that was the case until Amit Masurkar's Newton came along.

Directed by debutant Shubhashish Bhutiani, who was only 23 when he pitched the idea to Hussain, Mukti Bhavan is a hauntingly beautiful portrait of life and death and of troubled parent-offspring relationships.

As Hussain's character, Rajiv, takes his father to the titular hotel, where the elderly come to peacefully transition into the realm of the unknown, the film very subtly nudges one into examining our own attitudes towards mortality, parents as well as how their upbringing influences the way we end up treating our children. Incidentally, this was also one of the underlying themes in Titli.

Adil Hussain at the 6th Dharamsala International Film Festival.

Hussain and Behl have a fractured father-son relationship and it's this very complexity that Bhutiani explores with nuance and subtlety.

On the deathbed, can you get yourself to despise your father, or even love him fully, for the decisions that dramatically altered the course of your life? Hate, bitterness, distance are all components of the larger sentiment of love which overpowers most feelings in Hotel Salvation's morbid yet deeply funny universe.

The film has a terrific ensemble, led by Hussain and supported ably by Lalit Behl (who played the quietly sinister patriarch in Kanu Behl's Titli), Palomi Ghosh, Geetanjali Kulkarni, and Navnidra Behl.

Hussain spoke about how he drew out this part from his personal experience of having had a troubled relationship with his father, who wanted him to become a professor of English and not an actor. It was only in the last two years of his late father's life did he come around to approving his career choice, after watching an interview of his on the BBC.

About his performance, Hussain said, "I have learnt to be responsive and not reactive. I tend to internalise and hold back my emotions. Whatever seeps out is the performance you see on-screen."

Incidentally, Hussain's acting mentor, the legendary Barry John, was in the audience. About the film, Barry said, "A film like Mukti Bhavan is so moving and one is at a loss for words. There are so many emotions one experiences that one doesn't know how to cope with it."

It couldn't have been summed up in a better way.

The festival will continue until the weekend, where Rima Das' MAMI-favorite, Village Rockstars, plays as the closing film.

Among other films to be screened at the 4-day long festival include India's Oscar-entry Newton, Konkona Sen Sharma's A Death in the Gunj, and Rahul Jain's, Machines.

Also see on HuffPost:
TITLE: Dharamsala Film Festival 2017: Finding Salvation In The Mountains

TEXT:
J√ºrgen Trittin ist bei den Sondierungsgespr√§chen f√ºr eine Jamaika-Koalition Verhandler f√ºr die Gr√ºnen

In einem Interview hat der erfahrene Politiker nun Einblicke in die Vorg√§nge hinter verschlossenen T√ºren gegeben

Was Trittin beschreibt, mutet bisweilen bizarr an

Die gro√üe Zeit von J√ºrgen Trittin bei den Gr√ºnen schien eigentlich l√§ngst vorbei. Nach den Bundestagswahlen 2013 schob sich die Partei immer mehr in die b√ºrgerlich-gem√§chliche Mitte, J√ºrgen Trittin blieb eher allein am linken Rand zur√ºck. Einen gro√üen Posten hat der ehemalige Bundesminister nicht mehr inne.

Doch jetzt verhandelt Trittin f√ºr seine Partei mit √ºber die m√∂gliche Jamaika-Koalition. Pl√∂tzlich ist er wieder wichtig - und laut. Die "taz" schrieb unl√§ngst in einem Portrait √ºber Trittin, er sei f√ºr Union und FDP - aber auch f√ºr manche Parteikollegen, ein U-Boot: "Sie fragen sich, ob er f√ºr Jamaika Geleitschutz gibt oder ob er irgendwann den Torpedo auf den eigenen Tanker feuert."

Trittins Rolle bei den Gr√ºnen, so die Zeitung, sei w√§hrend der Sondierungsgespr√§che die des "diabolisch angehauchten Kotzbrockens, den die Gegenseite f√ºrchtet". In dieser Weise l√§sst sich auch ein Interview Trittins mit dem "Spiegel" lesen, in dem der Gr√ºnen-Politiker Union und FDP attackiert - und einen Einblick in bizarre Vorg√§nge bei den Jamaika-Verhandlungen gibt.

Trittin: "Das gleitet schon ins Satirische ab"

Gegen√ºber dem Magazin betont Trittin die Kompromissbereitschaft der Gr√ºnen w√§hrend der Verhandlungen - es seien vielmehr die FDP und besonders die Union, die blockieren w√ºrden. Im Fall der CDU spricht der Gr√ºne gar von einer "Totalblockade" und "absurden Streitigkeiten √ºber Begriffe".

So seien die Gespr√§che beim Thema Zukunft des Verbrennungsmotors an zwei W√∂rtern gescheitert: "Entdatum" und "Elektromobilit√§t". Beide Begriffe habe die CDU nicht in den Papieren haben wollen. Lieber wolle man dort √ºber "alternative Antriebe" schreiben.

"Das gleitet schon ins Satirische ab", echauffiert sich Trittin √ºber solche Wortklaubereien. Nach zwei, drei Stunden Streit h√§tten die Gr√ºnen sich dann einen Spa√ü erlaubt, und den Koalitionsvertrag von CDU und FDP in Nordrhein-Westfalen herausgeholt. "Da steht, dass NRW zum Vorreiter bei Elektromobilit√§t werden soll. Pl√∂tzlich hat die CDU ihren Widerstand aufgegeben."

Auch die FDP wird von Trittin deutlich kritisiert

Glaubt man Trittin, sei das gr√∂√üere Hindernis f√ºr eine Jamaika-Koalition jedoch vor allem die FDP.

Die habe lieber vier Jahre von rechts Opposition gegen eine Gro√üe Koalition machen wollen und k√§me nun aber nicht aus der Verantwortung. "Also provozieren sie uns, in der Hoffnung, dass wir Gr√ºne die Rei√üleine ziehen", sagt Trittin dem "Spiegel", "dabei untersch√§tzt die FDP unsere Intelligenz."

Am Ende l√§uft es nach Trittins Darstellung bei den Sondierungsgespr√§chen auf folgende Konstellation hinaus: Schwarz-Gelb blockiert, die Gr√ºnen seien bereit f√ºr Kompromisse, doch Union und FDP "sind sich offenbar einig, dass die Gr√ºnen m√∂glichst wenig, am besten gar nichts durchsetzen sollen".

‚û® Mehr zum Thema: CSU-Politiker Dobrindt w√ºtet: "Die Gr√ºnen provozieren das Scheitern von Jamaika"

Diese Anspannung f√ºhre dann dazu, dass man zwei Stunden √ºber das Wort "Elektromobilit√§t" streite. "Das verschwendet unn√ºtze Lebenszeit und tr√§gt nicht zur Verbesserung der Laune bei", findet Trittin. "Aber wenn wir Gr√ºne uns treffen, lachen wir ziemlich viel."

Gerade J√ºrgen Trittin hat daf√ºr allen Grund - er ist zur√ºck im Rampenlicht.

(lk)
TITLE: In einem Interview offenbart J√ºrgen Trittin, wie bizarr es bei den Jamaika-Verhandlungen zugeht

SUMMARY:
I tried to imagine what went through the minds of the first Anangu peoples who looked on the same scene more than 20,000 years ago.
A day earlier we had been walking around the base of Uluru while listening to Anangu traditional custodian Sammy Wilson recount the songlines of the Anangu ancestors.
But for Anangu, Uluru is a living entity, inseparable from the spirits which inhabit it.
And in the same way as you don't own your aging grandmother, the Anangu don't believe they own Uluru.
The Anangu people themselves only climb Uluru as part of their cultural ceremonies and initiation processes.
TEXT:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

As the first rays of morning light crept over the horizon, a hush fell over the waiting crowd.

Slowly -- oh so slowly -- the distinctive black silhouette on the horizon began to glow a deep, rich red and cascades of light and shade emerged. Crests of rock became lightning rods of colour and crevices and gaps fell into an even deeper darkness.

The familiar picture postcard had come to life.

I cast my mind's eye beneath the earth's surface and tried to imagine Uluru's submerged whole, extending a colossal six kilometres beneath the red dirt.

I tried to imagine what went through the minds of the first Anangu peoples who looked on the same scene more than 20,000 years ago. It wasn't hard to understand why, to them, this is a sacred place.

A day earlier we had been walking around the base of Uluru while listening to Anangu traditional custodian Sammy Wilson recount the songlines of the Anangu ancestors. According to the Tjukurpa (the traditional law of the Anangu people), these ancestors had helped shape and form the rock's many nooks, crevices and water holes, and their spirits still reside there today.

"We are part of the land and the land is part of me," explained traditional custodian Sammy Wilson.

Approaching Mutitjulu Waterhole at the base of Uluru, Sammy told us of Kuniya the Python woman, who travelled to Uluru to lay her eggs and whose snakelike form could be traced through an indentation in the rock surrounding the watering hole. Since transformed into a rainbow snake, whenever the pool runs dry she will return to fill it again.

The Anangu people may no longer rely on hunting and foraging the kernels of native plants for food, and they may live in man-made houses of brick and wood, but they still have the same ties to their traditional lands.

"We are part of the land and the land is part of me," Sammy explained to us.

It's an experience far removed from the "debate" which was brewing earlier this week as it emerged that the Uluru Kata Tjuta National Park's management would vote to close the national icon to climbers in two years' time.

While many supported the move out of respect to the site's first peoples, it was the voices of dissent that seemed to proclaim the loudest. Sentiments amounting to "it's just a big rock" and "we're all Australian, we should all be able to climb" were common repetitions on a theme.

The idea that the Anangu people "don't own" Uluru was also raised more than once by the armchair warriors. Well, the Anangu people would agree with the facts -- if not the sentiment -- of such words.

Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park was handed back to the Anangu people in 1985 and is run by a indigenous-majority board of management, so they do in fact "own" the site, alongside Australian Parks and Wildlife, according to a Western understanding of the word.

But for Anangu, Uluru is a living entity, inseparable from the spirits which inhabit it. And in the same way as you don't own your aging grandmother, the Anangu don't believe they own Uluru. Rather, they are custodians -- and it's a responsibility they take very seriously.

Mitijulu Waterhole is one of several pools around the base of Uluru.

Each time someone dies or is harmed climbing Uluru, instead of self-righteously proclaiming "serves you right", the locals express their grief. So you can only imagine their horror when they discover that the site's watering holes, many of them sacred, have been polluted by the excrement of visiting tourists who scale the rock.

The Anangu people themselves only climb Uluru as part of their cultural ceremonies and initiation processes. For them, the climb is not about any individual's rights or desires. It is about paying homage to their ancestors, obeying the law of the land and respecting the natural environment.

If we can learn from their example, then a visit to Australia's iconic red centre will truly prove an enriching adventure.

Having myself crossed continents in search of new peaks to climb, I sympathise with the irresistible urge to conquer every summit. But Uluru is much more than just a rock -- more, even, than a stunning and unique Australian icon.

If this landmark decision can help us surmount the wide divide that sadly still exists between Australia's first peoples and those of us who have come since, it will prove infinitely more enriching than any selfie at the summit.
TITLE: You Don't Need To Climb Uluru. Its Most Uplifting View Is From The Ground.

SUMMARY:
Women and children in J&K spend a lot of time walking to a source of drinking water away from their homes.
Akhtar and her neighbors collect water from the hillside because they find only that water fit for drinking.
In Harichander village of northern Bandipora district, young girls and women said that they consider themselves lucky when the water tanker comes to their village to supply drinking water.
In addition to that, she spends an average waiting time of 12 minutes a day at the principal source of drinking water.
However, in urban areas of J&K, a person spends 10 minutes to fetch drinking water, in addition to a waiting time of seven minutes.
TEXT:
Women and children in J&K spend a lot of time walking to a source of drinking water away from their homes. (Photo by Athar Parvaiz)

ADVERTISEMENT

By Athar Parvaiz*, Srinagar, Jammu & Kashmir

"Safe water, sanitation and hygiene at home should not be a privilege of only those who are rich or live in urban centers," Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the director general of WHO, said in a news release in July this year.

Villagers in many parts of Jammu and Kashmir feel exactly the same way. Residents of several villages across the state have to bear physical, economic and psychological hardship for getting access to water needed for their survival.

For a pot of water

Naseema Akhtar, a 40-year-old woman of Bonipora village in the northern Kupwara district, has to make several treks for collecting water from a small spring in the nearby hills. Akhtar and her neighbors collect water from the hillside because they find only that water fit for drinking. They don't have any piped water supply in their village.

"It does take us a lot of effort to fetch water from a spring situated way up, but we don't mind the trouble because we use this water without worrying about the consequences, given its purity," Akhtar told VillageSquare.in.

Source: National Sample Survey - 2016

According to a study by Water.org, disadvantaged women and children across the globe spend 200 million hours a day just to collect water, enough working time that could build nearly 30 Empire State Buildings.

Another study by University of Illinois says that the amount of time that women and children spend traveling to fetch water prohibits them from living out their full potential. Young girls often times have to miss school because they are traveling to provide water for their families, says the study.

Mubeena, a teenage girl in Kanihama village of Budgam district in central Kashmir, has appeared twice for her tenth standard exams, but was unsuccessful on both the occasions. The reason for her poor performance in studies is largely because she has spent most of her time in doing household chores including fetching water for the family, rather than attending school. "I don't want to write the exam again. I don't think I can do any better this time around," she told VillageSquare.in.

In Harichander village of northern Bandipora district, young girls and women said that they consider themselves lucky when the water tanker comes to their village to supply drinking water. "The tanker supply is not reliable. Sometimes we get it, sometimes we don't. When we don't get, we have to go and collect water from adjacent villages," Fatima told VillageSquare.in.

Paying and protesting for water

While some villages have access to piped water in the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K), there are still scores of villages that have to either make their own arrangements for getting potable water or have to be content with polluted water unsafe for drinking.

Abdul Gani Bhat of Bedibera village in Kupwara pays Rs 400 to a local tanker owner to fill the water tank in his house every week. The village, with over 500 households, experiences acute water shortage every summer. "This is an unnecessary expenditure. If we had proper water supply, there would be no need for me to spend on buying water," Bhat told VillageSquare.in.

People of different villages across J&K stage protests almost on a daily basis in summers for lack of drinking water and blame the authorities for not taking proper measures to address their grievances.

In late July this year, residents of Hompora village in Handwara area of north Kashmir staged protests for days, demanding piped water supply and tanker service for their village.

Source: National Sample Survey - 2016 According to a July 2017 UN report, of the 2.1 billion people in the world who do not have safely managed water, 844 million do not have access to basic drinking water. This includes 263 million people who have to spend over 30 minutes per trip collecting water from sources outside the house and 159 million who still drink untreated water from surface water sources, such as streams and lakes, says the report.

Traveling and waiting for water

The survey of National Sample Survey Office (NSSO) published in March 2016 reveals that a household member in rural areas of J&K spends an average time of 21 minutes a day to fetch drinking water from a source outside their premises. In addition to that, she spends an average waiting time of 12 minutes a day at the principal source of drinking water.

However, in urban areas of J&K, a person spends 10 minutes to fetch drinking water, in addition to a waiting time of seven minutes. The figures show the disparity in availability of water between urban and rural localities.

The district level results of the survey reveal that rural areas of Reasi district in Jammu Division fares the poorest. A household member spends an average traveling time of 34 minutes and a waiting time of 17 minutes. Reasi is followed by Rajouri district where a person spends 30 minutes of travel time, with 16 minutes of waiting time. Akhtar and her neighbors of Bonipora in Kupwara district spend at least two hours every day for fetching water.

Source: National Sample Survey - 2016 As for the districts of Kashmir Division, a villager of Anantnag district spends 33 minutes of travel time and 30 minutes of waiting time. In Pulwama district a person spends travelling time and waiting time of 29 minutes and 23 minutes respectively.

According to the survey, in the rural areas of Jammu Division, 42.6 % households get drinking water within their premises, as compared to 68.3 % in Kashmir Division. In urban areas, it is 94.3 % and 79.2% in Jammu Division and Kashmir Division respectively.

In Jammu Division, where there is no drinking water source within the premises, 29.9 % people in rural areas and 4.2 % people in urban areas travel less than 0.5 km to reach principal source of drinking water. In Kashmir Division, 26.1 % households in rural areas travel less than 0.5 km to reach a water source outside their premises.

"We have to walk more than 1 km to collect water for our daily use. This is total injustice," Abdul Subhan, a resident of Hompora village, told VillageSquare.in. "We have raised this issue several times, but it is yet to be fulfilled."

Athar Parvaiz is a Srinagar-based journalist.

This article was first published on VillageSquare.in, a public-interest communications platform focused on rural India.

The opinions expressed in this post are the personal views of the author. They do not necessarily reflect the views of HuffPost India. Any omissions or errors are the author's and HuffPost India does not assume any liability or responsibility for them.
TITLE: In The Absence Of Piped Water, Some Kashmiri Women Have To Trek Miles Uphill To Fetch Drinking Water

SUMMARY:
Plus que √ßa, je pense m√™me que les jeux vid√©o ont tout √† fait leur place dans la comp√©tition sportive la plus prestigieuse au monde!
Le tir √† l'arc, le tir √† la carabine, le golf ou encore le curling sont bien repr√©sent√©s aux Jeux Olympiques.
Cette opposition entre jeux vid√©o et bonne sant√© doit-elle emp√™cher l'e-sport d'int√©grer les Jeux Olympiques?
Et si on montrait au monde les jeux vid√©o comme une activit√© comp√©titive, pr√¥nant l'esprit d'√©quipe, le d√©passement de soi et le respect d'autrui?
Ces valeurs sont partag√©es par l'e-sport et par le sport traditionnel, et il serait grand temps que le grand public en soit inform√©.
TEXT:
La nouvelle s'est rapidement r√©pandue: le sport √©lectronique, plus commun√©ment appel√© e-sport, pourrait figurer sur la liste des disciplines aux Jeux Olympiques de Paris en 2024. C'est tout du moins ce qu'a laiss√© entendre Tony Estanguet, le Pr√©sident du Comit√© d'Organisation lors d'une interview:

"Nous devons nous pencher sur la question car nous ne pouvons pas dire 'non, √ßa ne nous regarde pas, √ßa n'a rien √† voir avec les JO'. La jeunesse est int√©ress√©e par l'e-sport et ce genre de pratiques. Nous devons y pr√™ter attention. Nous devons les rencontrer et voir si nous pouvons tisser des liens. Je ne veux pas dire 'non' d√®s le d√©but. Je pense qu'il est int√©ressant d'interagir avec le Comit√© Olympique International, avec les joueurs, avec la famille de l'e-sport, pour mieux comprendre comment cela fonctionne et pourquoi c'est un tel succ√®s."

Depuis cette d√©claration, les grands acteurs du sport mais aussi du milieu des jeux vid√©o y vont de leur opinion sur la question et les avis sont partag√©s chez les sportifs comme chez les joueurs. J'ai d'ailleurs compil√© les d√©clarations de quelques acteurs majeurs de l'e-sport fran√ßais que vous pourrez trouver sur le blog Gamezine.fr

En tant que passionn√© d'e-sport et amateur de sport traditionnel, je suis fermement convaincu que la repr√©sentation des jeux vid√©o comp√©titifs aux Jeux Olympiques de Paris est concevable. Plus que √ßa, je pense m√™me que les jeux vid√©o ont tout √† fait leur place dans la comp√©tition sportive la plus prestigieuse au monde!

L'e-sport est-il un sport?

Il faut avouer que la fronti√®re du sport est vague: l'effort physique est-il une composante indispensable pour qu'une activit√© puisse √™tre appel√©e "sport"? Et si cette question n'avait finalement pas tellement d'importance?

Le tir √† l'arc, le tir √† la carabine, le golf ou encore le curling sont bien repr√©sent√©s aux Jeux Olympiques. Et de nouvelles activit√©s peu physiques pourraient rejoindre la liste puisque la p√©tanque et le billard ont aussi candidats pour une int√©gration aux JO de Paris.

L'e-sport est tr√®s similaire aux sports √©voqu√©s ci-dessus si l'on se penche uniquement sur les aptitudes qui permettent aux athl√®tes de performer au plus haut niveau: de l'adresse, un esprit d'analyse, une strat√©gie efficace et m√™me des r√©flexes et un solide esprit d'√©quipe pour certains titres.

Le symbole d'une nouvelle g√©n√©ration de comp√©titeurs

L'e-sport est loin d'√™tre un effet de mode r√©cent et passager. Si les m√©dias ne s'y int√©ressent que depuis quelques ann√©es avec l'explosion de l'audience et des cash prizes de jeux comme League of Legends, Dota2 ou CS:GO, les jeux vid√©o comp√©titifs sont pratiqu√©s activement depuis pr√®s de 20 ans.

Aujourd'hui, si les jeux vid√©o ont encore mauvaise r√©putation aux yeux du grand public, ils sont devenus un support de loisir et de comp√©tition incontournable pour une grande partie de la population, notamment les 15-25 ans. Comme l'a indiqu√© Tony Estanguet dans son interview, l'e-sport a aujourd'hui trop d'ampleur pour √™tre simplement ignor√©... et l'√©volution de cette discipline n'est pas pr√™te de s'arr√™ter!

Les Jeux Olympiques ont cette image de graal ultime pour tout comp√©titeur: la plus prestigieuse des comp√©titions de sport au monde. C'est donc tout naturellement que la possibilit√© de voir de l'e-sport aux JO remplit d'√©toiles les yeux de nombreux passionn√©s.

Un message important √† passer

Alors que notre soci√©t√© est plus s√©dentaire que jamais, le Jeux Olympiques promeuvent le sport et ses bienfaits pour la sant√©. Les jeux vid√©o quant √† eux sont au contraire l'un des symboles de cette s√©dentarit√© pouss√©e √† ses extr√™mes et n√©faste pour notre sant√©.

Cette opposition entre jeux vid√©o et bonne sant√© doit-elle emp√™cher l'e-sport d'int√©grer les Jeux Olympiques? Surtout pas, au contraire!

Certains √©diteurs de jeux vid√©o, √† l'image de Riot Games et son c√©l√®bre jeu League of Legends, tentent au fil du temps de mettre en avant l'importance de l'activit√© physique dans la vie d'un joueur. Au travers de diff√©rents spots publicitaires et documentaires sur les joueurs professionnels, la soci√©t√© am√©ricaine vante les vertus d'une activit√© physique sur les performances en jeu. Le dicton "un esprit sain dans un corps sain" s'applique parfaitement √† l'e-sport.

Int√©grer l'e-sport aux Jeux Olympiques serait un pas de g√©ant pour mettre une bonne fois pour toute l'accent sur l'importance de l'activit√© physique dans la vie d'un joueur de jeux vid√©o. La mise en avant de l'exercice physique aupr√®s des communaut√©s les plus s√©dentaires est une mission d'int√©r√™t g√©n√©ral et les Jeux Olympiques sont la comp√©tition id√©ale pour avancer sur le sujet.

R√©concilier le grand public avec les jeux vid√©o

L'image n√©gative que transporte les jeux vid√©o aux yeux du grand public (fran√ßais tout du moins) est loin de s'√™tre totalement r√©sorb√©e au fil des ann√©es. Demandez √† une personne √¢g√©e ce qu'elle pense des joueurs d'√©checs et des joueurs de jeux vid√©o. Elle aura souvent une image radicalement diff√©rente des deux disciplines alors qu'elles ont de nombreuses similitudes: pas d'activit√© physique intense, une grande demande de concentration, d'analyse et de strat√©gie (tous les jeux ne demandent √©videmment pas ces m√™mes aptitudes). Non, les faits divers alarmants sur les exc√®s d'une poign√©e de joueurs ne sont pas repr√©sentatifs de l'ensemble de la communaut√©!

Et si on montrait au monde les jeux vid√©o comme une activit√© comp√©titive, pr√¥nant l'esprit d'√©quipe, le d√©passement de soi et le respect d'autrui? Ces valeurs sont partag√©es par l'e-sport et par le sport traditionnel, et il serait grand temps que le grand public en soit inform√©. Alors que cette discipline concerne aujourd'hui des millions de joueurs √† travers le monde, l'exposer sous son meilleur jour √† un public aussi large que celui des JO serait une belle avanc√©e pour att√©nuer l'image injustement n√©gative des jeux vid√©o.

√Ä voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Pourquoi l‚Äôe-sport a sa place aux Jeux Olympiques de 2024

SUMMARY:
Tatiana and Krista Hogan are craniopagus twins who live with their family in Vernon, B.C.
"We didn't know if they were going to survive 24 hours," Felicia Hogan says of her daughters Krista and Tatiana in a new CBC documentary.
Along with the twins, Hogan and her husband Brendan are raising three other children: 15-year-old Rosa, 13-year-old Christopher, and 9-year-old Shaylee.
Tatiana and Krista Hogan pose for a photo with family.
Conjoined twin Tatiana and Krista Hogan are held by their mother Felicia in Vernon, B.C.
TEXT:
Tatiana and Krista Hogan are craniopagus twins who live with their family in Vernon, B.C.

They weren't supposed to make it out of infancy.

"We didn't know if they were going to survive 24 hours," Felicia Hogan says of her daughters Krista and Tatiana in a new CBC documentary. "And then 24 hours went by and they survived."

The twins have done more than survive. They celebrated their 11th birthday in October. They've learned to swim. And despite dealing with Type 1 diabetes and epilepsy, Krista and Tatiana go to school in Vernon, B.C. for a few hours every day.

"For them to actually be here for 10 years is just a blessing," Hogan told HuffPost Canada in an interview. "It just felt so good to see them get to this milestone."

The documentary "Inseparable: Ten Years Joined At The Head," follows the Hogan family for a year leading up to the girls' 10th birthday party. Along with the twins, Hogan and her husband Brendan are raising three other children: 15-year-old Rosa, 13-year-old Christopher, and 9-year-old Shaylee.

Krista and Tatiana are ordinary girls with extraordinary abilities. As craniopagus twins ‚Äî conjoined twins attached at the head ‚Äî they are one in 2.5 million. They share a "thalamic bridge" that connects their brains, allowing them to see through each other's eyes, taste what each other eats, and even know each other's thoughts without speaking.

"The abilities they have that no one else could imagine having are just incredible," Hogan said. They play together, and without saying a word, get up when one decides she wants to do something else.

They're just little people that are here living their lives like the rest of us. Felicia Hogan

Krista and Tatiana's doctor, pediatric neurologist Dr. Juliette Hukin, has tracked their development since they were two. "They're the only twins that I'm aware of who are alive and remain conjoined with this shared connectivity," Hukin said in a press release.

Now that the girls are old enough to describe their experiences, doctors can better understand their connection, said the documentary's director and executive producer Judith Pyke.

"It was cool to hear from them about how they can see through each others' eyes or move each others' limbs," Pyke said in an email. "But just as striking is they get along incredibly well."

Tatiana and Krista Hogan pose for a photo with family.

Despite their unfathomable connection, they're very typical siblings, Hogan said. They have "off moments" when they argue and scream at each other.

"They're definitely different" in personality, she pointed out.

Krista is the family's jokester. She loves playing pranks and making people laugh. She is also the bigger twin and tends to take charge, Hogan explained.

Tatiana, on the other hand, is a "little lovebug." She loves cuddling animals and wants to hug everyone who comes by the house.

The girls love running around outside and going camping ‚Äî and like all kids these days, play video games and watch funny videos on their iPad.

Conjoined twin Tatiana and Krista Hogan are held by their mother Felicia in Vernon, B.C. on Dec. 18, 2006.

Felicia Hogan hugs her daughter Krista.

"They're just little people that are here living their lives like the rest of us," Hogan said. "That's how we see them and that's how their siblings see them."

"Inseparable: Ten Years Joined At The Head" premiers on CBC this Sunday, Nov. 5 at 9 p.m. ET.

Hogan said this will be the last documentary about the twins for now. Now that they're 11, she said, they can decide for themselves how much to share with the world.

Previously On HuffPost:
TITLE: Tatiana And Krista Hogan Featured In CBC Documentary 'Inseparable'

TEXT:
A trav√©s de varios testimonios, el diario Milwaukee Journal Sentinel denunci√≥ a la empresa TripAdvisor de borrar comentarios que alertaban a los usuarios, sobre presuntas violaciones, asaltos y apagones en algunos complejos tur√≠sticos mexicanos.

En el caso m√°s reciente ocurrido en julio pasado, Journal Sentiniel detall√≥ que una mujer de Indian√°polis cuestion√≥ en la p√°gina especializada en viajes, si deb√≠a viajar a la Riviera Maya, puesto que hab√≠a le√≠do que en los centros tur√≠sticos hab√≠a problemas con el alcohol, y que incluso unos turistas hab√≠an sido asaltados, violados y asesinados.

Despu√©s de 10 d√≠as, la pregunta expuesta en el foro logr√≥ 55 comentarios. Algunos positivos y unos m√°s con comentarios irrelevantes. Lo curioso fue que al menos 27 mensajes fueron borrados y en su lugar hab√≠a un mensaje de TripAdvisor que citaba varios motivos de eliminaci√≥n: "inapropiados", "fuera de tema" o con "lenguaje que no era 'familiar'".

Aunque el peri√≥dico solicit√≥ a la empresa revisar los comentarios omitidos, la compa√±√≠a se neg√≥.

En otro hecho, la estadounidense Kristie Love denunci√≥ en 2010, haber sido violada por un guardia de seguridad de la cadena hotelera Iberostar en la Riviera Maya.

Ante la falta de apoyo por parte de las autoridades, Love decidi√≥ recurrir al foro de TripAdvisor, para alertar a los dem√°s turistas; sin embargo, su comentario fue eliminado de la plataforma, por no ser apto para los usuarios.

La empresa con sede en Massachusetts, Estados Unidos explic√≥ este jueves a trav√©s de sus redes sociales, que las publicaciones fueron borradas al momento, debido a que violaban las normas y neg√≥ que la decisi√≥n fuera tomada por considerar que sus ingresos resultaran perjudicados.

We want to address statements made by a recent news article and since widely reported on. Our full statement: https://t.co/SNL0VDCQ8Z pic.twitter.com/idEpMoTKKk
TITLE: Denuncian a TripAdvisor de borrar mensajes que alertaban sobre violaciones y robos en la Riviera Maya

ENVIRONNEMENT - Le gouvernement de Donald Trump doit publier ce vendredi 3 novembre un important rapport scientifique sur le climat, qui selon des fuites, conclut que le changement climatique r√©sulte bien des activit√©s humaines et affecte d√©j√† la vie des Am√©ricains.

Ces conclusions contredisent les d√©clarations de nombreux membres de l'Administration Trump, y compris celles du pr√©sident, tr√®s ambigu sur le sujet.

Ce document, "Fourth National Climate Assessment", (4e √©valuation nationale du climat), mandat√© par le Congr√®s, est publi√© tous les quatre ans. Il a √©t√© approuv√© par l'Acad√©mie am√©ricaine des sciences et devait recevoir le feu vert de la Maison Blanche pour √™tre rendu public.

Le r√©chauffement climatique, ce "canular chinois"

Durant sa campagne √©lectorale Donald Trump avait qualifi√© le changement climatique de "canular chinois" pour p√©naliser l'√©conomie am√©ricaine avant d'annoncer en juin le retrait des Etats-Unis de l'Accord de Paris sur le climat.

La temp√©rature moyenne aux Etats-Unis a augment√© rapidement depuis 1980 et les r√©centes d√©cennies ont √©t√© les plus chaudes depuis les 1500 derni√®res ann√©es, selon une mouture pr√©liminaire de ce rapport, auquel ont contribu√© des scientifiques de treize agences f√©d√©rales et r√©v√©l√© en ao√ªt dernier par le New York Times.

Ils ont conclu que les Am√©ricains ressentent d'ores et d√©j√† les effets du changement climatique. Aux Etats-Unis, le rapport conclut avec un degr√© "tr√®s √©lev√©" de certitude que le nombre de nuits tr√®s froides avait diminu√© depuis les ann√©es 1960 tandis que la fr√©quence de journ√©es chaudes et caniculaires avait augment√©.

L'influence humaine comme "cause dominante"

Les auteurs du document soulignent que des milliers d'√©tudes effectu√©es par des dizaines de milliers de scientifiques, ont constat√© et mesur√© le changement climatique au sol, dans les oc√©ans et dans l'atmosph√®re.

"De nombreux indices montrent que les activit√©s humaines, surtout les √©missions de gaz √† effet de serre, sont principalement responsables du changement du climat observ√© r√©cemment", ont-ils √©crit, estimant "extr√™mement probable que l'influence humaine est une cause dominante du r√©chauffement observ√© depuis le milieu du 20e si√®cle".

Ces conclusions contredisent directement les affirmations de Donald Trump et de membres de son Administration dont notamment Scott Pruitt, le directeur de l'Agence de protection de l'environnement (EPA), un climato-sceptique proche du secteur des √©nergies fossiles. Selon ce dernier, la contribution humaine au changement du climat est "incertaine" et la capacit√© de pr√©voir ses effets est de ce fait limit√©e.

Cit√©e par le New York Times, Katharine Hayhoe, professeur de science politique √† l'Universit√© Texas Tech, une des scientifiques ayant travaill√© sur le document, a jug√© qu'il s'agissait "du rapport le plus complet √† ce jour sur la science du climat" devant √™tre publi√©.

Le rapport complet et mis √† jour devait √™tre divulgu√© ce vendredi √† 17h (heure de Paris) par l'Agence nationale oc√©anique et atmosph√©rique (NOAA). Le "Climate Science Special Report" qui fait partie de l'√©valuation nationale du climat (National Climate Assessment) "est un examen de la science du changement climatique qui fait autorit√© et se concentre sur les Etats-Unis", a pr√©cis√© la NOAA dans un communiqu√© avant la publication. "Il sert de fondement dans les efforts d'√©valuation des risques li√©s au climat et pour aider √† mieux s'y pr√©parer", ajoute l'agence.

Le s√©nateur d√©mocrate Al Franken (Minnesota) et huit de ses coll√®gues ont envoy√© cette semaine une lettre au pr√©sident Trump lui demandant d'indiquer "quelles mesures avaient √©t√© prises pour garantir que ce rapport scientifique sur le climat soit prot√©g√© de toutes interf√©rences politiques". Ce groupe de s√©nateurs a √©galement press√© l'Administration Trump d'agir en r√©ponse aux conclusions du rapport.

TITLE: Ce rapport du gouvernement Trump sur le climat ne va pas lui plaire
