SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTThe Collins Dictionary has said the "word of the year" is "fake news" though of course that's two words.
While Trump may have helped Fake News win the word-of-the-year mantle, India has been quite a fake news factory.
BJP leader Priti Gandhi posted Julian Assange's fake endorsement of Narendra Modi for Prime Minister which Wikileaks had to deny.
"Now they want us to bleed more by telling the state government to stop state advertisements as well," he said.
The government's idea to crack down on fake news sounds like good news.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

The Collins Dictionary has said the "word of the year" is "fake news" though of course that's two words. It had seen an unprecedented usage increase of 365% since 2016. "Fake news today is legitimate news," it said.

Helen Newstead, the head of language content, said, "Fake news, either as a statement of fact or as an accusation, has been inescapable, contributing to the undermining of society's trust in news reporting."

While Trump may have helped Fake News win the word-of-the-year mantle, India has been quite a fake news factory.

Now, according to Asian Age, the government is contemplating cracking down on fake news.

And about time. Fake news in India is like air pollution in Delhi ‚Äì toxic, stubborn and growing stronger.

The government has said official advertisements should be denied to outlets that indulge in "unethical reporting", news published out of "bad intent" and "fake news".

The Directorate of Advertising & Visual Publicity will stop release of advertisements to such publications. Until now the print media policy already stated a newspaper could be suspended from empanelment if it was found to have deliberately submitted false information regarding circulation.

This is not symbolic. Government ads are a major source of revenue for media.

The devil, as always, lies in the details. What is fake news? And who defines it? Who defines bad intent? Clearly one person's fake news is another person's truth or at least their agenda.

Fake news in India is like air pollution in Delhi ‚Äì toxic, stubborn and growing stronger.

Take a few recent examples:

During the riots in Basirhat, an image of a burning vehicle was sent out as part of a call to #SaveBengal. It was shared by Nupur Sharma, BJP spokesperson from Delhi and used on a flyer for protests. The image, it turned out, was from the 2002 Gujarat riots under Narendra Modi's watch.

BJP IT cell head Amit Malviya has been caught more than once peddling fake news, tweets he has refused to take down even after they have been proved to be false. Once he circulated a mischievously edited video clip of NDTV anchor Ravish Kumar. Another time during the Ram Rahim trial he posted a picture of Rahul Gandhi meeting Sant Niranjan Dass of Dera Sach Khand Ballan but captioned it as "Rahul Gandhi visited Dera Sach Sauda as recently as Jan 2017 to seek support."

BJP leader Priti Gandhi posted Julian Assange's fake endorsement of Narendra Modi for Prime Minister which Wikileaks had to deny.

These could be honest mistakes. Who among us has not fallen for fake news, especially when it fits our ideological bias? But sometimes it's far more deliberate and it comes from within the government itself, not some mischief monger on social media.

The state-run Press Information Bureau infamously photoshopped a picture of Narendra Modi looking at flood-ravaged Chennai with divyadrishti clarity through his chopper window. And of course, that iconic "rare" picture of Modi sweeping the floor at a 1988 RSS rally turned out to be a well-morphed fake photo.

So when it comes to curing the epidemic of fake news, physician heal thyself.

Does this mean the BJP is the sole offender? Of course, not. But as Rohan Venkataramakrishnan points out in Scroll, the BJP was an "early pioneer when it came to using the internet for organizing and building political awareness" and it also "has been at the forefront of the fake news phenomenon, with top party leaders and ministers occasionally revealing the kinds of dishonest messages that are much more rampant among the base."

Even more worryingly, in a country where the phrase "anti-national"can be used casually as a bludgeon to silence any dissent that is too bothersome, these new DAVP guidelines could just be another weapon to bring media to heel. The Centre has already told the Jammu and Kashmir government to stop advertising in local newspapers that allegedly publish "anti-national"articles "glamorizing terrorists and anti-national elements". Shujaat Bukhari, editor of Rising Kashmir told HT that three major newspapers there, including his own, are banned from getting central government ads for eight years because they cover "anti-national" issues, for example, the funerals of militants. "Now they want us to bleed more by telling the state government to stop state advertisements as well," he said.

So when it comes to curing the epidemic of fake news, physician heal thyself.

Government ads have long been part of a strategy to make sure that media does not get too uppity. As other ad revenues shrink government ads gain even more clout.

In 2012, Dhirendra K. Jha dubbed Nitish Kumar Bihar's editor-in-chief because he used the government's ad budget to control and bend the media to his will. The editor of Bihartimes.com said though it has been "No. 1" since inception in 1999, its application for empanelment with the Public Relations Department was kept pending without any "concrete reason" while a site based in Bhopal with tenuous connections to Bihar got government ads. He said he believes it's because his site carries reports related to corruption in the state. An Urdu paper Pindar ran afoul of the government because of a piece by its chief editor that apparently upset the government. The editor, Raihan Ghani, said he was demoted to managing editor and eventually resigned. Curiously the year after Ghani was gagged, the paper's government ad revenues ballooned from 1 lakh to 24 and the year after to 40 lakh.

When the ABP group in Bengal was perceived at loggerheads with the Trinamool government, Mamata Banerjee had banned their newspapers from state libraries. Global campaign group Avaaz said that five West Bengal outdoor advertising agencies and one newspaper group refused to run ads urging Mamata Banerjee to "stop attacking protesters and start attacking the problem" after the gangrape of a young woman in Kamduni. Jayalalithaa's Tamil Nadu was boomtown for lawsuits against media perceived as being overly critical of the government. In five years it filed 213 defamation cases against political opponents, 55 of them against media houses for "derogatory " statements whether it was reporting on the CM's vacations or water scarcity in Tamil Nadu. Its predecessor DMK was a poor second with 40 cases between 2006 and 2011.

The government's idea to crack down on fake news sounds like good news. Who could argue with punishing the purveyors of fake news? But the fear is it will have little to do with promoting free and fair journalism and far more to do with the carrot-and-stick policy that makes media toe the line.

Also On HuffPost:
TITLE: Is The Government's Crackdown On Fake News Another Way Of Controlling The Media?

TEXT:
(Photo by Marco Piraccini\Archivio Marco Piraccini\Mondadori Portfolio via Getty Images)

"I cinque stelle mi potevano incuriosire prima, ma con le ultime esperienze che hanno avuto di amministrazione non so se sarei cos√¨ convinto". Protagonista questa sera del Faccia a Faccia di Giovanni Minoli, in onda alle 20.30 su La7, Gianni Morandi dice la sua ad ampio raggio, dalla politica a XFactor fino al festival di Sanremo. E non nasconde delusioni e speranze, come quella sul segretario del Pd: "Sembrava che Renzi fosse un leader che ci potesse accompagnare a fare un passo in pi√π". Deluso? "Mah, non lo so, stiamo a vedere cosa far√†".

In generale, riflette l'interprete di tante hit, da Fatti mandare dalla mamma a C'era un ragazzo che come me, "L'Italia ha perso molte di quelle speranze che avevamo negli anni '60. Oggi √® molto disordinata , non √® compatta e non conosciamo pi√π il senso del collettivo: ognuno ha sempre la propria squadra, ognuno ha sempre la propria idea di politica e ognuno vuol fare un partito".

E a Minoli che gli chiede perch√© la politica non riesce pi√π a dare risposte, Morandi risponde: "Forse non abbiamo dei grandi politici che lo facevano con passione come i nostri vecchi a cominciare da De Gasperi, Berlinguer, Zaccagnini e lo stesso Andreotti".

Quanto a XFactor, "√® una scuola - sottolinea Morandi- Il problema vero √® che l√¨ si prende molta luce e poi dopo pu√≤ essere pericoloso quando si spegne tutto e non tutti i ragazzi capiscono che si tratta di un un punto di partenza e non di arrivo".

Immancabile la domanda sul Festival di Sanremo, che quest'anno √® affidato alla direzione di Claudio Baglioni suo compagno di viaggio nel tour Capitani Coraggiosi: "√à una buona scelta quella di Baglioni perch√© √® metodico, preciso, grande musicista e sar√† capace di fare un grande festival". Morandi andr√† a Sanremo? "Mah, se mi invitano chiss√†...".
TITLE: Gianni Morandi: "I 5 stelle mi incuriosivano, ma oggi non sono pi√π convinto"

SUMMARY:
Nadya from @pussyrrriot issues a warning: "I hear from Donald Trump the same words about media that Putin was using for 17 years."
#LastWord pic.twitter.com/J68VTrl5iXPussy Riot's Nadya Tolokonnikova says President Donald Trump is not so different from his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin.
I've seen it, in front of my eyes, for the last 17 years, and I hear it from Donald Trump the same words about media that Putin was using for 17 years," said Tolokonnikova.
Tolokonnikova also claimed that Trump's supposed lack of any true political beliefs played perfectly into Putin's hands.
And that's perfectly understandable for Putin as a (former) KGB agent," she said.
TEXT:
Nadya from @pussyrrriot issues a warning: "I hear from Donald Trump the same words about media that Putin was using for 17 years." #LastWord pic.twitter.com/J68VTrl5iX

Pussy Riot's Nadya Tolokonnikova says President Donald Trump is not so different from his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin.

In an interview Friday night with MSNBC's Lawrence O'Donnell, the founder of the Russian punk rock group, which often criticises Putin, said both leaders were intent on "eroding" their respective nations' institutions.

"I think they make us forget that citizenship is not just using things that your government is giving to you but giving back to your government and protecting those institutions like democracy," Tolokonnikova said.

The two presidents also share similar views about their critics and the media, she added.

"I've seen how badly it can turn. I've seen it, in front of my eyes, for the last 17 years, and I hear it from Donald Trump the same words about media that Putin was using for 17 years," said Tolokonnikova. "That it's fake news, that are paid by foreign governments and whoever."

Tolokonnikova also claimed that Trump's supposed lack of any true political beliefs played perfectly into Putin's hands.

"He's (Trump) really concerned with himself, with his fame and his wealth. And that's perfectly understandable for Putin as a (former) KGB agent," she said. "He knows how to deal with people who are easy to understand or easy to bribe."

Check out a segment of the interview above.
TITLE: Pussy Riot Star Breaks Down The Similarities Between Trump And Putin

TEXT:
POLITIQUE - Elle trouve l'article publi√© samedi 4 novembre par Le Monde "profond√©ment scandaleux". Invit√©e de "Dimanche en politique" sur France 3 ce dimanche 5 novembre, Marine Le Pen a rejet√© en bloc les r√©v√©lations du quotidien du soir, qui affirme que des cas de harc√®lements mettant en cause l'un de ses proches, Axel Lousteau, sont pass√©s sous silence au sein du parti d'extr√™me droite.

"J'ai trouv√© l'article du Monde profond√©ment scandaleux (...) Il ne s'agit pas de harc√®lement, mais de s√©parations de deux couples qui se sont mal pass√©es", a affirm√© la d√©put√©e du Nord, estimant que cette affaire relevait de la vie priv√©e. "Dans un des deux cas, c'est m√™me le tr√©sorier d'un pr√©sident du groupe du FN qui est all√© au commissariat avec la jeune femme pour l'accompagner dans sa plainte", affirme-t-elle, mettant en cause le "s√©rieux" du journal.

Concernant les intentions du Monde justement, Marine Le Pen affirme que cet article vise en r√©alit√© √† passer sous silence les accusations prof√©r√©es dans un livre √† l'encontre de Pierre Berg√© (d√©funt actionnaire du groupe Le Monde, auquel appartient Le HuffPost, ndlr). "Peut-√™tre est-ce pour d√©tourner le regard des horreurs que l'on apprend sur l'ancien propri√©taire du Monde Pierre Berg√©, qui est accus√© dans un livre, d'avoir autoris√© des actes de p√©dophilie dans sa maison de Marrakech", a-t-elle accus√©, alors que les journalistes l'alertaient sur les risques de diffamation qu'elle encourait en relayant ces affirmations (vid√©o en t√™te d'article).

Dans un livre largement comment√© dans les r√©seaux de la fachosph√®re ces derniers jours, un ex-amant de Yves-Saint-Laurent affirme (sans apporter de preuves) avoir assist√© √† des actes p√©dophiles impliquant le couturier et l'homme d'affaires.

Un proche de Marine Le Pen mis en cause

Ce n'est pas n'importe quel responsable qui est mis en cause dans l'article du Monde. Axel Lousteau, proche de Marine Le Pen et tr√©sorier de son micro-parti Jeanne, est accus√© d'avoir harcel√© une ancienne collaboratrice entre 2015 et 2016. "Il ne cesse de me menacer, moi et ma famille. Il a op√©r√© un vrai harc√®lement moral afin que je ne puisse pas √™tre embauch√©e", a d√©clar√© cette derni√®re aux enqu√™teurs.

Selon des SMS que Le Monde a pu consulter, Axel Lousteau a prof√©r√© des menaces explicites √† cette collaboratrice. "Sur tes parents, c'est pas des menaces, c'est une promesse", aurait √©crit ce cadre frontiste. Autre SMS r√©v√©l√© par le quotidien: "Tu veux faire du mal √† ma famille? Je vais te prouver qu'√† ce jeu-l√†, je suis redoutable". Toujours selon ce que dit cette ancienne militante, Axel Lousteau aurait d√©pos√© sur son bureau une balle de 9mm en guise d'avertissement.

√Ä voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Marine Le Pen balaie d'un revers les r√©v√©lations du "Monde" sur des accusations de harc√®lement au Front national

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTBHOPAL -- Five days after the gangrape of a 19-year-old college student in Bhopal, the Madhya Pradesh government has transferred two senior officers including Inspector General of Police (IG).
Railway police official, Anita Malviya, who had faced strong criticism for allegedly being insensitive during the handling of the case, has also been transferred.
This is the first action that has been taken against senior officials.
Till now mostly the lower rank officials including three SHOs apart and a middle-level official had faced action.
Though he has been removed from the post of IG Bhopal, Choudhary has been given the charge of IG (Law-and-Order).
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

BHOPAL -- Five days after the gangrape of a 19-year-old college student in Bhopal, the Madhya Pradesh government has transferred two senior officers including Inspector General of Police (IG).

Bhopal IG, Yogesh Choudhary, has been moved to the police headquarters.

Railway police official, Anita Malviya, who had faced strong criticism for allegedly being insensitive during the handling of the case, has also been transferred.

When asked by media persons, she was seen laughing and reportedly said that she had a "headache talking about case again and again". After the video of conversation went viral, there was anger among citizens, which was reflected on social media as well.

Malviya, a state police service (SPS) officer, was posted as superintendent of Railway Police. The GRP police station was directly under her supervision. The GRP too had refused to register an FIR initially.

This is the first action that has been taken against senior officials. Till now mostly the lower rank officials including three SHOs apart and a middle-level official had faced action.

Though he has been removed from the post of IG Bhopal, Choudhary has been given the charge of IG (Law-and-Order). Choudhary is being replaced by Jaideep Prasad.
TITLE: Bhopal Inspector General And SP Of Railway Police Transferred For Mishandling 19-Year-Old's Gangrape Case

SUMMARY:
"The challenge in learning a second language is the fact that you have a first language," Kidd said.
"Part of that is you are coming to your second language with knowledge of your first language."
"I guess what the one distinction between a first language and second language is that first language acquisition is really implicit and a second language can be more explicit."
The explicit nature of learning a second language means that we are very aware of how much energy and dedication it takes to be able to speak any language well.
"Let's face it, there is nothing more humbling than learning a second language and using it because you just revert to [being] a two-year-old."
TEXT:
Learning a second language is no easy task.

A lot of time and dedication is required, plus there is a significant amount of memorising of words and phrases. And even once you've learnt those, it takes both skill and confidence to use them in a real-life setting.

Well, Associate Professor Evan Kidd from the ARC Centre of Excellence for the Dynamics of Language says that anyone can learn a new language as long as they put enough time into the process.

"I think that almost anyone, if they give it a good enough shot, is going to have some abilities in a language with enough exposure and time," Kidd told HuffPost Australia.

According to Kidd, one of the biggest challenges adults face when learning a new language is approaching it with the knowledge of their mother tongue. Our brains are finely tuned to our first language and so we approach any new linguistic situation within the framework of that first language.

"The challenge in learning a second language is the fact that you have a first language," Kidd said. "Part of that is you are coming to your second language with knowledge of your first language."

So, what are some ways that we can make the language-learning process easier?

Three ways to make learning a new language easier Use stock phrases Learning a few generic and adaptable phrases in a new language can make it easier to use and also give you a template to build other terms using that same formula. "It's good to have a few stock phrases because then you can start strapping off from those so you can say -- 'OK I have got this phrase and I can put different verbs in it and different nouns in it', which is actually how young kids tend to learn," Kidd said. Memorise When you first start out, learning the basic grammar and vocabulary of any language is going to require time to create a solid linguistic foundation. This means a lot of dedication to learning the words and making an effort to remember those through practice. "Inevitably, there are going to be instances where you are just going to need to memorise the rule because, let's face it, languages are weird entities." Actually speak the language Kidd said that in his experience, one of the most important things when learning a new language is making the effort to use it as much as possible. "It's all fine and good to sit there and learn it and then do in a class, but you really have to talk and I think by virtue of talking that's when you really start to get much more sense that this is a communicative system and you really want to use that to communicate." "[It's a] combination between memorisation and a little bit of 'extraversion' and having a go."

Children are exposed to languages at a very young age, even from the time they are in the womb. The process of acquiring language begins with sounds and language rhythms and eventually builds up to words and sentences.

"One of the cool things about infants when they are born is they have the ability to perceive the difference between any sound that the human vocal tract can make, and the thing is that any one language will only use a subset of those sounds," Kidd said.

An interesting example of how this works can be found when the English and Japanese languages are compared.

"In English we have a distinction between the 'R' sound and the 'L' sound but in Japanese they don't have that distinction -- they've got one which is between these two sounds," Kidd explained.

"So, what happens when a Japanese infant is born is that they can distinguish between the 'R' and 'L' sounds but once they get to about 12 months they can't do it anymore and that is because their language doesn't have it."

Children under 12 months can identify every sound a human voice tract can make.

As humans lose this ability around the age of 12 months, we become unable to accurately distinguish some sounds that our mother tongue doesn't use. It's in this way that learning a first and a second language is fundamentally different.

Most of us can't remember learning our first language because it was effortless and occurred over a long period of time, but acquiring that second one requires a lot of hard work.

"I guess what the one distinction between a first language and second language is that first language acquisition is really implicit and a second language can be more explicit."

The explicit nature of learning a second language means that we are very aware of how much energy and dedication it takes to be able to speak any language well. Kidd says that being as confident as possible with another language could be the gateway to your success.

"Let's face it, there is nothing more humbling than learning a second language and using it because you just revert to [being] a two-year-old."
TITLE: Three Tips To Make Learning A Second Language Easier

SUMMARY:
Anna Soubry, another Tory backbencher, has already called for Green to step aside .
Damian Green should stand aside form his job as first secretary of state while an investigation into his conduct is carried out, a Tory MP has said.
Rudd sidestepped questions about whether Green should not have to stand aside while the inquiry was underway.
Tory MP Dan Poulter also under investigation by the party‚Äôs new disciplinary panel, following allegations he behaved inappropriately towards women in Westminster.
Former Tory cabinet minister Stephen Crabb has admitted writing some ‚Äúpretty outrageous things‚Äù in text messages to a young woman who applied for a job in his office.
TEXT:
Anna Soubry, another Tory backbencher, has already called for Green to step aside .

In a strongly worded statement, the de facto deputy prime minister said the allegation was ‚Äúcompletely untrue‚Äù and ‚Äúpolitical smears‚Äù.

Green has strongly denied the claims, made by ex-Metropolitan Police assistant commissioner Bob Quick, that pornography was found his office in Westminster during a raid in 2008.

Her intervention came as Home Secretary Amber Rudd revealed the inquiry into her cabinet colleague would be widened to include allegations pornographic material was found on one of his parliamentary computers

Heidi Allen told ITV‚Äôs Peston on Sunday it would be ‚Äúcompletely normal‚Äù in any other industry for someone to be suspended. ‚ÄúIf you are innocent you have nothing to worry about,‚Äù she said.

Damian Green should stand aside form his job as first secretary of state while an investigation into his conduct is carried out, a Tory MP has said.

. @heidiallen75 says it'd be sensible for @DamianGreen to stand down from Cabinet role whilst there is an inquiry into his actions #Peston pic.twitter.com/5K1I9Rq7Yr

Green, who sits at the heart of Theresa May‚Äôs government, is already under investigation by the Cabinet Secretary after he was accused of making unwanted sexual advances towards a young female Tory activist. He denies the accusation.

Rudd the BBC‚Äôs Andrew Marr show this would now be expanded to include the allegations about his computers.

‚ÄúI know that the Cabinet Office is going to be looking at this tomorrow along with the wider inquiry about Damian and I do think that we shouldn‚Äôt rush to allege anything until that inquiry has taken place,‚Äù she said.

Rudd sidestepped questions about whether Green should not have to stand aside while the inquiry was underway.

‚ÄúHe strongly denies the allegations. Let‚Äôs give him time and the inquiry time to put it straight,‚Äù she told Sky News. ‚ÄúI really look forward to him clearing his name.‚Äù

The Sunday Times reported Quick‚Äôs claim police officers found ‚Äúextreme porn‚Äù on computers in Green‚Äôs office.

But Green said the former police chief was a ‚Äútainted and untrustworthy source‚Äù.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been aware for some years that the discredited former assistant commissioner Bob Quick has tried to cause me political damage by leaking false information about the raid on my parliamentary office,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúNo newspaper has printed this story due to the complete lack of any evidence.

‚ÄúIt is well-known that Quick, who was forced to apologise for alleging that the Conservative Party was trying to undermine him, harbours deep resentment about his press treatment during the time of my investigation.

‚ÄúMore importantly, the police have never suggested to me that improper material was found on my parliamentary computer, nor did I have a ‚Äòprivate‚Äô computer, as has been claimed.

‚ÄúThe allegations about the material and computer, now nine years old, are false, disreputable political smears from a discredited police officer acting in flagrant breach of his duty to keep the details of police investigations confidential, and amount to little more than an unscrupulous character assassination.‚Äù

Both the Conservatives and Labour have been rocked by a series of sexual harassment claims over the last week.

Several MPs have been suspended by their parties and Sir Michael Fallon resigned as defence secretary over allegations he behaved inappropriately towards women.

Rudd described as ‚Äúdisgusting‚Äù an incident in which Sir Michael Fallon is alleged to have lunged at a journalist and tried to kiss her on the lips.

The comments came after Jane Merrick alleged in The Observer that the incident took place after a 2003 lunch when she was a 29-year-old junior political reporter.

On Sunday morning, Daniel Kawczynski became the third Tory MP to be referred to the party‚Äôs disciplinary committee over allegations he pressured a young woman who worked in parliament into meet a wealthy businessman. Kawczynski denies anything inappropriate took place.

Tory MP Dan Poulter also under investigation by the party‚Äôs new disciplinary panel, following allegations he behaved inappropriately towards women in Westminster. He denies the allegations.

Former Tory cabinet minister Stephen Crabb has admitted writing some ‚Äúpretty outrageous things‚Äù in text messages to a young woman who applied for a job in his office.
TITLE: Damian Green Must Step Aside While Sexual Harassment Claims Are Investigated, Says Tory MP

Anna Soubry, another Tory backbencher, has already called for Green to step aside .
Damian Green should stand aside form his job as first secretary of state while an investigation into his conduct is carried out, a Tory MP has said.
Rudd sidestepped questions about whether Green should not have to stand aside while the inquiry was underway.
Tory MP Dan Poulter also under investigation by the party‚Äôs new disciplinary panel, following allegations he behaved inappropriately towards women in Westminster.
Former Tory cabinet minister Stephen Crabb has admitted writing some ‚Äúpretty outrageous things‚Äù in text messages to a young woman who applied for a job in his office.
TEXT:
Anna Soubry, another Tory backbencher, has already called for Green to step aside .

In a strongly worded statement, the de facto deputy prime minister said the allegation was ‚Äúcompletely untrue‚Äù and ‚Äúpolitical smears‚Äù.

Green has strongly denied the claims, made by ex-Metropolitan Police assistant commissioner Bob Quick, that pornography was found his office in Westminster during a raid in 2008.

Her intervention came as Home Secretary Amber Rudd revealed the inquiry into her cabinet colleague would be widened to include allegations pornographic material was found on one of his parliamentary computers

Heidi Allen told ITV‚Äôs Peston on Sunday it would be ‚Äúcompletely normal‚Äù in any other industry for someone to be suspended. ‚ÄúIf you are innocent you have nothing to worry about,‚Äù she said.

Damian Green should stand aside form his job as first secretary of state while an investigation into his conduct is carried out, a Tory MP has said.

. @heidiallen75 says it'd be sensible for @DamianGreen to stand down from Cabinet role whilst there is an inquiry into his actions #Peston pic.twitter.com/5K1I9Rq7Yr

Green, who sits at the heart of Theresa May‚Äôs government, is already under investigation by the Cabinet Secretary after he was accused of making unwanted sexual advances towards a young female Tory activist. He denies the accusation.

Rudd the BBC‚Äôs Andrew Marr show this would now be expanded to include the allegations about his computers.

‚ÄúI know that the Cabinet Office is going to be looking at this tomorrow along with the wider inquiry about Damian and I do think that we shouldn‚Äôt rush to allege anything until that inquiry has taken place,‚Äù she said.

Rudd sidestepped questions about whether Green should not have to stand aside while the inquiry was underway.

‚ÄúHe strongly denies the allegations. Let‚Äôs give him time and the inquiry time to put it straight,‚Äù she told Sky News. ‚ÄúI really look forward to him clearing his name.‚Äù

The Sunday Times reported Quick‚Äôs claim police officers found ‚Äúextreme porn‚Äù on computers in Green‚Äôs office.

But Green said the former police chief was a ‚Äútainted and untrustworthy source‚Äù.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been aware for some years that the discredited former assistant commissioner Bob Quick has tried to cause me political damage by leaking false information about the raid on my parliamentary office,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúNo newspaper has printed this story due to the complete lack of any evidence.

‚ÄúIt is well-known that Quick, who was forced to apologise for alleging that the Conservative Party was trying to undermine him, harbours deep resentment about his press treatment during the time of my investigation.

‚ÄúMore importantly, the police have never suggested to me that improper material was found on my parliamentary computer, nor did I have a ‚Äòprivate‚Äô computer, as has been claimed.

‚ÄúThe allegations about the material and computer, now nine years old, are false, disreputable political smears from a discredited police officer acting in flagrant breach of his duty to keep the details of police investigations confidential, and amount to little more than an unscrupulous character assassination.‚Äù

Both the Conservatives and Labour have been rocked by a series of sexual harassment claims over the last week.

Several MPs have been suspended by their parties and Sir Michael Fallon resigned as defence secretary over allegations he behaved inappropriately towards women.

Rudd described as ‚Äúdisgusting‚Äù an incident in which Sir Michael Fallon is alleged to have lunged at a journalist and tried to kiss her on the lips.

The comments came after Jane Merrick alleged in The Observer that the incident took place after a 2003 lunch when she was a 29-year-old junior political reporter.

On Sunday morning, Daniel Kawczynski became the third Tory MP to be referred to the party‚Äôs disciplinary committee over allegations he pressured a young woman who worked in parliament into meet a wealthy businessman. Kawczynski denies anything inappropriate took place.

Tory MP Dan Poulter also under investigation by the party‚Äôs new disciplinary panel, following allegations he behaved inappropriately towards women in Westminster. He denies the allegations.

Former Tory cabinet minister Stephen Crabb has admitted writing some ‚Äúpretty outrageous things‚Äù in text messages to a young woman who applied for a job in his office.
TITLE: Damian Green Must Step Aside While Sexual Harassment Claims Are Investigated, Says Tory MP

SUMMARY:
Finally, she thought, she'll stop wasting her money, start saving for a house, have kids and live happily ever after.
Unfortunately for my mum, marriage and kids did nothing to quench our thirst for exploring, and despite setting up shop with the kids, the travelling never stopped.
A honeymoon with kids?
Romantic bars (kids were always warmly welcomed), fabulous restaurants and crystal-clear waters, topped with that infectious and fun Greek spirit.
There are fantastic camping spots -- the perfect activity to enjoy a glass of wine under the stars as the kids sleep.
TEXT:
"The excitement of going somewhere new will help rekindle the romance in your relationship, and provide family memories that will last a lifetime."

Figuratively and literally, the honeymoon is not over for us. The truth is, we never planned to catch that plane home to a mundane life and an uninspiring relationship.

Numerous articles have been written about the key to keeping the pizzazz in relationships, and even more articles have dissected the apparently unavoidable tragedy that occurs when the honeymoon period of a relationship comes to an abrupt end.

But what if the honeymoon period never ends?

After a solid decade of exploring all corners of the globe together, my partner and I decided to embark on a new adventure: marriage and children. I could almost hear my mum's sigh of relief when we announced it... Finally, she thought, she'll stop wasting her money, start saving for a house, have kids and live happily ever after.

Unfortunately for my mum, marriage and kids did nothing to quench our thirst for exploring, and despite setting up shop with the kids, the travelling never stopped. In fact, we went into overdrive. In an almost defiant, rebellious quest, we continued to travel the world with two young kids in tow -- mastering the art of travelling with a glass of bubbles in one hand and a bottle of milk in the other (responsibly, of course).

We were determined to prove wrong all the people who insisted that life, romance and fabulous holidays would end as soon as marriage and kids entered the equation. And so, we kept travelling... mostly with the kids and, on one rare occasion, without them.

Nothing deterred us, not even that nightmare 22-hour flight to Europe when my two year old refused to sleep. Our combined obsession with travel motivated us to book that next holiday. And with each adventure, whether it was the camping trip just out of town or the tropical getaway on a luxurious island, we realised we had inadvertently managed to stay in the honeymoon phase simply by continuing to go on 'honeymoons' -- with the kids.

A honeymoon with kids?

Okay, so it's not your typical honeymoon. The traditional honeymoon is synonymous with the ultimate celebration of love. Usually taken immediately after the wedding, it's that once-in-a-lifetime romantic holiday where you deliriously succumb to life's little luxuries and the term 'love drunk' takes on a whole new meaning.

However, if you look beyond the indulgent hotel rooms and the token petals scattered over beds, you'll realise the essence of a honeymoon can easily be applied to any holiday. It's about exploring together, discovering together, going to new places together, sharing new experiences together and (this is the real ground-breaking one)... it's about spending time together.

Honeymoons and holidays embody the all-important 'together' things that people tend to forget when kids come along or when they've been in a relationship for years. They are shoved right under a one-metre pile of bills, never to be seen again. That's when the ever-so-feared domestication truly starts to set in and you can guarantee the honeymoon phase will well and truly be over shortly afterwards.

So as Nike always recommends, just do it. Keep the adventures going, keep 'honeymooning' and don't be afraid to take the kids with you. There may be fleeting moments of despair but the good times will far outweigh the bad. The excitement of going somewhere new will help rekindle the romance in your relationship, and provide family memories that will last a lifetime.

Here are our top five places to honeymoon with the kids:

1. Mykonos -- Synonymous with hedonistic parties, it's not the first Greek Island that springs to mind when you think of romance and family holidays, but this charming island has everything for everyone. Romantic bars (kids were always warmly welcomed), fabulous restaurants and crystal-clear waters, topped with that infectious and fun Greek spirit.

2. Vomo, Fiji -- This luxurious Fijian resort, only a short boat or helicopter ride from Fiji's mainland, has all the elements of a blissful tropical getaway -- picture-perfect beaches framed with palm trees, amazing food and hospitality, and a fantastic kids club with island activities to keep the little ones learning and engaged.

3. Bali -- From the stunning properties of Alila Villas on the cliffs of Uluwatu, to the many affordable hotels and villas along Seminyak and Kuta, Bali offers something for all budgets. The sunsets are some of the most famed in the world and provide the perfect setting for sunset cocktails.

4. Port Douglas -- This charming town in Tropical North Queensland is uniquely positioned where the 'rainforest meets the sea'. The spectacular natural scenery, coupled with world-class eateries means there is always plenty to see and do. Explore the Daintree Rainforest, take a boat ride out and snorkel the Great Barrier Reef or simply relax by the pool at one of the many waterfront resorts.

5. Seal Rocks -- Lush surrounds including endless beaches and bushwalks makes this area the ideal place to unwind and get some quality time together. There are fantastic camping spots -- the perfect activity to enjoy a glass of wine under the stars as the kids sleep.

Happy honeymooning, with the kids.

_______________________________

For more travel inspiration, follow Meri Hindes' Instagram account @huntersandtravellers
TITLE: The Way To Make Your Honeymoon Last Forever Is To Invite Your Kids

TEXT:
Si est√°s habituada a pasar noches en vela, no est√°s sola. En general, las mujeres tienden a sufrir m√°s que los hombres de insomnio o problemas para dormir, de acuerdo con un estudio internacional realizado por Calm.

El resultado encontr√≥ que las mujeres son 40% m√°s proclives a "siempre" dormir mal. La situaci√≥n empeora cuando se trata de mujeres entre los 45 y 55 a√±os (55%).

Existen muchas posibles razones por las que las mujeres tienden a dormir peor que los hombres, dijo el doctor Steve Orma, autor del libro Stop Worrying and Go To Sleep.

"Una de ellas son las hormonas ‚Äìcomo estr√≥geno y progesterona‚Äì, que var√≠an m√°s en las mujeres. Esas variaciones pueden causar incomodidad f√≠sica, que puede alterar el sue√±o", agreg√≥ al especialista, de acuerdo con un comunicado de Calm.

6 razones por las que las mujeres duermen mal

Aunque las hormonas podr√≠an ser la principal causa de los problemas de sue√±o, existen otros factores que van de lo f√≠sico a lo emocional:

Mayores fluctuaciones en las hormonas como el estr√≥geno y la progesterona, que causan malestar.

La ansiedad y la depresi√≥n son dos veces m√°s comunes en las mujeres que en los hombres.

El embarazo y la incomodidad asociada.

El s√≠ndrome de piernas inquietas: las mujeres lo padecen m√°s.

La menopausia trae m√°s fluctuaciones hormonales, sofocos.

Consejos para dormir mejor

Lo principal es identificar las causas de los problemas para dormir.

De acuerdo con Orma, consultar a un especialista es clave para determinar si la causa es psicol√≥gica o biol√≥gica u hormonal. Un m√©dico podr√≠a solicitar una serie de estudios para descartar causas f√≠sicas.

En caso de que las razones sean psicol√≥gicas, buscar a un psicoterapia, de preferencia cognitivo‚Äìconductual.

Finalmente, estar consciente de que para dormir mejor se necesitan buenos h√°bito e incluso una alimentaci√≥n sana.
TITLE: Estas son las razones por las que las mujeres tenemos m√°s problemas para dormir

TEXT:
Operazioni di voto per le elezioni regionali in Sicilia in un seggio di Caltanissetta, 5 novembre 2017. ANSA / CIRO FUSCO

Urne aperte dalle 8 alle 22 in Sicilia per le elezioni regionali. Sono circa quattro milioni e mezzo i votanti chiamati alle urne. Cinque i candidati alla presidenza: Giancarlo Cancelleri del M5S, Claudio Fava della sinistra, Roberto La Rosa dei Siciliani liberi, Fabrizio Micari del centrosinistra e Nello Musumeci del centrodestra. Settanta i parlamentari da eleggere all'Assemblea regionale. In base ai primi dati, affluenza in calo: a mezzogiorno ha votato il 10,8% degli elettori (503.537 su 4.661.111) con un lieve calo dello 0,43% rispetto alle regionali del 2012 quando aveva votato l'11,23%. L'unica provincia dove l'affluenza √® maggiore √® quella di Ragusa: ha votato l'11,24% rispetto al 10,82% del 2012.

Lo scrutinio inizier√† domattina alle 8, come da previsione normativa di una legge regionale. Anche nel 2012 si √® votato con lo stesso sistema, ma a partire dal Sinistra Italiana, fino a Rosario Crocetta - che avrebbe avuto tutto il tempo di cambiare questa legge - protestano per questa diversit√† di azione rispetto al resto d'Italia, dove lo spoglio comincia subito. Rischio brogli, si dice, e il ministro dell'Interno Marco Minniti ha inviato una nota ai prefetti perch√© la vigilanza sul voto sia accurata.

Al voto, insieme ai 4,5 milioni di siciliani, anche il presidente della Repubblica, Sergio Mattarella. Il timore √® quello di un astensionismo molto diffuso. Ieri il candidato M5S Giancarlo Cancelleri ha fatto appello ai personaggi pi√π noti dell'isola - da Ficarra e Picone a Fiorello - perch√© si uniscano nell'appello per andare al voto. Sulle pagine del Corriere della Sera, per√≤, Rosario Fiorello esprime tutta la sua disillusione per quello che sar√† il futuro della Sicilia: "La politica non ha mai cambiato le cose in Sicilia. E non lo far√† neanche questa volta" dice lo showman, "mi fanno ridere tutto questi che promettono acqua frizzante dai rubinetti e treni superveloci fra Catania e Palermo ... Per quanto mi riguarda, non credo a nessuno".
TITLE: Sicilia al voto, bassa affluenza. Fiorello non si illude: "Qui la politica non ha mai cambiato le cose e neanche stavolta lo far√†"

Mais le match ne se jouera peut-√™tre pas uniquement sur le terrain.
Car le club lyonnais, qui esp√®re empocher un derby qui lui √©chappe dans le Chaudron depuis novembre 2013, s'est fait remarquer par sa strat√©gie sur les r√©seaux sociaux.
Les tweets retranscrivent l'actualit√© du club (les entra√Ænements, les r√©sultats, les sponsors etc), sans √©clat majeur d'ironie.
Une rencontre √¢pre, disput√©e sur le terrain (score final de 3-3) et... sur Twitter.
Une relation quelque peu d√©licate, sur Twitter, entre certains sympathisants lyonnais et le club rhodanien comme l'expliquait Charly dans son article.
TEXT:
R√âSEAUX SOCIAUX - Ce dimanche 5 novembre, Saint-Etienne re√ßoit l'OL pour un derby tr√®s attendu. Mais le match ne se jouera peut-√™tre pas uniquement sur le terrain.

Car le club lyonnais, qui esp√®re empocher un derby qui lui √©chappe dans le Chaudron depuis novembre 2013, s'est fait remarquer par sa strat√©gie sur les r√©seaux sociaux.

Chaque club dispose de sa propre politique en la mati√®re. Certains jouent la carte d√©cal√©e, en misant sur un registre humoristique et divertissant, √† l'instar de Guingamp, Nantes, Bordeaux, Toulouse, pour ne citer qu'eux.

A contrario, la politique de l'OL s'av√®re bien diff√©rente. La tonalit√© se veut plus s√©rieuse. Les tweets retranscrivent l'actualit√© du club (les entra√Ænements, les r√©sultats, les sponsors etc), sans √©clat majeur d'ironie. Le contraste est donc saisissant avec les autres entit√©s cit√©es plus haut, d'autant que l'OL n'h√©site pas √† critiquer parfois ouvertement l'arbitrage ou √† chambrer ses adversaires.

Et c'est sans parler du pr√©sident du club qui a un style bien √† lui sur Twitter. Le pr√©sident Jean-Michel Aulas est sans doute le dirigeant sportif le plus connect√© de France. Ses punchlines distill√©es √† tout-va sur son compte Twitter, fort de quelque 431.000 abonn√©s, lui permettent facilement d'occuper l'espace m√©diatique.

J lis Larqu√© s faire + gros k la grenouille d LaFontaine en prenant ss d√©sirs pr d r√©alit√©s j lui conseille d se consacrer o mus√©e d l'asse ‚Äî Jean-Michel AULAS (@JM_Aulas) 2 mars 2015

@Adrien_Ve quand on veut √™tre exemplaire il faut prendre un peu de temps pour vulgariser la gestion et le management du foot √† des abrutis ‚Äî Jean-Michel AULAS (@JM_Aulas) 17 f√©vrier 2013

Ses messages massivement relay√©s peuvent √™tre adress√©s √† des anonymes ou √† certains supporters de l'OL. Parfois d√©cri√© ou alors simplement interrog√©, le pr√©sident lyonnais n'h√©site pas √† r√©pondre √† ses d√©tracteurs pour d√©fendre son club. D'autres messages sont l'occasion pour lui de clamer son amour pour son club de coeur ou de mettre en lumi√®re la progression de son entreprise sportive.

avec tes 9 abonn√©s tu te prends pour qui ? ‚Äî Jean-Michel AULAS (@JM_Aulas) 30 octobre 2016

et toi un QI qui frise le plancher üòÇüòÇ ‚Äî Jean-Michel AULAS (@JM_Aulas) 30 octobre 2016

Dans un article publi√© en septembre sur Yahoo Sports, Charly, fan de l'OL et r√©dacteur au liberolyon, relevait dans le d√©tail les axes de cette politique jug√©e "limite et √† l'envers". Il est vrai que le compte Twitter de l'institution s'est d√©j√† illustr√© par "une certaine mauvaise foi", par exemple lors du match PSG-OL le 17 septembre.

Deux fautes semblables, un m√™me arbitre, deux poids deux mesures... #PSGOL pic.twitter.com/Y0Pw8k0qBC ‚Äî Olympique Lyonnais (@OL) 20 septembre 2017

Autre aper√ßu. Lors de la 3√®me journ√©e de Ligue 1 disput√©e en ao√ªt dernier, l'OL recevait les Girondins de Bordeaux. Une rencontre √¢pre, disput√©e sur le terrain (score final de 3-3) et... sur Twitter. En t√©moigne le clash assez insolite entre les CM des deux institutions footballistiques.

On va pas parler mauvaise foi avec les leaders dans le domaine ‚Äî FCGirondins Bordeaux (@girondins) 19 ao√ªt 2017

Tellement classe... ‚Äî FCGirondins Bordeaux (@girondins) 19 ao√ªt 2017

"Le community manager est d√©sormais devenu la personne la plus importante au sein de l'organigramme administratif d'un club de football! C'est lui qui est en contact direct et permanent avec les fans. C'est lui qui peut mesurer le degr√© de satisfaction ou de m√©contentement des supporters. Les fans recherchent une conversation tout en √©tant int√©gr√©s √† une communaut√©", expliquait √† ecofoot Boris Helleu, ma√Ætre de Conf√©rences √† l'universit√© de Caen.

Une relation quelque peu d√©licate, sur Twitter, entre certains sympathisants lyonnais et le club rhodanien comme l'expliquait Charly dans son article. Contact√© par Le HuffPost, il explique son sentiment: "Le r√¥le d'un CM d'une marque tr√®s suivie comme l'OL, c'est d'animer, de choyer sa communaut√©. √Ä Lyon, il manque ce lien entre les deux parties mais je n'incrimine pas sp√©cifiquement le CM de l'OL. J'imagine qu'il ob√©it aux ordres qu'on lui donne. Parfois, le club en vient m√™me √† critiquer certains de ses supporters". En mars dernier, le club publiait un tweet m√©prisant, assimilant certaines discussions de fans "au caf√© du commerce".

When we see the "Caf√© du commerce"... üòÅüòÇüòù pic.twitter.com/6Tv3PecbFb ‚Äî Olympique Lyonnais (@OL) 14 mars 2017

"Quand tu vois le "Caf√© du commerce"

Vers une nouvelle politique num√©rique?

Joint par Le HuffPost, l'OL n'a pas accept√© de r√©pondre √† nos questions au motif que le club est en pleine reconfiguration de sa strat√©gie digitale. Pour Charly le supporter, il faudrait que le club "s'approprie davantage ses fans, qu'il leur fasse moins honte, qu'il arr√™te les trolls (les messages provocateurs, ndlr) malvenus. En somme, si la communication √©tait √† la hauteur du club, avec plus de classe et de propret√©, ce serait d√©j√† une tr√®s bonne avanc√©e."

Depuis plusieurs semaines, la communication du club sur Twitter s'est toutefois largement assagie. Les sorties "maladroites" et autres d√©rapages sont bien plus rares, comme le confirme Charly: "Les r√©sultats sont plut√¥t bons ces derniers temps (l'OL reste sur une bonne s√©rie de 5 victoires cons√©cutives toutes comp√©titions confondues, il occupe la 3e place du classement, ndlr). C'est vrai que √ßa s'est pas mal calm√© sur Twitter. Peut-√™tre que le club a compris la n√©cessit√© d'avoir une autre forme de communication et donc d'√©voluer sur ce point."

SUMMARY:
Dans l'Iliade, le roi grec Agamemnon, qui s'appr√™te √† diriger sa flotte vers Troie, tue accidentellement un cerf dans le bosquet d'Art√©mis.
Plus question d'autoritarisme comme dans "Canine", de syst√®mes √©conomiques morbides fa√ßon "Alps" ou encore de relations amoureuses forc√©es √† la "The Lobster".
Le√ßon d'humanit√© dans un monde d√©sax√©"Mise √† mort du cerf sacr√©", comme les autres films de L√°nthimos, ne conviendra pas √† tout le monde.
Pourtant, il s'agit sans doute de son long-m√©trage le plus humain, tant il donne une profondeur √©motionnelle √† ses personnages pouss√©s √† bout.
Par un retour √† la simplicit√© symbolique, narrative et de mise en sc√®ne, le dernier film de Y√≥rgos L√°nthimos questionne, avec humour, sur ce qui a encore du sens √† notre √©poque.
TEXT:
Steven Murphy est chirurgien cardiaque au prestigieux Christ Hospital de Cincinnati. Il m√®ne une vie agr√©able avec sa femme ophtalmologue et leurs deux enfants dans une immense maison de banlieue. Le parfait portrait de famille voit appara√Ætre ses premi√®res craquelures lorsque Martin, un adolescent troubl√© que Steven a pris sous son aile depuis le d√©c√®s de son p√®re, le force √† faire un choix corn√©lien. Martin lui explique que, son p√®re √©tant mort sur la table d'op√©ration de Steven, il doit d√©sormais tuer un membre de sa propre famille pour √©quilibrer la situation. S'il refuse, tous mourront les uns apr√®s les autres dans d'atroces circonstances.

Fid√®le √† son style √©pur√© et ses personnages gla√ßants, Y√≥rgos L√°nthimos signe un nouveau long-m√©trage noir, absurde et d√©cal√© qui lui a valu le prix du sc√©nario au Festival de Cannes 2017. Si son pr√©c√©dent film, "The Lobster", prenait la forme d'un drame comique et dystopique, "Mise √† mort du cerf sacr√©" se veut beaucoup plus r√©aliste et simpliste. Dans les couloirs de l'h√¥pital de Steven ou le long des boiseries de sa maison, les spectateurs suivent le regard d'une cam√©ra oppressante en flottaison au-dessus des personnages, telle une force surnaturelle, divine.

Proph√©tie moderne

Cette entit√© sup√©rieure observant les actions de Steven (Colin Farrell) dans sa qu√™te pour sauver sa famille est expliqu√©e dans le titre du film, qui renvoie directement au mythe d'Iphig√©nie. Dans l'Iliade, le roi grec Agamemnon, qui s'appr√™te √† diriger sa flotte vers Troie, tue accidentellement un cerf dans le bosquet d'Art√©mis. En guise de punition, la d√©esse emp√™che les bateaux d'accoster √† Troie en lib√©rant ses vents, qu'elle n'accepte de calmer qu'en l'√©change du sacrifice d'Iphig√©nie, la fille d'Agamemnon. Celui-ci refuse, avant d'√™tre pouss√© √† s'y soumettre par ses soldats.

En donnant un nouveau twist √† un texte aussi fondateur, L√°nthimos abandonne partiellement la complexit√© de ses films pr√©c√©dents pour offrir un divertissement plus explicite dans sa critique sociale. Plus question d'autoritarisme comme dans "Canine", de syst√®mes √©conomiques morbides fa√ßon "Alps" ou encore de relations amoureuses forc√©es √† la "The Lobster". Cette fois, le r√©alisateur grec s'int√©resse aux liens t√©nus et primitifs entre mort, d√©sir et vengeance, √† une √©poque o√π les dieux ont √©t√© oubli√©s et ne sont plus les sources impr√©visibles du malheur des hommes.

Le√ßon d'humanit√© dans un monde d√©sax√©

"Mise √† mort du cerf sacr√©", comme les autres films de L√°nthimos, ne conviendra pas √† tout le monde. Son style extr√™mement froid, ses personnages m√©prisables par leur √©go√Øsme et leurs dialogues robotiques peuvent en repousser plus d'un. Pourtant, il s'agit sans doute de son long-m√©trage le plus humain, tant il donne une profondeur √©motionnelle √† ses personnages pouss√©s √† bout. √Ä la fois satirique, horrifique et hilarant, le film d√©range autant qu'il amuse. Il tient en haleine ses spectateurs avec l'in√©vitable d√©cision de Steven tout en les interrogeant sur le sens des trag√©dies modernes du quotidien.

Alors que les m√©dias diffusent en permanence des informations tragiques √† v√©rit√© variable, "Mise √† mort du cerf sacr√©" appara√Æt comme un √©cho √† "l'hypernormalisation" ch√®re √† Adam Curtis; la th√©orie selon laquelle le monde est conscient de son propre chaos et de sa faillite, mais que, faute d'alternative, personne ne s'y oppose.

Par un retour √† la simplicit√© symbolique, narrative et de mise en sc√®ne, le dernier film de Y√≥rgos L√°nthimos questionne, avec humour, sur ce qui a encore du sens √† notre √©poque. Qu'est-ce qui touche encore l'humain au plus profond de lui-m√™me lorsque le chaos ambiant lui est devenu habituel?

TITLE: Qu'est-ce qui a encore du sens pour nous? La question que pose le film "Mise √† mort du cerf sacr√©"

TEXT:
Die Kritik an Horst Seehofer nach dem Wahldesaster der CSU wird immer lauter - auch in den eigenen Reihen

Der CSU-Chef hat sich jetzt erbost √ºber die Attacken gegen ihn gezeigt

Sie seien sch√§dlich f√ºr die Sondierungsgespr√§che f√ºr eine Jamaika-Koalition

Nach wo¬≠chen¬≠lan¬≠ger Kri¬≠tik und R√ºck¬≠tritts¬≠for¬≠de¬≠run¬≠gen aus der ei¬≠ge¬≠nen Par¬≠tei greift der baye¬≠ri¬≠sche Mi¬≠nis¬≠ter¬≠pr√§¬≠si¬≠dent und CSU-Chef Horst See¬≠ho¬≠fer seine Kri¬≠ti¬≠ker an.

"Ich nehme die Dis¬≠kus¬≠sio¬≠nen in Bay¬≠ern um meine Per¬≠son hin¬≠ter und vor den Ku¬≠lis¬≠sen mit Er¬≠stau¬≠nen zur Kennt¬≠nis", sagte See¬≠ho¬≠fer der "Bild"-Zeitung. "Ob¬≠wohl im Par¬≠tei¬≠vor¬≠stand ein¬≠stim¬≠mig be¬≠schlos¬≠sen wurde, dass eine Per¬≠so¬≠nal¬≠dis¬≠kus¬≠si¬≠on w√§h¬≠rend der Ge¬≠spr√§¬≠che in Ber¬≠lin nicht er¬≠fol¬≠gen soll, er¬≠le¬≠be ich seit der Bun¬≠des¬≠tags¬≠wahl ein un¬≠un¬≠ter¬≠bro¬≠che¬≠nes Trom¬≠mel¬≠feu¬≠er gegen meine Per¬≠son aus der ei¬≠ge¬≠nen Par¬≠tei. Das ist ohne Frage sch√§d¬≠lich."

Laut See¬≠ho¬≠fer pral¬≠le die Dau¬≠er¬≠kri¬≠tik an ihm ab: "Ich lasse mich da¬≠durch aber in kei¬≠ner Weise be¬≠ein¬≠flus¬≠sen. Jetzt geht es erst ein¬≠mal um die Durch¬≠set¬≠zung un¬≠se¬≠rer Po¬≠si¬≠tio¬≠nen in Ber¬≠lin. Nach den Son¬≠die¬≠rungs¬≠ge¬≠spr√§¬≠chen wird es von mir eine klare und deut¬≠li¬≠che Re¬≠ak¬≠ti¬≠on geben."

Jamaika-Verhandlungen f√ºr Seehofer "Schwerstarbeit"

See¬≠ho¬≠fer will zu¬≠n√§chst bei den Ja¬≠mai¬≠ka-Ge¬≠spr√§¬≠chen in Ber¬≠lin f√ºr Klar¬≠heit und eine sta¬≠bi¬≠le Re¬≠gie¬≠rung mit CSU-Be¬≠tei¬≠li¬≠gung sor¬≠gen.

Er k√§mp¬≠fe "wie ein L√∂we in Ber¬≠lin", so der Par¬≠tei¬≠chef. "Die Ver¬≠hand¬≠lun¬≠gen sind po¬≠li¬≠ti¬≠sche Schwerst¬≠ar¬≠beit. Wir m√ºs¬≠sen jetzt das Tempo er¬≠h√∂¬≠hen. Die Men¬≠schen in Deutsch¬≠land er¬≠war¬≠ten zu¬≠recht end¬≠lich Re¬≠sul¬≠ta¬≠te aus den Ver¬≠hand¬≠lun¬≠gen und die Bil¬≠dung einer sta¬≠bi¬≠len Re¬≠gie¬≠rung."

Aufbegehren der Jungen

Die bayerische Junge Union (JU) hatte sich offen gegen den Parteichef gestellt und forderte den R√ºckzug Seehofers im kommenden Jahr.

Ein Antrag, in dem mit Blick auf die Landtagswahl im Herbst 2018 ein "personeller Neuanfang" gefordert wird, wurde auf der Landesversammlung des CSU-Nachwuchses am Samstag in Erlangen mit deutlicher Mehrheit angenommen.

Bayerns Finanzminister Markus S√∂der lobte die JU: "Es gibt immer mal wieder in der Geschichte der Union Landesversammlungen, an denen wird man nicht vorbeigehen k√∂nnen. Die haben eine Wirkung", sagte der CSU-Politiker am Samstagabend. S√∂der gilt als aussichtsreicher Kandidat f√ºr die Nachfolge von Seehofer.

"Ich wei√ü, sowas f√§llt nicht leicht, und das muss man auch in Ruhe machen. Aber ich m√∂chte euch wirklich sagen: Ich habe gro√üen Respekt davor, was ihr f√ºr Verantwortung zeigt, welchen Mut ihr habt, was ihr euch traut", sagte S√∂der an die bayerische JU gerichtet. "Das ist eine Landesversammlung, und es ist eine Junge Union, die zeigt R√ºckgrat in der Partei. Meinen Respekt davor, toll gemacht."

Un¬≠ter¬≠st√ºt¬≠zung be¬≠kam See¬≠ho¬≠fer unterdessen von CSU-Par¬≠tei¬≠vi¬≠ze Man¬≠fred Weber: "Ge¬≠ra¬≠de als b√ºr¬≠ger¬≠li¬≠che Par¬≠tei muss sich die CSU sehr gut √ºber¬≠le¬≠gen, wie wir mit¬≠ein¬≠an¬≠der um¬≠ge¬≠hen. In der Art und Weise, wie es die letz¬≠ten Wo¬≠chen ge¬≠lau¬≠fen ist, wurde be¬≠reits Scha¬≠den ver¬≠ur¬≠sacht. Die Men¬≠schen haben ein fei¬≠nes Ge¬≠sp√ºr daf√ºr, dass der An¬≠stand ge¬≠wahrt blei¬≠ben muss. Ge¬≠ra¬≠de ein Mi¬≠nis¬≠ter¬≠pr√§¬≠si¬≠dent ist eine Re¬≠spekts¬≠per¬≠son."

SUMMARY:
The President of the United States briefly vanished from Twitter on Friday, perhaps explaining away that weird feeling of impending doom which may have lifted from your shoulders for a few minutes.
Donald Trump's account vanished and reappeared with no explanation within and for some the skies turned as blue as a Twitter error page.
I survived the Trump twitter outageNovember 2, 20176:58PM to 7:04PM #neverforget ‚Äî Judd Legum (@JuddLegum) November 2, 2017Trump returning to twitter like pic.twitter.com/ATbeXFf6Qh ‚Äî General Munnahger (@JDunnah) November 2, 2017Have the Russians hacked Trump's Twitter acct in order to help him again ?
‚Äî George L (@lageorges) November 2, 2017Apparently for six shining minutes, Trump was no longer the President of Twitter.

TEXT:
So it turns out an entire planet can hold its breath for 11 minutes.

The President of the United States briefly vanished from Twitter on Friday, perhaps explaining away that weird feeling of impending doom which may have lifted from your shoulders for a few minutes.

Donald Trump's account vanished and reappeared with no explanation within and for some the skies turned as blue as a Twitter error page.

That blue is a calming colour is purely coincidental.

The reaction was strong as it was swift, as Twitter's highest-profile and angriest performer suddenly disappeared.

I survived the Trump twitter outage



November 2, 2017



6:58PM to 7:04PM #neverforget ‚Äî Judd Legum (@JuddLegum) November 2, 2017

Trump returning to twitter like pic.twitter.com/ATbeXFf6Qh ‚Äî General Munnahger (@JDunnah) November 2, 2017

Have the Russians hacked Trump's Twitter acct in order to help him again ? This time by silencing him? ‚Äî George L (@lageorges) November 2, 2017

Apparently for six shining minutes, Trump was no longer the President of Twitter. I was busy biking, but I felt a disturbance in the Force. November 2, 2017

Happy to say I survived the @realDonaldTrump blackout. All the kids are fine. I'm reporting in as safe. ‚Äî Brian J. Karem (@BrianKarem) November 2, 2017

The reason everyone went nuts? Well, Trump's under a considerable amount of pressure at the moment with former aids under the glare of an intense federal investigation over ties to Russia.

So with all that swirling around, and the fact Trump has been unable to do little legislatively while his poll numbers drop into the low thirties, for a brief time people had a little calm.

Turns out it was all a big mistake.

Earlier today @realdonaldtrump's account was inadvertently deactivated due to human error by a Twitter employee. The account was down for 11 minutes, and has since been restored. We are continuing to investigate and are taking steps to prevent this from happening again. ‚Äî Twitter Government (@TwitterGov) November 3, 2017

Government work, what can we say.
TITLE: For A Brief Peaceful Moment, Donald Trump Vanished From Twitter

SUMMARY:
Mais il pense savoir ce que sa base attend de lui, et il le lui donne.
Des retweets qui en disent long sur sa mani√®re de s'informerS'il est hors de contr√¥le lorsqu'il tweete, Donald Trump l'est tout autant lorsqu'il partage des contenus sur son fil Twitter.
"Ce qu'il voit √† travers son portail aux 140 caract√®res est un monde rempli de soutien √† Trump", r√©sume le Washington Post.
Si le danger est grand, la puissance de frappe de Donald Trump sur Twitter et sa politique de la provocation syst√©matique ont pay√©.
Il le reconna√Æt lui-m√™me: "Je ne sais pas si je serais l√† o√π je suis sans les r√©seaux sociaux".
TEXT:
INTERNATIONAL - C'√©tait tout un symbole: en d√©sactivant pendant onze minutes le compte de Donald Trump vendredi 3 novembre, un employ√© de Twitter est parvenu, en quelques clics, √† atteindre l'un des organes fondamentaux de l'exercice du pouvoir √† la Maison Blanche. Avec cet ultime acte de bravoure pour son dernier jour chez Twitter, il a √©t√© salu√© en h√©ros. Car si les minutes ont d√ª para√Ætre bien longues au pr√©sident am√©ricain, elles ont √©t√© un court mais salutaire r√©pit pour d'autres.

En pr√®s de dix mois √† Washington et une ann√©e (le 8 novembre) en tant que pr√©sident √©lu, Donald Trump a fait la pluie et le beau temps de la politique nationale et internationale en 140 caract√®res. Mesures, invectives et commentaires de toutes sortes se c√¥toient p√™le-m√™le sur son fil Twitter, dont la teneur n'a aucunement chang√© depuis qu'il n'est plus animateur d'√©missions de t√©l√©-r√©alit√©. Il a d'ailleurs pr√©f√©r√© conserver son compte personnel (@realDonaldTrump) en acc√©dant √† la Maison Blanche, le compte officiel du @POTUS n'√©tant qu'une suite de retweets de son propre profil.

Le r√©seau social a pris une telle place dans sa politique que le pr√©sident am√©ricain y a d√©velopp√© des petites manies, qui en disent long sur sa vision du pouvoir... et donnent parfois le vertige.

1. La routine des tweets matinaux

Les journalistes couvrant la Maison Blanche le savent bien, aller sur Twitter est l'un des rituels matinaux du pr√©sident. Certaines expressions se sont m√™me install√©es: Donald Trump fait sa "tirade matinale sur Twitter", sa "temp√™te", sa "col√®re du matin".

En un an, Donald Trump a envoy√© 43% de ses tweets entre 2 et 9 heures du matin (retweets compris), comme nous permet de le calculer le site Trump Twitter Archive. En ao√ªt, le journaliste du New York Times Peter Baker disait ceci de la matin√©e type de Donald Trump, qu'il soit au travail ou en vacances: "Il se l√®ve, il allume la t√©l√©vision, il voit quelque chose qui le rend fou, et il cherche son t√©l√©phone -avec son compte Twitter d√©j√† activ√© dessus- pour se d√©fouler".

D√®s les premiers mois du mandat de Donald Trump, nombre d'observateurs ont en fait remarqu√© que le pr√©sident am√©ricain r√©agissait en m√™me temps qu'√©taient √©voqu√©s les sujets de l'√©mission matinale "Fox and Friends" sur Fox News, ce qui explique qu'il puisse parfois commenter des sujets sur lesquels on ne l'attendait pas.

"√Ä gauche, Fox & Friends, 6h29. √Ä droite, 6h56 (Donald Trump regarde parfois en diff√©r√©, ce qui explique le laps de temps entre l'√©mission et son tweet)"

"Plus que tout dans l'Am√©rique de Trump, ces tweets tendent √† donner le ton de la journ√©e, et son humeur du jour", interpr√®tent deux journalistes de ABC en Australie. En s'imposant d√®s le saut du lit √† ses quelque 42 millions d'abonn√©s sur Twitter, Donald Trump donne le rythme de l'actualit√© √† ses soutiens comme √† ses d√©tracteurs, et dicte les sujets qui feront parler. "C'est une alarme de r√©veil comme il n'y en a pas d'autre", disent-elles.

I've got to stop going on twitter in the morning...Trump just makes my blood boil! ‚Äî Pink Fluffy Timbers (@Timberkart) 3 novembre 2017

"Je dois arr√™ter d'aller sur Twitter le matin... Trump fait bouillir mon sang!"

Il arrive aussi r√©guli√®rement au pr√©sident am√©ricain de tweeter tard le soir, pour corriger une nouvelle fois ce qui a pu √™tre dit sur lui ou s'imposer dans un d√©bat. Certains observateurs l'expliquent par le fait que Donald Trump ne dort que quelques heures par nuit, "trois ou quatre heures", de son propre aveu. "Mais il ne tweete pas tard dans la nuit parce qu'il est en col√®re, il tweete tard dans la nuit parce qu'il tweete tard dans la nuit. Parce qu'il avait quelque chose √† dire √† ce moment pr√©cis donc il le dit, au lieu de, par exemple, aller se coucher (ou retourner se coucher)", analyse un journaliste du Washington Post.

2. Des fautes d'orthographe... et des mots invent√©s

"Un acte sans pr√©sident" (au lieu de "sans pr√©c√©dent"), "le conseil de la Maison Blanche" (au lieu du "conseiller de la Maison Blanche"), "enrregistrer" (au lieu de "enregistrer")... on ne compte pas les fois o√π le pr√©sident am√©ricain a fait des fautes d'orthographe ou de grammaire dans ses tweets avant de les corriger, quand il prend la peine de le faire.

Thr coverage about me in the @nytimes and the @washingtonpost gas been so false and angry that the times actually apologized to its..... ‚Äî Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) 28 janvier 2017

"Les articles me concernant dans le New York Times et le Washington Post sont tellement faux et haineux que le Times s'est m√™me excus√© aupr√®s de..." (le pr√©sident am√©ricain √©crit "Thr" au lieu de "the", "gas" au lieu de "has" et oublie la majuscule √† "Times")

Saving this for postority. pic.twitter.com/wmnanHjPWF ‚Äî Dave Itzkoff (@ditzkoff) 21 janvier 2017

Ici, le pr√©sident est "hon√©r√© de servir le grand peuple am√©ricain", au lieu d'√™tre "honor√©"... le jour de son investiture.

Certains de ses tweets suscitent aussi des interrogations pour les d√©tails qui semblent y avoir √©t√© volontairement diss√©min√©s. Pourquoi rajouter cette lettre isol√©e √† la fin de son tweet? Pourquoi utiliser une apostrophe pour qualifier le "petit' s√©nateur Bob Corker"?

Son plus grand fait d'armes linguistique est √©videmment l'invention du mot "covfefe", dans un tweet -incomplet- dans lequel il voulait semble-t-il parler de la "couverture m√©diatique" ("press coverage"). A-t-il fait une fausse manipulation? S'est-il endormi sur son clavier? Myst√®re. Mais le message, aim√© 123.000 fois et retweet√© plus de 100.000 fois, n'a √©t√© supprim√© que six heures apr√®s sa publication.

"Cela montre bien qu'il n'aime pas √™tre ma√Ætris√© par ses conseillers", analyse Amanda Terkel, cheffe du bureau du HuffPost am√©ricain √† Washington, interrog√©e par Le HuffPost. "Il utilise Twitter pour les contourner et √©crit tout ce qu'il veut. Souvent, ce qu'il √©crit n'est pas ce que ses conseillers aimeraient qu'il dise, explique-t-elle. Mais il pense savoir ce que sa base attend de lui, et il le lui donne. Cela vient du fait qu'il n'est pas un homme politique traditionnel -et c'est pour cela que tant de gens ont vot√© pour lui."

Malheureusement pour Trump, tous ses tweets supprim√©s sont consign√©s par l'organisme ProPublica. Par souci de transparence, mais surtout pour conserver des √©crits que la loi consid√®re, au m√™me titre qu'une note de service ou un pamphlet, comme des "presidential records", faisant partie des registres pr√©sidentiels de la Maison Blanche.

3. Des surnoms entr√©s dans les habitudes m√©diatiques

Avoir un surnom dans le vocabulaire du pr√©sident am√©ricain est le meilleur moyen de savoir qu'il vous d√©teste. Donald Trump ne manque jamais d'affubler ses adversaires politiques de surnoms au mieux d√©gradants, au pire insultants. Hillary Clinton est "Crooked Hillary" ("Hillary la crapule"), le dirigeant nord-cor√©en Kim Jong-Un est "Little Rocket Man" ("l'homme fus√©e"), Jeb Bush est "Low Energy Jeb" ("Jeb √† basse tension"), la s√©natrice d√©mocrate Elizabeth Warren est "Pocahontas" (Trump l'accuse de mentir sur ses origines am√©rindiennes).

Plus d'une quinzaine de ses opposants ont ainsi droit √† leur surnom r√©gulier, sans compter les sobriquets ponctuels, comme lorsqu'il avait attaqu√© l'actrice Meryl Streep, qu'il juge "surcot√©e". Forc√©s de relayer la parole pr√©sidentielle, les m√©dias ont malgr√© eux fait entrer ces surnoms dans l'actualit√©, quitte √† appuyer les travers des adversaires vis√©s par Trump.

Mais l'utilisation de ces surnoms ob√©it √† une strat√©gie politique dont Donald Trump a bien saisi l'efficacit√©: frapper tr√®s fort, rapidement, l√† ou √ßa fait mal. Les r√©seaux sociaux et l'acc√©l√©ration de l'information poussent les politiques √† rentabiliser leur temps et leur espace de parole, explique ainsi Dietram Scheufele, professeur de communication √† l'Universit√© du Wisconsin, interrog√© par Business Insider.

"Pour son public, (l'utilisation des surnoms) a une tr√®s grande r√©sonance, estime-t-il. Une grande partie de son succ√®s est due √† sa capacit√© √† faire √©cho presque intuitivement chez son auditoire en seulement quelques mots". En deux mots, Hillary Clinton est donc ramen√©e √† l'affaire de ses emails. Et le point va donc √† Donald Trump.

4. Des retweets qui en disent long sur sa mani√®re de s'informer

S'il est hors de contr√¥le lorsqu'il tweete, Donald Trump l'est tout autant lorsqu'il partage des contenus sur son fil Twitter. En septembre, lors de l'une de ses sessions matinales sur le r√©seau social, il avait ainsi partag√© un gif de l'un de ses sympathisants, le montrant jouant au golf et toucher Hillary Clinton dans le dos, la faisant tr√©bucher. L'auteur de ce gif, @Fuctupmind sur Twitter, a √©t√© rep√©r√© par Buzzfeed, notamment √† cause de ses tweets transphobes et antis√©mites.

"Le swing incroyable de Donald Trump #CrookedHillary"

L'an dernier, alors qu'il √©tait toujours en campagne, il avait supprim√© son tweet reprenant un montage photo d'Hillary Clinton qualifi√©e de "candidate la plus corrompue de l'histoire", cette expression ayant √©t√© inscrite dans une √©toile de David. Le montage avait √©t√© r√©alis√© par des supr√©macistes blancs et n√©onazis.

Cette porosit√© entre des comptes v√©hiculant des id√©ologies douteuses et celui du pr√©sident des √âtats-Unis en dit long sur sa mani√®re de s'informer et les id√©es dont il s'inspire tous les jours. "Ce qu'il voit √† travers son portail aux 140 caract√®res est un monde rempli de soutien √† Trump", r√©sume le Washington Post. C'est pour souligner cela que le site d'information a cr√©√© le compte Twitter "Trump's Feed", qui retweete automatiquement tous les tweets des 45 comptes suivis par Donald Trump (9 sont de la Trump Organization, 7 sont de Fox News), et donne un aper√ßu de sa page d'accueil sur Twitter.

En twittant et retweetant des informations √©manant de The Hill (un site d'information qui lui est favorable, et dont il conna√Æt le propri√©taire), de Breitbart News (plateforme de l'extr√™me droite am√©ricaine) ou de ses soutiens anonymes, Donald Trump prend le risque de partager des informations incorrectes (les fameuses "fake news", expression qui qualifiait au d√©part ses d√©clarations infond√©es et dont il a retourn√© le sens pour en faire l'apanage des m√©dias).

"Le danger d'un pr√©sident qui se nourrit de la t√©l√©vision pour parler des √©v√©nements nationaux et internationaux est qu'il se base tr√®s souvent sur des avis d'experts, les opinions des gens et non les faits", analyse l'historien politique Mark Updegrove. Si le danger est grand, la puissance de frappe de Donald Trump sur Twitter et sa politique de la provocation syst√©matique ont pay√©. Il le reconna√Æt lui-m√™me: "Je ne sais pas si je serais l√† o√π je suis sans les r√©seaux sociaux".

√Ä voir √©galement sur Le HuffPost:
TITLE: Les 4 manies de Donald Trump sur Twitter qui en disent long sur sa mani√®re de gouverner

TEXT:
Pierre Brassard est le porte-parole d'Ataxie Canada, et la t√™te d'affiche de la nouvelle campagne de l'organisme. Les ataxies familiales sont un groupe de maladies neurologiques, g√©n√©tiques et d√©g√©n√©ratives du syst√®me nerveux central. Ce sont des maladies tr√®s handicapantes pour ceux qui en souffrent. ¬´La recherche permet de faire avancer la cause et de redonner espoir aux gens qui souffrent d'une ataxie familiale. Nous n'avons jamais √©t√© aussi pr√®s de la gu√©rison et chaque don, aussi petit soit-il, nous en rapproche¬ª, explique Brassard dans un communiqu√© de presse.

Afin d'encourager les donations, une annonce a √©t√© cr√©√©e par l'agence Brad et r√©alis√©e par Jean-Fran√ßois Chagnon, qu'on conna√Æt pour son travail sur Les Appendices et les Bye-Bye. SUMMARY:
I grew up saying ‚ÄúAllahu Akbar‚Äù numerous times every day.
Allahu AkbarThe saying literally means God is the greatest.
It is required of all Muslims to say several times during prayer, which is demanded five times a day.
So when and why is the phrase Allahu Akbar used as a battle cry, when a terrorist is about to kill someone?
Here‚Äôs where the double standard hurts: When that man killed 58 people in Las Vegas, the word terrorist was not uttered by anyone.
TEXT:
I grew up saying ‚ÄúAllahu Akbar‚Äù numerous times every day.

And no, I wasn‚Äôt, and am not, a terrorist.

I wasn‚Äôt someone who blew buildings up, killed people or shot a missile from my rocket launcher. As far as the West is concerned, those are the events associated with the saying when something bad is about to happen. People of the West are terrified of the phrase.

I was a Muslim boy trying to pray as many times as he could amidst a life of love and peace, in a home that did not condone any terrorism. My father was a poet who read me love poetry instead of nursery rhymes. He uttered the phrase when he prayed. If love existed in the form of a man, it was my father.

‚ÄúLove everyone,‚Äù was the phrase he uttered almost daily. To him, there was not a problem he couldn‚Äôt solve with love.

Allahu Akbar

The saying literally means God is the greatest. It is required of all Muslims to say several times during prayer, which is demanded five times a day. On the average a Muslim ends up saying it hundreds of times. The words are also used as a celebration of life: When a baby is born, when a couple marry or when a veteran returns home safe.

The word Islam means surrender. You‚Äôre supposed to surrender to God and worship him. Love, mercy and compassion are uttered several hundred times a day by any Muslim when they say Besm Allah Alrahman Alraheem, In The Name Of God The Merciful The Compassionate. That saying is uttered before you do anything.

So when and why is the phrase Allahu Akbar used as a battle cry, when a terrorist is about to kill someone? The latest incident was the horrific act in New York when the terrorist shouted the phrase before the police shot him, and after he killed eight people and injured many more.

For the majority of Muslims, to shout God‚Äôs name as you killed the innocent is an abomination. Muslims no more want innocent people killed than anyone else. So why is the phrase used by terrorists?

For the same reason ISIS and Al-Qaida exist: The misinterpretation of Islam. When you use religion as the motive for you actions, you have the power to appeal to the masses. It‚Äôs a brain washing if you will. The terrorists who flew the planes into the World Trade Center on September 11th are no different than any suicide bomber in Israel/Palestine, are no different that the one who mowed down bicyclists in New York. They are people who misunderstood and misused the religion. They are sick and twisted and evil.

The phrase is to remind Muslims that God is supreme. That‚Äôs it. It was never to be used as a battle cry during horrendous actions furthering political agendas with evil motives.

My heart sank when I heard the terrorist shouted the saying after the attack. I will never understand the link between Islam and Terrorism. The Islam I grew up amidst condemns such actions. It preaches love and peace and tranquility and feeding the hungry and clothing the poor and sheltering the homeless. One of the five main requirements of Islam in addition to prayer and fasting is to give a percentage of your money to the poor.

Is There A Difference?

To me, there is no difference between the terrorists who shout Allahu Akbar when committing a crime and those white nationalists and racists who shouted ‚ÄúJews will not replace us‚Äù in Charlottesville ‚Äï Virginia recently.

Here‚Äôs where the double standard hurts: When that man killed 58 people in Las Vegas, the word terrorist was not uttered by anyone. Why is it only attached to people who claim Islamic affiliation?

The Quran was brought down to Muhammad in the seventh century. The verses which preach war and fighting were contextual and apply to the time when he and his followers had no choice but to fight back, or die. It is no different than the Old Testament which contains many verses preaching war and killing.

In Deuteronomy Chapter 2, Verses 32-37, Moses is told to kill men, women, and children:

‚ÄúAnd the LORD said unto me, Behold, I have begun to give Siphon and his land before thee: begin to possess, that thou mayest inherit his land. Then Sihon came out against us, he and all his people, to fight at Jahaz. And the LORD our God delivered him before us; and we smote him, and his sons, and all his people. And we took all his cities at that time, and utterly destroyed the men, and the women, and the little ones , of every city, we left none to remain. From Aroer, which is by the brink of the river of Arnon, and from the city that is by the river, even unto Gilead, there was not one city too strong for us: the LORD our God delivered all unto us.‚Äù

How is this any different than what‚Äôs in the Quran? And why are Muslims judged by a different prism? Most of the Quran preaches love and harmony and helping those who have not. Take this for example:

‚ÄúAnd feed with food the needy wretch, the orphan and the prisoner, for love of Him (saying): We feed you, for the sake of Allah only. We wish for no reward nor thanks from you.‚Äù [76:8-9]

Any ancient religious book can be misunderstood and misrepresented. The Ku Klux Klan said the Jesus was the first Klansman. They burned crosses to spread their ill will. How is that any different?

My Sister

Karim Shamsi-Basha My sisters Mimi, right, and Rowaida.

My sister Rowaida lives in New York. We chatted last night when I wanted to make sure her head covering was not causing any problems. In the past when terrorists committed atrocities in the name of Islam, women with head coverings were profiled. She said everything was fine, and prayed for those people affected by the terror.

My sister prayed for them.

She is a teacher and her husband is an architect. All they want is food, water, and a roof over their heads, and for their children to thrive. They have four: a computer scientist, a doctor, a physical therapist, and a pharmacist. They love like anyone else, and they have compassion and mercy and empathy like anyone else.

The covering on her head says two things: Modesty and humility.

A Wish Or Two

I have one wish, well maybe two.

The first is for my children to thrive and go through life without any judgment based on their last name.

The second is for this world to know that Muslims mean no one any harm. The people who mean harm are as far from Islam as the KKK is far from Christianity.

My religion is love.
TITLE: I Say Allahu Akbar. I Am Not A Terrorist.
