SUMMARY:
For those living in countries with poor population nutrition like India, this saying has more ironic significance than we can imagine.
Hence, a significant section of India's population has poor nutrition and resultantly poor immunity to the TB bacteria.
In the case of TB, poor nutrition also affects recovery from TB and increases drug toxicity, relapse and death once TB develops.
First and foremost, hunger and poor nutrition should be morally unacceptable in largely poor countries like India.
If the state cannot feed its people, it loses all moral right to exercise authority.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

We are what we eat or so the famous saying goes. For those living in countries with poor population nutrition like India, this saying has more ironic significance than we can imagine. In India, it is estimated that half of Indian women age 15-49 (48 percent) and 43 percent of Indian men age 15-49 are undernourished. Arguably, a third of women of reproductive age in India is undernourished. In children under 5, statistics reveal that stunting is seen in 48 per cent while 43 per cent are underweight and wasting is common in close to 20 per cent. Hence, India is what it eats. It seems either hungry or without sufficiently nutritious food.

While governments ignore or dismiss these statistics, what they often do not realise is that poor nutrition is a leading cause of vulnerability to diseases. Nutrition has a critical role in both determining immunity and the ability to recover from diseases. Take the case of Tuberculosis of TB- one of India's top killers.

TB is easily diagnosed and treated, yet it kills lakhs of Indians each year. Several studies globally, and in India, illustrate that social, behavioural, economic and environmental factors like undernutrition, indoor air pollution, smoking and alcohol addiction act as facilitating factors to the spread of TB.

Nutrition has a critical role in both determining immunity and the ability to recover from diseases

Of these, undernutrition is the single-most important predisposing factor for TB in India. Hence, a significant section of India's population has poor nutrition and resultantly poor immunity to the TB bacteria. Not surprisingly, like undernutrition, TB exists in India at an epic scale, most often affecting those among the age group of 15-55 ‚Äî an individual's most productive age.

With undernutrition we essentially create large masses with increased vulnerability to TB and other diseases. This, along with poor infection control and limited awareness, creates disease epidemics such as TB in India. Nutrition also affects recovery from disease. In the case of TB, poor nutrition also affects recovery from TB and increases drug toxicity, relapse and death once TB develops. As a result patients with poor nutritional levels are likely to show poorer performance on TB treatment because of poor muscle strength. There is always a higher risk of TB relapse among such patients as well. Appropriate nutritional intake is critical to ensure treatment completion as well as a faster road to recovery.

NEW DELHI, INDIA MAY 29: The picture featuring TB Patients in Patel Chest Hospital on May 29, 2013 in New Delhi, India. (Photo by Ramesh Pathania/Mint via Getty Images)

When considering India's significant TB crisis, it is clear that new technologies, quick and early diagnosis and less toxic treatments are critical to address India's TB epidemic. With a vast number of people affected, this is needed urgently. An accompanying though more fundamental question, what about addressing hunger and nutrition? How can we comprehensively address TB in the long-term without addressing the nutritional status of the population and ensuring immunity? Until we do so, are we not setting a near-impossible task for ourselves with a large and vulnerable population? Unless we address the root cause, will faster diagnosis and improved treatment alone end TB in India?

India needs food security for increased immunity for all diseases including TB. Why? The answers are simple. First and foremost, hunger and poor nutrition should be morally unacceptable in largely poor countries like India. If the state cannot feed its people, it loses all moral right to exercise authority. Without food, words like vikas are meaningless. Also, continued malnutrition and hunger increase vulnerability, thereby increasing disease prevalence, and consequently human suffering, burdening the health system and society at large. This has staggering human, economic and social consequences that perpetuate inequity‚Äîsomething that should be unacceptable as well. From a purely economic view, it causes increased suffering, loss of wages, unemployment, debt and financial desperation ‚Äî undesirables in India's fantastic march towards vikas.

If the state cannot feed its people, it loses all moral right to exercise authority

It's time India thought of significant investment in nutrition as the foundational basis of a population's well-being, social justice, economic growth and as a preventive strategy for all diseases. Some solutions that India must consider are universal food security. This, of course, is fraught with challenges both in relation to implementation and in funding. However, these challenges cannot be used as the basis of reneging on this essential and beneficial strategy.

Too often there are too many ineffective schemes.We need to re-examine, link and innovate programmes run by various ministries, including health and women & child development among others. This is possible if we mainstream nutrition and food security for all beneficiary groups and not just those affected by diseases. For those affected by diseases, we need to provide long-term specialised nutritional support and supervision through programmes that ensure sufficient nutrition.

It's time to go back to basics and recognise that nutrition is the fundamental building block not just for disease prevention but the nation itself. Until we do so our claims to eliminate TB or any other disease will remain hollow. And our march towards vikas will be like a never-ending one to a mythical heaven.

Also on HuffPost
TITLE: If A State Cannot Feed Its People, It Loses All Moral Right To Exercise Authority

TEXT:
Le 7 d√©cembre prochain, Kazuo Ishiguro, romancier britannique n√© √† Nagasaki, prononcera son discours de r√©ception du prix Nobel de litt√©rature. Quel sera le contenu de son allocution? Il faudra patienter encore plus d'un mois avant de le savoir. En attendant, essayons d'imaginer les grandes lignes de son futur message en gardant en m√©moire le discours de Su√®de d'Albert Camus, √©galement couronn√© du Nobel il y a soixante ans.

Kazuo Ishiguro est un humaniste au positionnement moral et politique comparable √† celui d'Albert Camus. Un r√©cent volume de la collection Folio, intitul√© Conf√©rences et discours, offre l'occasion de relire le discours de l'auteur de L'√©tranger, prononc√© le 10 d√©cembre 1957 √† Stockholm, et de transposer ses pr√©occupations dans l'univers d'Ishiguro.

Camus s'interrogeait sur les devoirs de l'√©crivain. Il s'agissait pour lui de r√©soudre ce qu'il nommait depuis la fin de la Seconde Guerre mondiale "la crise de l'homme". Pour lutter contre les risques de d√©sagr√©gation du monde, il soutenait une morale de l'engagement.

Ishiguro partage l'inqui√©tude camusienne : quelle vertu pr√¥ner pour √©viter l'autodestruction de l'humanit√© sous la pression des guerres, des totalitarismes et du d√©voiement de la technique? Ces questions n'ont gu√®re chang√© depuis les ann√©es 1950. Mais Ishiguro se distingue par une technique magistrale de romancier : le monologue int√©rieur lui permet d'explorer les fronti√®res de l'humain dans des m√©ditations subtiles et sensibles.

Avant lui, Camus a souvent d√©plor√© la disparition du sentiment de dignit√©, consid√©r√© comme la plus haute exigence humaine. "Un homme √ßa s'emp√™che. Voil√† ce que c'est un homme, ou sinon...", s'exclame le p√®re de Jacques Cormery dans Le premier homme √† propos des exactions commises au Maroc pendant le conflit de 1905. La ma√Ætrise de soi, le refus de la barbarie sont des crit√®res pour d√©finir l'homme probe.

Et pourtant, les sentiments les plus nobles n'emp√™chent pas les erreurs de jugements et ne pourront, √† eux seuls, sauver l'humanit√©. D√©veloppant en creux une √©thique de l'engagement dans Les vestiges du jour, roman qui a re√ßu le Booker Prize en 1989, Ishiguro imagine le personnage de Stevens, impeccable majordome √† Darlington Hall. Le butler est convaincu que la dignit√© est l'apanage de l'aristocratie domestique. √Ä ses yeux, ceux qui dirigent les plus grandes maisons doivent d√©ployer des tr√©sors de distinction, d'√©ducation et de d√©vouement pour d√©passer leur condition d'employ√©.

Cette attitude irr√©prochable est pourtant mise √† l'√©preuve quand elle devient contraire √† la pr√©servation des int√©r√™ts de l'humanit√©. Stevens est persuad√© que son honneur de majordome exige qu'il conserve sa discr√©tion professionnelle, y compris quand son ma√Ætre, Lord Darlington, invite les plus hauts dignitaires nazis dans son ch√¢teau.

En r√©alit√©, dans Les vestiges du jour, Ishiguro se montre tr√®s pessimiste quant aux capacit√©s des hommes √† affronter le mal. Et la confiance en une vertu rigide ne semble pas un viatique suffisant pour garantir √† chacun l'accomplissement de son destin humain.

Mais Ishiguro ne se satisfait pas de la satire. C'est pourquoi il d√©laisse progressivement le r√©alisme pour aborder le registre onirique ou fantastique. Dans Quand nous √©tions orphelins, roman des ann√©es 2000, son personnage principal, Christopher Banks est contraint √† revisiter le pass√© colonial de l'Orient. Au terme d'une enqu√™te initiatique sur la disparition inexpliqu√©e de ses parents dans le Shanghai dangereux de son enfance, √† une √©poque o√π le territoire √©tait livr√© aux trafiquants d'opium, Banks r√©tablit le lien bris√© de la m√©moire. Il acquiert ainsi le sentiment d'avoir accompli sa mission consistant √† r√©tablir une forme de continuit√© avec ses anc√™tres.

D'ailleurs, la m√©moire devient progressivement un th√®me obs√©dant chez le romancier. Dans un effrayant r√©cit intitul√© Aupr√®s de moi toujours, Ishiguro continue d'explorer les fronti√®res de l'humain √† travers le transhumanisme. Les personnages de ce roman sont en effet des clones, √©lev√©s dans le seul but de devenir des donneurs d'organes. Leur libert√© est tout √† fait illusoire, leur avenir sera tragique et le pass√© est leur seule consolation.

Apr√®s Bob Dylan, laur√©at 2016 du prix Nobel de litt√©rature, les jur√©s du Nobel confirment leur int√©r√™t pour les questions √©thiques et leur inqui√©tude concernant le futur de l'humanit√©. Et le prochain discours d'Ishiguro sera un √©v√©nement √† suivre sur le site officiel du prix Nobel.

Pour aller plus loin: Conf√©rences et discours 1936-1958 d'Albert Camus, Folio, 2017. Les vestiges du jour de Kazuo Ishiguro, traduit de l'anglais par Sophie Mayoux, Folio, 2010. Quand nous √©tions orphelins de Kazuo Ishiguro, traduit de l'anglais par Fran√ßois Rosso, Folio, 2009. Aupr√®s de moi toujours de Kazuo Ishiguro, traduit de l'anglais par Anne Rabinovitch, 2015.

20:15 Uhr, ZDF: Marie f√§ngt Feuer: Allein war gestern, Familienfilm

Marie (Christine Eixenberger) trifft nach einem Feuerwehreinsatz auf Luisa (Katharina Thalbach), eine Pferdehofbesitzerin, die sich das Leben nicht mehr leisten kann. Luisa versucht allein mit der Situation zurechtzukommen. Doch Marie macht ihr klar, dass sie Hilfe braucht und es diese gibt. Sie beantragen Grundsicherung f√ºr Luisa. Doch die Hoffnung w√§hrt nicht lange: Um Geld zu bekommen, m√ºsste Luisa Pferd und Hof aufgeben. Erst der neue Tierarzt Joachim (Simon Schwarz) bringt Marie auf die rettende Idee.

"Pixels" und viele weitere Filme k√∂nnen Sie bei Amazon Prime sehen - hier geht's zum kostenlosen 30-Tage-Test

20:15 Uhr, RTL: Pixels, Sci-Fi-Action

Im Jahr 1982 nehmen Sam Brenner (Sam Brenner) und sein Freund Will Cooper (Kevin James) an der ersten Arcade-Weltmeisterschaft teil. Brenner kommt ins Finale, verliert jedoch gegen den geh√§ssigen Plant im Spiel Donkey Kong. Die NASA schickt die Mitschnitte der Spiele ins Weltall, um mit au√üerirdischem Leben in Kontakt zu treten. Die Au√üerirdischen interpretieren die Aufnahmen als Kriegserkl√§rung der Menschen und greifen daraufhin die Erde an. Da das Milit√§r machtlos ist, bittet der US-Pr√§sident Will Cooper seinen alten Freund Sam Brenner um Hilfe. Denn als fr√ºherer Videospiel-Champion wei√ü er am besten, wie man Pac-Man, Donkey Kong und Co. besiegen kann.

20:15 Uhr, ProSieben: Die Tribute von Panem - Mockingjay Teil 1, Sci-Fi-Drama

Katniss Everdeen (Jennifer Lawrence) wird von den Rebellen aus der Arena der Hungerspiele gerettet. Anschlie√üend taucht sie im unterirdischen, zerst√∂rt geglaubten Distrikt 13 unter. Als ein Krieg ausbricht, der die Zukunft von Panem bestimmen wird, muss sich Katniss entscheiden, ob sie die Rebellen im Kampf gegen das Kapitol unterst√ºtzt. Das Schicksal liegt in ihren H√§nden.

20:15 Uhr, RTL II: Big Wedding, Kom√∂die

Alejandro (Ben Barnes) und Melissa (Amanda Seyfried) stecken mitten in ihren Hochzeitsvorbereitungen. Als sich Alejandros leibliche und streng katholische Mutter Madonna (Patricia Rae) aus Kolumbien ank√ºndigt, gestalten sich diese allerdings pl√∂tzlich ganz anders. Seit zehn Jahren sind Alejandros Adoptiveltern Don (Robert De Niro) und Ellie (Diane Keaton) nicht mehr verheiratet. Madonna wei√ü jedoch nichts √ºber die Trennung der Adoptiveltern. Da Alejandro nicht mit der Wahrheit herausr√ºcken will, m√ºssen Don und Ellie kurzerhand das gl√ºckliche Ehepaar mimen. Doch das f√ºhrt zu chaotischen Momenten und unerwarteten Wahrheiten.

20:15 Uhr, VOX: Grill den Profi, Kochshow

Oana Nechiti, Peter Neururer und Pietro Lombardi treten gegen den Profikoch Ralf Zacherl an. Die Promis bringen ihr Lieblingsgericht mit, um mithilfe eines Koch-Coaches den Profi auf die Probe zu stellen. Denn der erf√§hrt erst in der Show von seinem zu kochenden Gericht. Wer am Ende ein Preisgeld f√ºr den guten Zweck absahnt, entscheidet nach jeder Kochrunde die anspruchsvolle Jury.
TITLE: TV-Tipps am Sonntag: Darum geht's bei "Marie f√§ngt Feuer: Allein war gestern"

SUMMARY:
Mujeres que como la Sra.
Que igual se agrandan tetas que se colocan o se quitan pijas.
Un mundo en el que los poderosos se convierten en dependientes de la gente que est√° a su servicio.
Una corriente que en su mundo de locura permite y admite tanto los cultismos como la comedia, incluida la musical.
Un autor que es un animal salvaje al que resulta dif√≠cil, sino imposible, domesticar.
TEXT:
El homosexual o la dificultad de expresarse - Copi

Ha pasado Copi, mejor dicho, dos de sus obras, por el madrile√±o Teatro Espa√±ol como una exhalaci√≥n. Apenas 3 d√≠as para ver en programa doble la obra 'El homosexual o la dificultad de expresarse' y una de sus m√°s conocidas, 'Eva Per√≥n'. S√≠, Copi era argentino y homosexual. De lo primero no ejerci√≥ de forma voluntaria, pues para √©l, el artista es de donde pace, no de donde nace, y el pac√≠a en Francia y en el mundo. De lo segundo s√≠ ejerci√≥, y lo hizo sin ambages, sin dudas.

De tal manera que su teatro se caracteriza porque los papeles de muchas de las mujeres de sus obras, sobre todo los protag√≥nicos, los deben interpretar hombres. Homosexuales o no, como no lo es Benjam√≠n Vicu√±a, el famoso actor latinoamericano que interpreta a Eva Per√≥n.

Todo es extremo pero todo se act√∫a en escena con una pasmosa naturalidad, como sin esfuerzo.

Primera extra√±eza pues, encontrarse hombres haciendo de mujer. Mujeres que como la Sra. Garbo (¬°magn√≠fico Hern√°n Franco!) y la Sra. Simpson de 'El homosexual...' enamoran a otros hombres. Y ellas se enamoran de otros hombres como lo pueden hacer de otras mujeres. Aunque en ese l√≠o de g√©neros, perfectamente calculado por el autor, uno ya no sabe si eran hombres que se operaron de mujeres o mujeres que se operaron para ser hombres que luego se operaron para ser mujeres. Que igual se agrandan tetas que se colocan o se quitan pijas. El caso es que, o se quieren o se admiran, y, o las quieren o las admiran, curiosamente, tal y como son, como fueron y como puedan llegar a ser.

Por tanto, una vez m√°s, se trata de una reivindicaci√≥n loca del amor, ese p√°jaro rebelde al que se canta en Carmen de Bizet, habanera que Gustavo Lizarecrea en versi√≥n asi√°tica. Amor y p√°jaro que superan imponderables. Incluidos los cotidianos, las costumbres del otro, del ser amado. Sus malos olores. Sus malos humos. Sus cambios de humor. Esa realidad tozuda que es el otro o la otra que se incluye sin invitarla a cualquier sue√±o o futuro de happy ending que se tenga so√±ado para con la persona amada, idealizada. Un amor extremo que ya solo es posible en lugares rid√≠culamente extremos. Como esta historia de madre e hija, un poco lela, un poco rebelde, a la que le gusta coger (es decir, follar), que viven en Siberia. All√≠ la nena, se dejar√° querer por la glamurosa Sra. Garbo, su profesora de piano, que sue√±a con llev√°rsela a China para vivir juntas, y su esperada descendencia, hasta el final de sus d√≠as.

Todo es extremo pero todo se act√∫a en escena con una pasmosa naturalidad, como sin esfuerzo. Porque hay una direcci√≥n exquisita de Marcial Di Fonzo Bo, actual director art√≠stico de La Comedie de Caen, el CDN de Normandie, y un texto que lo permite y que, a la vez, lo pide. Ha sido bueno que encontrase el director y los actores que se lo han podido proporcionar. Lo que se necesita para poder contar la dificultad que hay (todav√≠a) para hablar de una operaci√≥n de sexo como se habla de haberse roto una pierna. Ambas cosas igual de accidentales, igual de dolorosas y necesitadas de que se fijen. La dificultad para hablar de ir al m√©dico para una cosa como para hablar de la otra. Escrita en los setenta y tan actual.

Benjam√≠n Vicu√±a como Eva Per√≥n de Copi

Un grado de locura que no acaba aqu√≠. Pues sigue en 'Eva Per√≥n', obra que cuenta los √∫ltimos d√≠as u horas de este icono del siglo XX que agrand√≥ Andrew Lloyd Weber con su Evita, virgen de los descamisados y de las villas miserias argentinas. Obra en la que se muestra como el oropel del lujo, el cortin√≥n con flor de Lis y los vestidos de haute couture resultan insuficientes para arropar un cuerpo que sabe que se muere y que nada de eso, ni el lujo ni el amor del pueblo, podr√° llevarse a la tumba.

En el entreacto se recuerdan las palabras de Copi acerca de su Eva. √âl fue claro en que esta obra no era un trasunto pol√≠tico, aunque ahora y m√°s cuando se estren√≥ resulte dif√≠cil no verla y leerla en esos t√©rminos. El caso es que la reina se muere. El (deterioro) f√≠sico le obliga a despedirse de su mundo. Un mundo caprichoso en el que poder permite querer una cosa para inmediatamente querer su contraria. Un mundo en el que es dif√≠cil saber qui√©n te quiere. Quien te ama. Un mundo en el que los poderosos se convierten en dependientes de la gente que est√° a su servicio. Un mundo que impide escapar si no es muri√©ndose. O se mata o se muere en este juego. No hay otra forma de salir indemne, aunque se haga por la puerta de atr√°s como este personaje. De incognito y con las cuentas en Suiza, u otros para√≠sos fiscales, llenas de pesos.

Un cuerpo que es el musculado y sano de Benjam√≠n Vicu√±a, mientras que su personaje no para de decir que se muere de c√°ncer, entre capricho y capricho. Contradicci√≥n que se hace con sutileza a pesar de estar este actor casi siempre en escena. El caso es que la reina se muere sin remedio y es el momento de que sus asesores y familiares, que se dan cuenta que se les acaba el momio, est√©n a la que salta para asegurarse o crearse un futuro, por corto que pueda ser como el de la anciana madre de Eva Per√≥n, tambi√©n interpretada por un hombre del que resulta imposible despegar el la vista y el o√≠do. Mecanismos de un poder pol√≠tico paradigm√°tico que se hace popular para ser poder y poder hacer (y deshacer) a su antojo.

Copi es, pues, un grito susurrado al ojo del espectador. Una corriente que en su mundo de locura permite y admite tanto los cultismos como la comedia, incluida la musical. Por todo ello, es y sigue siendo aire fresco, a pesar de su consagraci√≥n y del intento de meterlo en las academias y clasificarlo, por su militancia, como literatura solo LGTB cuando este escritor dice tanto sin importar el g√©nero. Un autor que es un animal salvaje al que resulta dif√≠cil, sino imposible, domesticar. Por eso han hecho bien el director y el equipo de esta propuesta tir√°ndose al monte con √©l antes que intentar doblegarlo. Ir a su corriente en vez de convertirlo en un autor contracorriente.

S√≠guenos tambi√©n en el Facebook de HuffPost Blogs
TITLE: Copi, ese autor salvaje e indomable que hay que montar a pelo

SUMMARY:
The self-described Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the terror attack in lower Manhattan this week, which killed eight and injured 12.
It's a pattern seen before, although the militant group waited longer than it typically does to claim responsibility.
Notes found at the scene point to Saipov's belief that the militant group would "endure forever."
It is currently unclear to what extent, if any, ISIS was involved in planning or inspiring the attack in New York.
It's also rare for ISIS to claim responsibility for an attack if the perpetrator is in custody, New York Times' ISIS correspondent Rukmini Callimachi noted.
TEXT:
The self-described Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the terror attack in lower Manhattan this week, which killed eight and injured 12.

ISIS described the attack in its weekly Al-Naba newsletter as "one of the most prominent attacks targeting Crusaders in America," and a response to its call to target "citizens of the Crusader countries involved in the alliance against the Islamic State." The publication also called the alleged assailant, who is in police custody, a "soldier" of the group.

It's a pattern seen before, although the militant group waited longer than it typically does to claim responsibility. ISIS also tends to release the news via its Amaq news agency after a flurry of activity among pro-ISIS online accounts.

Police said Wednesday that the suspect, Sayfullo Habibullaevic Saipov, acted in the name of ISIS and had been planning the attack for several weeks. Notes found at the scene point to Saipov's belief that the militant group would "endure forever."

While recovering from a gunshot wound at a hospital in New York, Saipov asked investigators if he could display ISIS flags in his room, according to a complaint released by the U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York. In court papers, prosecutors noted Saipov said "he felt good about what he had done." The suspect had planned to put ISIS flags on his vehicle but later thought better of it, afraid it would draw attention to him, the complaint said. Saipov's cellphones contained about 90 videos and 3,800 photos, many related to ISIS, The Associated Press reported. The images included ISIS prisoners being beheaded, shot or run over by a tank.

The group's intricate involvement in each attack differs. It is currently unclear to what extent, if any, ISIS was involved in planning or inspiring the attack in New York. It's also rare for ISIS to claim responsibility for an attack if the perpetrator is in custody, New York Times' ISIS correspondent Rukmini Callimachi noted.

Following ISIS's claim of responsibility for the deadly mass shooting in Las Vegas on Oct. 1, which lacked evidence, there has been increased scrutiny over the credibility of the group's statements.
TITLE: ISIS Claims Responsibility For New York City Terror Attack

SUMMARY:
It‚Äôs fair to say that Sir Kenneth Branagh‚Äôs latest offering, a big-screen adaptation of ‚ÄòMurder On The Orient Express‚Äô, is one of the year‚Äôs most talked-about films, thanks in no small part to its all-star cast.
Given modern tastes, there is probably a reason for that.‚Äù‚ÄúDespite its credentials ‚Äì and its impeccable styling ‚Äì this Orient Express never gets up a head of steam.
‚ÄúWhere ‚ÄòMurder On The Orient Express‚Äô succeeds is in Branagh‚Äôs fast pacing and the suspense he maintains throughout; each suspect is given screen time, and each has a plausible reason for murder, but none of them are lingered on for too long.
‚ÄúA multi-generational team sees crowd pleasers Daisy Ridley and Olivia Colman rubbing elbows with Hollywood stars such as Judi Dench, Penelope Cruz and Willem Dafoe.
‚ÄúI am still wondering why you‚Äôve gathered us all together.‚Äù‚ÄòMurder On The Orient Express‚Äô is in UK cinemas now.
TEXT:
It‚Äôs fair to say that Sir Kenneth Branagh‚Äôs latest offering, a big-screen adaptation of ‚ÄòMurder On The Orient Express‚Äô, is one of the year‚Äôs most talked-about films, thanks in no small part to its all-star cast.

As well as the esteemed thespian himself, the film includes star turns from an array of our absolute faves, including Dame Judi Dench, Michelle Pfeiffer, Daisy Ridley, Olivia Colman and Leslie Odom Jr (oh, and Johnny Depp‚Äôs in it).

Well, following Thursday‚Äôs world premiere, the critics have had their say, and they‚Äôre largely divided over the new film.

Here‚Äôs a cross-section of what the reviews are saying‚Ä¶

‚ÄúFor those who know the outcome of ‚ÄòMurder‚Äô going in, the question isn‚Äôt so much whodunit as how Branagh will keep audiences guessing, and though he succeeds in creating the most memorable incarnation of Poirot ever seen on-screen (upstaging even Johnny Depp‚Äôs competing cameo), the movie is a failure overall, juggling too many characters to keep straight, and botching the last act so badly that those who go in blind may well walk out not having understood its infamous twist ending.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhen the murder is announced, the narrative clockwork is assumed to have been set in motion. And yet it is more like the victim‚Äôs pocket watch, which was smashed in the violence and ceased to work, thus giving Poirot a vital clue as to the time of death. ... This film never gets up a head of steam.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe film‚Äôs starry cast certainly matches Lumet‚Äôs in its lustre, though Depp feels too much the caricature gangster drawn from a pulp fiction, while the likes of Judi Dench, Penelope Cruz, Derek Jacobi, Willem Dafoe and Daisy Ridley (largely untested in a galaxy closer to home) get little opportunity to strut their stuff.

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt make too many classic ‚Äòwhodunnits‚Äô like this anymore. Given modern tastes, there is probably a reason for that.‚Äù

‚ÄúDespite its credentials ‚Äì and its impeccable styling ‚Äì this Orient Express never gets up a head of steam. Its cast feel fenced in, somehow, like travellers used to the legroom of the premium coach consigned to cattle class. Since the plot has 12 suspects to juggle that‚Äôs partly a matter of logistics.

‚ÄúBut even in their showpiece one-on-one moments, something‚Äôs not there ‚Äì you never feel as if you‚Äôre getting full-beam Pfeiffer or Maximum Dench, and a swishy roundhouse kick or two aside, Polunin‚Äôs Count Andrenyi doesn‚Äôt count for much.

‚ÄúWhere ‚ÄòMurder On The Orient Express‚Äô succeeds is in Branagh‚Äôs fast pacing and the suspense he maintains throughout; each suspect is given screen time, and each has a plausible reason for murder, but none of them are lingered on for too long.

‚ÄúThe elephant on the screen, however, is Johnny Depp, whose performance isn‚Äôt strong enough to make you forget you‚Äôre watching Depp and therefore forget about his real life troubles. Although the debate over separating the individual from the performance has no clear answer, unfortunately here Depp is back to his usual tricks of overacting... and it‚Äôs a shame, as his Mr Ratchett is a piece of work and one of the more intriguing characters.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot too long at under two hours, ‚ÄôMurder on the Orient Express‚Äô chugs along steadily toward the end-point revelation, which is unlikely to come as an enormous surprise to even the uninitiated, but delivers an added punch new to this version of the film. It‚Äôs highly entertaining escapism but it‚Äôs all rather forgettable once you disembark. And like Poirot‚Äôs moustache, it‚Äôs all a bit unnecessary.

‚ÄúA multi-generational team sees crowd pleasers Daisy Ridley and Olivia Colman rubbing elbows with Hollywood stars such as Judi Dench, Penelope Cruz and Willem Dafoe. Dressed in richly designed period costumes, they are appropriately photographed on old school film stock not modern digital cameras.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs questionable whether this will gain traction with a young audience who expect louder and flashier cinematic fireworks, or with an older audience who have possibly witnessed each of the previous three adaptations. But there‚Äôs no doubt Branagh‚Äôs express efficiently delivers.‚Äù

‚ÄúEveryone looks fabulous ‚Äì it‚Äôs like a walking, talking Vanity Fair portfolio ‚Äì but, possibly knowingly, the film feels like a pop-up book, a feature-length OK Go music video‚Ä¶ what we‚Äôre left with is a superficially sweet yet unfulfilling confection. They‚Äôre a dazzling bunch‚Ä¶ But none of them get much to do other than endure Poirot‚Äôs interrogations.‚Äù

‚ÄúMost of you know the twist that ranks this story as the second- cleverest, behind The Murder of Roger Ackroyd, in the Christie canon. Those who don‚Äôt, if they stay awake long enough (triple espressos, pleasing you, with the popcorn) may find it one of two solaces.‚Äù

‚ÄúBranagh the director makes equally pointless efforts at visual innovation by establishing bravura shots for their own sake... None of this would matter if the mystery ticked along at the required pace. But key clues have been removed. Vital pointers have been taken down. The result is a broken mechanism whose wheezes and clanks offer only hints of Lumet‚Äôs delightful film.

‚ÄúI am still wondering why you‚Äôve gathered us all together.‚Äù

‚ÄòMurder On The Orient Express‚Äô is in UK cinemas now.
TITLE: 'Murder On The Orient Express' Reviews: They're In... And They Are Not Great

SUMMARY:
When Osama bin Laden wasn‚Äôt planning terrorist attacks, such as 9/11, he was apparently watching YouTube videos like ‚ÄúCharlie Bit My Finger.‚ÄùAnd that shocks Howard Davies-Carr, who filmed his son Charlie biting the finger of brother Harry in the now-legendary 2007 viral video.
Turns out ‚ÄúCharlie Bit My Finger‚Äù was one of the many videos that Navy SEALs found in bin Laden‚Äôs collection when they stormed his compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, on May 2, 2011, according to a CIA press release issued Wednesday.
Davies-Carr filmed the 55-second video in May 2007 just to capture a moment in their lives, and he uploaded it only after reviewing it and finding it funny.
‚ÄúCharlie Bit My Finger‚Äù was, perhaps, the strangest film found in bin Laden‚Äôs video stash, which included old Tom & Jerry cartoons, feature films including ‚ÄúCars‚Äù and ‚ÄúResident Evil,‚Äù and a number of crochet tutorials, according to Gizmodo.
Davies-Carr says he‚Äôs aware of many high-profile people who‚Äôve seen ‚ÄúCharlie Bit My Finger‚Äù but admits bin Laden ‚Äúis the most notorious.‚Äù
TEXT:
When Osama bin Laden wasn‚Äôt planning terrorist attacks, such as 9/11, he was apparently watching YouTube videos like ‚ÄúCharlie Bit My Finger.‚Äù

And that shocks Howard Davies-Carr, who filmed his son Charlie biting the finger of brother Harry in the now-legendary 2007 viral video.

Turns out ‚ÄúCharlie Bit My Finger‚Äù was one of the many videos that Navy SEALs found in bin Laden‚Äôs collection when they stormed his compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan, on May 2, 2011, according to a CIA press release issued Wednesday.

Davies-Carr filmed the 55-second video in May 2007 just to capture a moment in their lives, and he uploaded it only after reviewing it and finding it funny.

It struck a chord with many, ultimately receiving more than 854 million views.

But Davies-Carr told HuffPost exclusively that he had no idea one of the viewers might be the mastermind of one of the worst terrorist attacks on American soil.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how to react,‚Äù Davies-Carr said when contacted by phone at his home in London. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to take in.

‚ÄúYou never can tell who has a lighter side. It‚Äôs hard to imagine he‚Äôs planning terrible things one minute and then laughing with his family over this the next.‚Äù

Davies-Carr said his sons, 13-year-old Harry and 11-year-old Charlie, aren‚Äôt surprised by it because they‚Äôre too young to know much about 9/11.

However, his wife‚Äôs first reaction was different than his own.

‚ÄúShe wondered, ‚ÄòWere they targets?‚Äô‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúCharlie Bit My Finger‚Äù was, perhaps, the strangest film found in bin Laden‚Äôs video stash, which included old Tom & Jerry cartoons, feature films including ‚ÄúCars‚Äù and ‚ÄúResident Evil,‚Äù and a number of crochet tutorials, according to Gizmodo.

Davies-Carr says he‚Äôs aware of many high-profile people who‚Äôve seen ‚ÄúCharlie Bit My Finger‚Äù but admits bin Laden ‚Äúis the most notorious.‚Äù
TITLE: 'Charlie Bit My Finger' Dad Is Shocked His Video Was In Osama Bin Laden's Collection

SUMMARY:
Law enforcement officials also reported that witnesses at the scene claimed Saipov yelled out the phrase ‚ÄúAllahu akbar‚Äù during the attack.
CNN: We know that Allahu Akbar is a popular phrase among terrorists.
A Phrase With A Profound Spiritual HistoryThe phrase Allahu akbar has a long history of use within Islam.
The phrase Allahu akbar is also used by non-Muslim Arab speakers, since ‚ÄúAllah‚Äù is the Arabic word for God.
This summer, an Italian mayor threatened that anyone who shouts Allahu akbar in a main square in Venice would be immediately shot.
TEXT:
‚ÄúAllahu akbar‚Äù is an Arabic phrase that translates to ‚ÄúGod is greater.‚Äù In the wake of a deadly attack in New York on Tuesday, this inherently spiritual phrase is being used in a different context: to signify a link to political terrorism.

Eight people were killed and 12 others injured after a driver plowed through pedestrians and cyclists in lower Manhattan on Tuesday. The suspect, a 29-year-old Uzbek immigrant identified as Sayfullo Habibullaevic Saipov, rammed into a school bus and exited the truck holding imitation firearms before being shot by police.

On Wednesday, federal prosecutors accused Saipov of plotting out a terror attack inspired by propaganda from the so-called Islamic State. Law enforcement officials also reported that witnesses at the scene claimed Saipov yelled out the phrase ‚ÄúAllahu akbar‚Äù during the attack.

JEWEL SAMAD via Getty Images Investigators work around the wreckage of a Home Depot pickup truck a day after it was used in a terror attack in New York on November 1, 2017.

This phrase has also reportedly been invoked during other terror attacks this year ‚Äï in Belgium, the United Kingdom, France, and Spain. As a result of the way it surfaces during these acts of violence, Allahu akbar has become something that provokes fear among those who are unfamiliar with or suspicious of Islam.

CNN: We know that Allahu Akbar is a popular phrase among terrorists.



COME ON MUSLIMS SAY THIS EVERYDAY IN PRAYER. ‚Äî Rowaida Abdelaziz (@Rowaida_Abdel) October 31, 2017

To hear a spiritual phrase that Muslims use in their everyday lives twisted in this violent way is incredibly frustrating, said Rabiah Ahmed, director of media and public affairs at the Muslim Public Affairs Council.

‚Ä≥[Allahu Akbar] has been used in traditional Muslim prayers for centuries and is used as a peaceful reminder of their religious commitment. They are also the opening words of the Adhan (Islamic call to prayer) and is also often used in approval in the same way Christians say Amen,‚Äô‚Äù Ahmed told HuffPost.

‚ÄúIts extremely painful and frustrating [to see it misused], and unfortunately, just another example of how our religion is co-opted by those those who act outside of it.‚Äù

John Moore via Getty Images A makeshift memorial stands on a bike path in lower Manhattan on November 1, 2017 in New York City. Eight people were killed and 12 injured on October 31 when suspect 29-year-old Sayfullo Saipov intentionally drove a truck onto the path.

A Phrase With A Profound Spiritual History

The phrase Allahu akbar has a long history of use within Islam. It expresses a sentiment that is at its heart a theological reflection about humanity‚Äôs place in the world: That no matter what trials or victories people face, God is greater than it all.

It appears a few times in the Quran, but only mid-sentence, according to Imam Omar Suleiman, president of the Yaqeen Institute for Islamic Research. The phrase is more explicit in the sunnah, a set of teachings about the way of life modeled by Islam‚Äôs founder, the Prophet Muhammad.

Suleiman pointed in particular to a hadith ‚Äï one of the collected reports about the prophet ‚Äï where Muhammad is recorded as saying, ‚ÄúAllah is Greater, Mightier than all His creation. He is Mightier than what I fear and dread.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat it suggests is that God is greater than all our concerns, God is greater than all that is ascribed to him, greater than all the disappointments we have,‚Äù Suleiman said. ‚ÄúGod is greater than our pain, God is greater than our material possessions.‚Äù

Allahu akbar is an affirmation of a belief in a monotheistic God, Suleiman said ‚Äï since it suggests that God has no partners. Belief in absolute monotheism is a core part of orthodox Islamic theology.

The phrase Allahu akbar is also used by non-Muslim Arab speakers, since ‚ÄúAllah‚Äù is the Arabic word for God. Some Christians from Syria, Lebanon, and other regions in the Levant, say Allahu akbar to express surprise, excitement, puzzlement or dismay ‚Äï in the same way that English speakers may use the phrase ‚ÄúOh my God.‚Äù (It‚Äôs not a religious pronouncement for these Christians, however, and some Arab Christians, such as Egypt‚Äôs Copts, do not use it.)

From a theological point of view, the idea that God is greater than human circumstances is not limited to Islam. In English, one verse of the Bible declares, ‚ÄúHe who is in you is greater than he who is in the world.‚Äù

A popular Christian worship song by the band MercyMe is based on the verse. Another wildly popular Christian song, by the musician Chris Tomlin, states, ‚ÄúOur God is greater, our God is stronger, God you are higher than any other.‚Äù

Nick Jonas has a symbol representing the words ‚ÄúGod is greater than the highs and lows‚Äù tattooed on his arm.

A post shared by Nick Jonas (@nickjonas) on Aug 8, 2013 at 5:03pm PDT

Saying Allahu Akbar In Prayer, Joy And Sadness

For Muslims, the phrase Allahu akbar is built into the prayers that are one of the pillars of Islam. It begins the call to prayer, or ‚Äúadhan.‚Äù It‚Äôs also used as a verbal transition between the different positions Muslims assume during prayer ‚Äï standing up, bowing, kneeling, prostrating on the ground.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something extremely powerful about saying Allahu akbar and then prostrating yourself, putting your face on the ground in supplication to our creator,‚Äù Suleiman said. ‚ÄúIn Islam, the greatest position of prayer is prostration ‚Äï the more you lower yourself to God, the higher he elevates you.‚Äù

Muslim Girl via Getty Images Muslims repeat Allahu akbar as a transition between different positions used during prayer.

Outside of the context of formal prayer, Allahu akbar is also used by Muslims in moments of celebration, such as when someone passes a hard exam or is accepted into college. It is also said in times of sorrow ‚Äï such as when a dearly loved one passes away.

The phrase is often the first sound Muslims whisper into a baby‚Äôs ears at birth and one of the last sounds they hear during a burial, as a body is lowered into the grave.

Suleiman said that often during Islamic fundraisers, every time someone raises their hand to donate the whole audience will say Allahu akbar in celebration of the act of charity.

The phrase is so much a part of daily life that Qasim Rashid, a spokesperson for the Ahmadiyya Muslim community in America, estimates that he‚Äôs said it more than 1.6 million times over the course of his life ‚Äï just because of the five daily prayers.

‚Äú[Praying] five times a day, since I was about seven years old, it comes out to about 1.6 million times over the last 28 years or so,‚Äù Rashid told HuffPost. ‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt include when I said Allahu akbar when my kids were born, or when I helped build a hospital, or Michael Jordan made the game winning shot in the NBA finals.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs part of our celebratory mode, and to believe that it could mean something violent is asinine,‚Äù he said.

For the record, "Allahu Akbar" has no inherent political/violent connotation meriting instant terror diagnosis.I say it like 20 times a day. ‚Äî rabia chaudry (@rabiasquared) October 31, 2017

The Consequences Of Misusing The Phrase

Despite the prevalence of this religious concept, Hind Makki, an interfaith educator and activist, told HuffPost said she feels that a stigma has become attached to the phrase in American culture ‚Äï particularly when it is said in Arabic.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one of those Arabic phrases that people who aren‚Äôt Muslim or aren‚Äôt really familiar with Islam treat with dread because they connect it to a crime,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs frustrating because we have seen how many mass shootings and mass murders there have been recently and several of the suspects, I would assume have some kind of ideological bent,‚Äù she said, referring in particular to the Las Vegas shooter Stephen Paddock, whose rampage in October left 58 people dead and hundreds more injured. ‚ÄúBut because the person is not from a Muslim background, or didn‚Äôt yell Allahu akbar, people are like, ‚ÄòWe don‚Äôt know why he did it.‚Äô‚Äù

Some Muslims have become wary of saying the phrase, or speaking in Arabic in general, while in public. The feeling of anxiety is felt heavily on planes, where some have reported being taken off flights for speaking in Arabic.

Rashid said that as a result of how the phrase is treated in America, he tries to use it as much as possible around his children.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want them to feel intimidated. I feel young Muslims feel intimidated using words like jihad, or Allahu akbar, or even saying ‚Äòassalamu alaikum‚Äô [a common greeting] in public,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an unfortunate side effect of what‚Äôs happening right now.‚Äù

Burhaan Kinu via Getty Images Allahu akbar is said during prayer and also in everyday conversations -- as an expression of celebration.

Another side effect of misusing and misunderstanding Islamic phrases is that it leads to fears of a backlash against the Muslim community. Anti-Muslim hate crimes have increased dramatically since the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.

Allahu akbar has been weaponized in the past by people whose intent is to harm Muslims. In Quebec City, Canada in January, it was reportedly yelled out by a suspect with far-right, white nationalist views during a deadly attack on a mosque community.

This summer, an Italian mayor threatened that anyone who shouts Allahu akbar in a main square in Venice would be immediately shot.

Ahmed, of MPAC, said she believes every terrorist act done in the name of Islam not only takes away innocent lives but also threatens the security of Americans who are Muslim.

‚ÄúBecause there is so much misinformation and misunderstanding about our faith and community, those who seek revenge for these attacks will usually direct their anger toward the first innocent Muslim they see on the streets, at school, and at public places,‚Äù she told HuffPost. ‚ÄúSince 9/11, this has been our reality. Whenever there is any terror incident done in our name, we mourn not only as Americans, but we mourn the hijacking of our faith and brace ourselves for potential backlash.‚Äù

That‚Äôs why Ahmed believes education about Islam is crucial. Instead of allowing the Islamic State to define what Allahu akbar means, she said it‚Äôs important to seek authentic, legitimate voices and interpretations of the phrase.
TITLE: Here's What You Need To Know About The Phrase 'Allahu Akbar'

Roma ammicca e si lascia sedurre ma esaurito l'impeto delle prime volte, ti scarica per la nuova passione passeggera. Foodies, food bloggers e gastro-hipsters, assieme alla morbosa relazione tra cibo e anglofilia, presidiano con zelo il panorama capitolino inseguendo l'ultimo gastro-trend. Sintomo evidente di una citt√† dove ‚Äì finalmente - dalle infinite variazioni sul tema quinto quarto si vira con nonchalance verso carbonare gourmet, creazioni tri-stellate e costate di Wagyu cotte sulla robata.

Che negli indirizzi "cool" di Roma manchi l'eclettica clientela di Londra e Parigi siamo tutti d'accordo ma intanto, a forza di sfide a colpi di tuorli biologici, guanciali prestigiosi, sous-vide e salse ponzu ci siamo avvicinati all'offerta di capitali dal ben pi√π ampio respiro internazionale. In questo moto culinario perpetuo, tra le tante ottime tavole, una decina di realt√† hanno contribuito a cambiare la mentalit√† dei romani e la scena gastronomica; indirizzi eccellenti che non sfigurerebbero ‚Äì ed in alcuni casi non potrebbero essere - in nessun'altra parte del mondo.

Oswald recibi√≥ un disparo del propietario de un club nocturno local, Jack Ruby, poco despu√©s de que se tomara esta fotograf√≠a.
Estuvo de visita en la embajada sovi√©tica en Ciudad de M√©xico, al mismo tiempo en que Lee Harvey Oswald estuvo en M√©xico.
Las autoridades diplom√°ticas estadounidenses pensaron que se trataba del mismo Lee Harvey Oswald.
Declaraci√≥n manuscrita de Lee Harvey Oswald escrita en la papeler√≠a sovi√©tica anunciando su intenci√≥n de revocar su ciudadan√≠a.
En la era de la Guerra Fr√≠a, literalmente, todo era v√°lido.
TEXT:
Para los fan√°ticos de las conspiraciones estadounidenses, el pasado 26 de octubre fue un d√≠a de fiesta. Gracias a una legislaci√≥n llamada JFK Assassination Records Collection Act, ese d√≠a el National Archives de Estados Unidos liber√≥ un lote de 2 mil 891 documentos relacionados con las investigaciones del asesinato del presidente estadounidense John F. Kennedy, ocurrido el 22 de noviembre de 1963.

La publicaci√≥n de los documentos resguardados por el John F. Kennedy Assassination Records Collection ocurri√≥ seg√∫n lo anunciado y aunque la versi√≥n sin censura de documentos como el llamado Lopez Report ‚Äîque describe las actividades y el seguimiento de las autoridades mexicanas y estadounidenses a Lee Harvey Oswald durante su estancia en Ciudad de M√©xico entre 26 de septiembre y el 2 de octubre de 1963‚Äî no se realiz√≥, los documentos liberados narran interesantes an√©cdotas sobre las t√©cnicas de espionaje y la forma en que el gobierno mexicano procesaba las demandas de los √≥rganos de inteligencia vecinos.

El cheque inexistente

Una transmisi√≥n televisiva en la que se observ√≥ a guardias y agentes del servicio secreto que escoltaron a Lee Harvey Oswald a la sede de la polic√≠a de Dallas, dos d√≠as despu√©s de su arresto por el asesinato del presidente Kennedy. Oswald recibi√≥ un disparo del propietario de un club nocturno local, Jack Ruby, poco despu√©s de que se tomara esta fotograf√≠a.

En el documento 179-40003-10282, firmado el 9 de marzo de 1964, el Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) relat√≥ que a inicios de enero de ese a√±o una fuente confidencial les inform√≥ que un giro telegr√°fico (una especie de cheque) se hab√≠a enviado a Lee Harvey Oswald durante su estancia en M√©xico.

El 13 de enero el FBI se puso en contacto con Alfonso Fr√≠as, un miembro del √°rea de seguridad del Banco de M√©xico ‚Äînombrada como Bank of Mexico Police‚Äî para preguntar si alg√∫n documento hab√≠a sido girado en territorio nacional a nombre de Harvey o de los alias O.H. Lee y Alex James Hidell entre septiembre y octubre de 1963. Cuatro d√≠as m√°s tarde, el funcionario inform√≥ que en Ciudad de M√©xico no se hab√≠a girado documento semejante y para el 6 de marzo les inform√≥ que tras una revisi√≥n en los registros de media docena de bancos y Tel√©grafos Nacionales no hab√≠a evidencias de giro, cheque u otro documento girado a nombre del asesino de John. F. Kennedy.

Todo esto sucedi√≥ sin pedimento judicial, ni comunicaci√≥n formal con el gobierno mexicano y la b√∫squeda ocurri√≥ en una √©poca cuando los registros se hac√≠an de forma documental.

El asesino de JFK pas√≥ por M√©xico y se entrevist√≥ con un mat√≥n de la KGB... el FBI lo sab√≠a

Carta para Rigoberto

Un despacho de la estaci√≥n de la CIA en Ciudad de M√©xico, fechado el 18 de noviembre de 1963, reporta el env√≠o de informaci√≥n relacionada con una persona identificada en clave como KIVA/1, "la siguiente informaci√≥n fue provista por los mexicanos y se env√≠a para su registro", dice el documento.

National Archives - JFK via Getty Images 'Hombre sin identificar' fue considerado una posible pista dentro de una teor√≠a conspiracionista. Estuvo de visita en la embajada sovi√©tica en Ciudad de M√©xico, al mismo tiempo en que Lee Harvey Oswald estuvo en M√©xico. Las autoridades diplom√°ticas estadounidenses pensaron que se trataba del mismo Lee Harvey Oswald.

¬øA qui√©n se refiere?

El documento habla de una carta escrita por un sujeto denominado KIVA/1, probablemente un ciudadano mexicano, quien habr√≠a recibido alg√∫n tipo de entrenamiento ideol√≥gico en la Uni√≥n Sovi√©tica. La carta habr√≠a sido interceptada por alguna autoridad mexicana y que habr√≠a sido recibida por un tal Rigoberto C√°lix, con domicilio en el rumbo de Vertiz - Narvarte en la capital. Esta carta hac√≠a referencia a tres personas: Ernesto Delgado, Carlos Pineda y un tal J. Rom√°n. Este √∫ltimo personaje habr√≠a recibido una carta diferente, proveniente de una direcci√≥n en Guadalajara, Jalisco.

El funcionario quien firm√≥ el documento se√±al√≥ que si las personas nombradas eran identificadas como personas que hab√≠an viajado hacia la Uni√≥n Sovi√©tica, se informase a la sede central de la Agencia Central de Inteligencia (CIA, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) para un an√°lisis m√°s detallado de estos sujetos.

Declaraci√≥n manuscrita de Lee Harvey Oswald escrita en la papeler√≠a sovi√©tica anunciando su intenci√≥n de revocar su ciudadan√≠a.

Se entiende que la intercepci√≥n de la correspondencia la realizaron autoridades como el entonces Servicio Postal Mexicano, ¬øpor orden de qui√©n?, ¬øbajo qu√© autoridad? En aquel entonces los servicios de inteligencia de Estados Unidos ten√≠an por lo menos dos programas de intercepci√≥n de correo postal, llamados LIMUD y LIBIGHT.

El bar de Bakulin

Desde 1959, Valent√≠n Bakulin se desempe√±aba como agregado militar de la embajada sovi√©tica en M√©xico. Un cargo de peso dentro de la estructura burocr√°tica. Para los organismos estadounidenses de inteligencia era muy importante acceder a su entorno cercano. Por tal motivo, en el documento n√∫mero 104-10215-10019 se narr√≥ una suerte de discusi√≥n entre dos agencias: la CIA bajo el c√≥digo KUBARK, y el FBI bajo el c√≥digo ODENVY.

En el documento, ambas instancias se√±alaron el haber reclutado a un trabajador de American Airlines de nombre Carlos Vejar (sic), quien vivi√≥ en el mismo edificio que Bakulin y al que tratar√≠a de convertir en agente encubierto para poder extraerle informaci√≥n. En ese mismo documento, el representante del FBI indic√≥ que proporcionar√° la lista de los bares frecuentados por Bakulin y extraerle informaci√≥n.

¬øPor qu√© eran tan importantes los bares?

Un perfil realizado por la CIA report√≥ que este funcionario era proclive a la bebida, al punto que hab√≠a recibido una reprimenda por parte de su superior en alguna ocasi√≥n, probablemente despu√©s de alg√∫n pleito de bar. Un agregado militar sovi√©tico ebrio en cantinas mexicanas podr√≠a ser una valiosa fuente de informaci√≥n para los servicios de inteligencia de Estados Unidos.

En la era de la Guerra Fr√≠a, literalmente, todo era v√°lido.
TITLE: Las tramas siniestras mexicanas dentro de los archivos de JFK

SUMMARY:
That's the case with the fossil fuel industry ‚Äî the most profitable in human history.
Although most of our elected representatives acknowledge climate change and the need to act, some have been compromised by the fossil fuel industry.
Since their 2015 election, the federal Liberals and Alberta NDP have maintained support for fossil fuel projects and infrastructure.
In Oil's Deep State, Taft outlines how the oil industry worked to influence governments and their bureaucracies, as well as public institutions like universities.
It's not the first time the University of Calgary has been caught up in oil industry scandals.
TEXT:
I consider voting a privilege and a responsibility. But I wish politicians would take their responsibility to voters more seriously. We elect them to represent us. Sometimes our interests coincide with corporate priorities. After all, corporations create jobs and economic opportunities, and often develop products and services citizens need. Corporations can't vote, but by putting enormous amounts of money into campaigns and lobbying, they can hijack the political agenda.

That's the case with the fossil fuel industry ‚Äî the most profitable in human history. It's taken such hold on the U.S. that the current administration refuses to accept advice and research from climate scientists, biologists, military experts, economists and others who warn that continuing to burn fossil fuels will steer us to climate catastrophe, with horrendous impacts on agriculture, human migration, health, security, the economy and resources, and that failing to act will be far more costly and lacking in economic opportunity than confronting the challenge.

Canadians shouldn't be smug. Although most of our elected representatives acknowledge climate change and the need to act, some have been compromised by the fossil fuel industry. Many people expected changes in 2015 when the Liberals won the federal election and the NDP won Alberta's election. The new governments said the right things and came up with reasonably good plans but then continued to approve and promote fossil fuel development and infrastructure to the extent that one has to question whether they understand the urgency of the climate crisis.

As former Alberta Liberal Party leader and Oil's Deep State author Kevin Taft writes in a Maclean's article, "The link between fossil fuels and global warming has been known since the 1980s, and so has the solution to global warming: phasing out fossil fuels. Rather than accepting the science and adapting to other sources of energy, the oil industry has developed an aggressive campaign to obscure the science and advance its own interests."

Since their 2015 election, the federal Liberals and Alberta NDP have maintained support for fossil fuel projects and infrastructure.

In Oil's Deep State, Taft outlines how the oil industry worked to influence governments and their bureaucracies, as well as public institutions like universities. From the 1980s and into the '90s, Taft writes in Maclean's, "University and government scientists conducted research; civil servants prepared plans and legislation to reduce emissions; political parties committed to action; and Canada's Parliament endorsed international climate change agreements." Then the Harper government pulled out of the Kyoto Protocol, cut research funding and silenced scientists. Since their 2015 election, the federal Liberals and Alberta NDP have maintained support for fossil fuel projects and infrastructure.

In early October, federal environment commissioner Julie Gelfand gave the government a failing grade on climate change, noting only five of 19 government departments she looked at had even assessed climate risks and how to deal with them.

Taft also examines how oil money has compromised universities' independence. A recent report by the University of Western Ontario's Alison Hearn and York University's Gus Van Harten backs him up, showing Enbridge funding for the University of Calgary created conflicts of interest, compromised academic freedom and gave the company influence over decision-making.

It's not the first time the University of Calgary has been caught up in oil industry scandals. In 2004, political science professor Barry Cooper set up research accounts to secretly funnel donations, mostly from oil and gas industries, to the misnamed group Friends of Science for its efforts to dispute climate science and reject the Kyoto Protocol.

Taft also examines the case of Bruce Carson, a senior adviser to former Prime Minister Stephen Harper who was appointed to set up an energy institute at the University of Calgary and later convicted on three counts of illegal lobbying on behalf of the oil industry.

In a Desmog Blog interview, Taft says, "The universities, starting in the 1960s, were the foundation of much of the scientific research underlying global warming. To win the battle and delay action on global warming, the oil industry needed to gain influence in universities to smother or distort or counter the science that was coming out. And they succeeded substantially."

Democracy works ‚Äî if we participate. But it doesn't function well if we forfeit our rights to corporate interests. We must speak out at the ballot box and between elections, and tell politicians our support depends on them putting our interests first.

Written with contributions from David Suzuki Foundation Senior Editor Ian Hanington.

Learn more at www.davidsuzuki.org.

Follow HuffPost Canada Blogs on Facebook

Also on HuffPost:
TITLE: Democracy Works When We Don't Forfeit It To The Oil Industry

SUMMARY:
Investigative journalist and author Jacques Pauw has distanced himself from sharing and circulating his new book on social media after the State Security Agency (SSA) demanded the book be withdrawn from stores.
The "hacked" version of the book went viral on social media on Saturday after a PDF copy surfaced on WhatsApp.
Pauw also distanced his publishers from circulating the book on social media.
Asked whether he suspected anyone for the piracy of his book, Pauw said: "I don't have time to look for the culprit as I'm on deadline for Sunday Times.
Statement by #JacquesPauw about #ThePresidentsKeepers and the PDF version.
TEXT:
Investigative journalist and author Jacques Pauw has distanced himself from sharing and circulating his new book on social media after the State Security Agency (SSA) demanded the book be withdrawn from stores.

The SSA sent a cease and desist letter to Pauw and his publisher -- NB Publishers -- over revelations in his book -- titled The President's Keepers -- which it claims are in violation of the Intelligence Services Act.

"It's definitely not me that's doing it. I won't do it because I don't believe the book will be banned. I don't think the State Security Agency has any chance of being successful with their court application so there's no reason for me to do it," Pauw told News24 on Saturday.

The "hacked" version of the book went viral on social media on Saturday after a PDF copy surfaced on WhatsApp.

NB Publishers had on Friday said they had received the letter from the SSA, demanding that they withdraw the book from stores, as well as retract certain parts of the book.

The SSA threatened to go to court to get an interdict preventing NB Publishers from further distributing, printing, publishing or promoting the book should they refuse to withdraw it from bookshops.

Pauw also distanced his publishers from circulating the book on social media.

"The copies that are floating around are from the e-book version. Somebody has obviously bought an e-book and has converted it into PDF. It's definitely not me, there's no reason for me to do it," he said.

Asked whether he suspected anyone for the piracy of his book, Pauw said: "I don't have time to look for the culprit as I'm on deadline for Sunday Times. The publishers might be doing something about it. Well, I don't know what they'll gain by doing it. I believe that people are still going to go out and buy the book, personally, I'm not that concerned."

UPDATE: On Sunday, Pauw issued a statement on his Facebook account.

Statement by #JacquesPauw about #ThePresidentsKeepers and the PDF version. (Posted on Facebook on Sunday 5 November at about 07:50.) pic.twitter.com/Fzkm50YRvq ‚Äî Penny Haw (@PennyHaw) November 5, 2017

NB Publishers have assured South Africans that the book has not been banned."We assure the public the book is not banned and we're printing more to meet the overwhelming demand and working to get them to the shops as soon as possible," the publishers said in a statement.They said they were also fighting the attempt to have the book withdrawn.The publishers warned that circulating the book on social media amounted to piracy."Piracy hurts this courageous author who has put everything on the line to ensure South Africa knows the truth this book tells. It also hurts the publishing industry and is illegal."Pauw's book exposes how millions of rands of taxpayers' money were spent on bogus spies. It also exposes revelations about President Jacob Zuma's compromised government.An extract of Pauw's book, published in last weekend's Sunday Times, alleged that Zuma received monthly payments of R1m from controversial tender mogul Roy Moodley without declaring it to the South African Revenue Service (SARS).On Friday morning, SARS said it was considering taking criminal and civil steps against Pauw and the Sunday Times because it was concerned about the publication of confidential taxpayer information in contravention of Chapter 6 of the Tax Administration Act (TAA).
TITLE: Pauw Distances Himself From Circulating His Book On Social Media

SUMMARY:
But how does a robot compare to the real thing?
Ten years since their last release (presumably someone was in the dog house), Sony has decided to bring out a new version of their iconic Aibo robot dog.
Just like a real dog, Aibo is billed as being able to form ‚Äúan emotional bond‚Äù with members of the household and provide you with ‚Äúlove, affection, and the joy of nurturing and raising a companion‚Äù.
On the other hand, robot dog does not need to toilet or shed hair.
For any dog owner who has ever tried to have an impromptu weekend away or stay at work late without being crippled by the guilt of leaving Fido home alone, robot dog would undeniably solve those problems.
TEXT:
But how does a robot compare to the real thing? Could a machine ever really replace man‚Äôs best friend?

The updated model - simply named Aibo - is making the most of a decade‚Äôs worth of technological advances by integrating artificial intelligence, machine learning and mobile software. Aibo can supposedly do more than ever before.

Ten years since their last release (presumably someone was in the dog house), Sony has decided to bring out a new version of their iconic Aibo robot dog.

1. Keeping You Company

All dog owners will agree that one of the best parts about having a canine is the company, and in many cases forming a life-long friendship with your furry friend.

Just like a real dog, Aibo is billed as being able to form ‚Äúan emotional bond‚Äù with members of the household and provide you with ‚Äúlove, affection, and the joy of nurturing and raising a companion‚Äù.

Now don‚Äôt get us wrong, that all sounds perfect, but if Aibo is anything like Alexa or Siri, yes they‚Äôll listen to what you‚Äôre saying and give you some feedback, but it‚Äôs hardly the friendship of the century. Plus you always get the feeling they secretly loathe your entire being. Dogs could never hate anyone.

Winner: Dog

2. Making A Mess

One of the hardest parts about bringing a live animal into your family home is that different species don‚Äôt always have the same standards of cleanliness.

From chewing the sofas to using the garden as their personal bathroom, real dogs can be a messy to say the least. Then of course there is the hair they leave on every soft furnishing they happen to come into contact with.

On the other hand, robot dog does not need to toilet or shed hair. So not only is it great for those with pet allergies, but could be a winner for anyone who wants to ditch the poo bags.

Winner: Robot

3. Allowing You To Leave The House

Having a dog at home can be a joy, but it isn‚Äôt half a commitment. For any dog owner who has ever tried to have an impromptu weekend away or stay at work late without being crippled by the guilt of leaving Fido home alone, robot dog would undeniably solve those problems.

And if you‚Äôre still feeling racked by guilt, there is an app that can be used to control Aibo remotely, as well as look at the catalogue of photographs taken by the dog, so you can even see what it is up to (although presumably, not a lot).

Winner: Robot
TITLE: We Compared Sony's New Robot Dog To The Real Thing, Guess Which Version Won

SUMMARY:
It‚Äôs been three long years since Sam Smith unveiled his debut studio album, ‚ÄòIn The Lonely Hour‚Äô, with the long-awaited follow-up ‚ÄòThe Thrill Of It All‚Äô being released on Friday (3 November).
With Sam already a polarising figure within the industry, will ‚ÄòThe Thrill Of It‚Äô cement his place as one to watch within the music world?
‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt to say that the album‚Äôs conservatism doesn‚Äôt leave some questions about where Smith‚Äôs headed.
If The Thrill Of It All were any more constipated, it would come with laxative coupons.‚Äù‚Ä≥‚ÄòThe Thrill of It All‚Äô shakes some of the stuffiness off Smith‚Äôs sound by livening up arrangements.
‚ÄúAgain; nothing on ‚ÄòThe Thrill of It All‚Äô will surprise anyone, it‚Äôs very much peak Sam Smith.
TEXT:
It‚Äôs been three long years since Sam Smith unveiled his debut studio album, ‚ÄòIn The Lonely Hour‚Äô, with the long-awaited follow-up ‚ÄòThe Thrill Of It All‚Äô being released on Friday (3 November).

Second albums are a notoriously tricky hurdle for a lot of artists, particularly when their first offering has received critical or commercial success, as it‚Äôs often seen by music-lovers as a sink or swim situation.

With Sam already a polarising figure within the industry, will ‚ÄòThe Thrill Of It‚Äô cement his place as one to watch within the music world?

Well, the first reviews for his latest offering are out, and while many have pointed out the obvious similarities to ‚ÄòIn The Lonely Hour‚Äô, the jury‚Äôs still out as to whether or not that‚Äôs a good thing...

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs tempting to read the album‚Äôs title ironically, but for as pained as Smith sounds, he‚Äôs also engaged and alive, channeling his demons into songs that are immediately welcoming, warm, and soulful.

‚ÄúThat isn‚Äôt to say that the album‚Äôs conservatism doesn‚Äôt leave some questions about where Smith‚Äôs headed. He‚Äôs deepened his craft without exactly broadening it, which makes ‚ÄòThe Thrill of It All‚Äô feel more like a fine-tuning than a bold new adventure.‚Äù

‚ÄúSmith‚Äôs voice remains a thing of wonder throughout. On the old soul-styled ‚ÄòOne Last Song‚Äô, he sweeps smoothly into a clear high tenor without slipping into falsetto escape, thereby evoking more genuine emotional connection; and his vibrato touches in ‚ÄòBurning‚Äô are subtly controlled, against the rich choral backing vocals that give the album a powerful gospel flavour.‚Äù

‚ÄúEven to the untutored ear, it‚Äôs obvious the 25-year-old is a fearsome ninja of vocal technique. Which makes the ‚Äòthrill‚Äô in that title doubly baffling, because it doesn‚Äôt relate to anything in this mannered and self-consciously ‚Äòmoving‚Äô soul-blues set...

‚ÄúEmotions are notoriously messy, but Smith‚Äôs controlled material reflects none of that. If The Thrill Of It All were any more constipated, it would come with laxative coupons.‚Äù

‚Ä≥‚ÄòThe Thrill of It All‚Äô shakes some of the stuffiness off Smith‚Äôs sound by livening up arrangements. Songs that would‚Äôve been hammered out as droll piano ballads get fleshed out with strings, horns, and sweeping backing vocals.

‚ÄúBut writing off the album‚Äôs embrace of soul and gospel as a deliberate signifier of groundedness‚Ä¶ ignores how genuinely engaged Smith sounds when singing this music.‚Äù

‚ÄúEven at a compact 10 songs, ‚ÄôThe Thrill of It All‚Äô has a dull spot or two... but these are small quibbles, and at a brisk 35 minutes, the album is so aerodynamically constructed that it quickly flies past any rough patches.

‚ÄúMuch of it feels comfortable; at 25, Smith can still sing the hell out of the kind of love songs he could sing the hell out of when he was 20. But he‚Äôs grown, too, and ‚ÄôThe Thrill of It All‚Äô is best when he stretches out of his comfort zone.‚Äù

‚ÄúFor ‚ÄúThe Thrill of It All,‚Äù the musical backdrop is far lusher than it was on his debut, though Smith‚Äôs voice is still distinctive enough and powerful enough to command the spotlight in every song.

‚ÄúSometimes, Smith‚Äôs sadness becomes a bit overwhelming, but his voice remains a marvel, making ‚ÄòThe Thrill of It All‚Äô an even more potent statement than his thrilling debut.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course, Sam Smith‚Äôs voice is just as powerful as ever - though his range is occasionally tested, his falsetto, control, and technical skill are all impressively on point.

‚ÄúAgain; nothing on ‚ÄòThe Thrill of It All‚Äô will surprise anyone, it‚Äôs very much peak Sam Smith. But it‚Äôs romantic, painfully honest, bleak as hell, and just as impressive.‚Äù
TITLE: Sam Smith's 'The Thrill Of It All' Reviews: What Did The Critics Say About His Latest Release?

TEXT:
Un hombre de mediana edad residente en la costa este de Estados Unidos asegur√≥, en declaraciones a la publicaci√≥n digital Vulture, que mantuvo relaciones sexuales con Kevin Spacey a los 14 a√±os.

Seg√∫n su testimonio, la relaci√≥n con Spacey comenz√≥ cuando el actor ten√≠a 24 a√±os y acab√≥ en lo que describe como "un intento de violaci√≥n".

El hombre asegura que ha decidido hacer p√∫blica su denuncia gracias al arrojo mostrado por el actor Anthony Rapp, que el domingo relat√≥ un supuesto episodio de acoso sexual por parte de Spacey.

Aquel incidente supuestamente tuvo lugar en 1986, cuando Rapp ten√≠a 14 a√±os, una denuncia que llev√≥ a Spacey a afirmar que no recordaba ese episodio, pero que si realmente tuvo lugar, le deb√≠a "la m√°s sincera disculpa".

"Honestamente, no recuerdo el encuentro, hubiera sido hace m√°s de 30 a√±os. Pero si me comport√© como √©l describe, le debo la m√°s sincera disculpa por lo que habr√≠a sido un comportamiento ebrio profundamente inapropiado", valor√≥ Spacey en un comunicado publicado en su perfil de Twitter.

Desde entonces, otras personas han acusado a Spacey de actos similares, a los que se suma este nuevo testimonio.

"He arrastrado un nivel de culpa toda mi vida sabiendo que estas personas repiten sus comportamientos. No paran. No se trata de una sola vez (...). Sabiendo que continu√≥ actuando as√≠, me hizo avergonzarme", relat√≥ el hombre a la web.

En su caso, prefiere mantener el anonimato porque, sostiene, no quiere ser recordado por este suceso ni ser devorado por los medios de comunicaci√≥n.

"He trabajado muy duro para tener una buena vida y sentirme seguro, y no voy a dejar todo eso por √©l", declar√≥. "No quiero que me encuentre", a√±adi√≥.

Ambos se conocieron en 1981, cuando Spacey ejerc√≠a como profesor en una escuela de interpretaci√≥n en Westchester County y el hombre era un estudiante de 12 a√±os. Volvieron a coincidir en 1983, y entonces Spacey le dio su n√∫mero de tel√©fono.

"Comenzamos una relaci√≥n sexual en su apartamento en el Upper West Side (Nueva York), en la primera vez que acud√≠. Consist√≠a b√°sicamente en que le penetrara", indic√≥ el hombre, que volvi√≥ a reunirse con Spacey "tres o cuatro veces m√°s".

"Nos dec√≠amos que nos quer√≠amos. Y √©l me dec√≠a que hab√≠a productores que estaban muy interesados en m√≠ como actor y que me iba a conseguir audiciones (...). No me hab√≠a visto actuar desde que yo ten√≠a 12 a√±os", declar√≥.

En las siguientes veces que se vieron, Spacey le dijo que prefer√≠a ser √©l quien llevara a cabo la penetraci√≥n, pero el hombre se resisti√≥.

"Me empuj√≥ fuerte, me cogi√≥ y empez√≥ a restregarse contra mi trasero. Me dol√≠a much√≠simo. Le dije que no repetidamente. Por suerte yo era fuerte y logr√© quit√°rmelo de encima. Me deshice de √©l y me fui corriendo mientras lloraba", sostuvo.

El abogado de Spacey ha denegado esta acusaci√≥n por completo.

Mientras tanto, su representante se√±al√≥ este mi√©rcoles que Spacey "se est√° tomando el tiempo necesario para buscar evaluaci√≥n y tratamiento", una afirmaci√≥n que deja en tela de juicio su participaci√≥n en la sexta y √∫ltima temporada de House of Cards.

El rodaje de la serie, que arranc√≥ hace unas dos semanas, fue suspendido indefinidamente por la plataforma poco despu√©s de conocerse las acusaciones contra Spacey.
TITLE: Otro hombre afirma que mantuvo relaci√≥n sexual con Kevin Spacey a los 14 a√±os

TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

ABU DHABI (Reuters) ‚Äî Pakistan plans to build at least three to four big reactors as it targets nuclear power capacity of 8,800 megawatts (MW) by 2030, the country's atomic energy commission chairman said.

Pakistan has five small reactors in operation with combined capacity of just over 1,300 MW. The last one in the four-reactor Chashma plant in Punjab province, built by China National Nuclear Corp (CNNC), went into operation in September this year.

It is also building two Chinese Hualong One reactors with a capacity of 1,100 MW each near the port city of Karachi.

Muhammad Naeem, Chairman of the Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission, told Reuters these two new reactors are now 60% and 40% complete respectively and should become operational in 2020 and 2021.

Pakistan is now also in the final stages of awarding contracts for an eighth nuclear reactor with 1100 MW capacity which would take the country's total nuclear capacity to about 5,000 MW when it is finished.

"We could award the contracts before year-end," Naeem told Reuters on the sidelines of a nuclear conference in Abu Dhabi.

He declined to say how many contenders are in the race and whether non-Chinese bidders may be in the running.

Pakistan's five operating reactors ‚Äî including a tiny 125 MW Canadian-built reactor in Karachi in operation since 1972 ‚Äî generate just 5% of the country's electricity, with the rest coming from oil, gas and some hydropower.

With about one quarter of Pakistan's population having no access to electricity, the government said late last year that it wants to boost nuclear capacity to 8,800 MW, or about 20% of power generation capacity, by 2030.

Naeem said Pakistan is looking at building at least three to four more big nuclear reactors before 2030 in order to reach that target.

"We have the plans in place, we are watching for proven technologies," he said, adding that funding would come from the state budget and loans.

He did not specify whether countries other than China may be invited to bid.

Pakistan, which has a nuclear weapons programme, has not signed the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, which means Western reactor vendors such as EDF cannot sell reactors there. China has defied nuclear trading bans on Pakistan and delivered equipment as well as fuel.

Russia's Rosatom has built nuclear reactors in India, but a Rosatom official said earlier this year the firm has not worked with Pakistan.

Also on HuffPost
TITLE: Pakistan To Build Several Nuclear Reactors To Boost 8,800 MW Energy By 2030
