TEXT:
Hay un runr√∫n incesante en c√≠rculos jur√≠dicos. La pregunta del t√≠tulo no es ingenua porque proviene de un destacado jurista que ha tenido altos cargos en la administraci√≥n de Justicia de este pa√≠s. "No entiendo esa obsesi√≥n de los medios llamados institucionales en centrarse en la juez Carmen Lamela. Afortunadamente, la justicia espa√±ola establece que un juez no puede pedir prisi√≥n para un encausado si no es a petici√≥n de la Fiscal√≠a ¬øentonces? Es la Fiscal√≠a General del Estado, el fiscal Maza, quien ha apostado por la prisi√≥n incondicional. Y con el pleno conocimiento del Gobierno. Dejen a la juez en paz, hombre, es secundaria. Con la malversaci√≥n ten√≠a para prisi√≥n".

Las sospechas y dudas del experto jurista no son muy diferentes de las de los fiscales no afines a Maza. Algunos de ellos se preguntan por qu√© la Fiscal√≠a General no ha reunido a la Junta de Fiscales de Sala ‚Äìel √≥rgano que se ocupa de asesorar en cuestiones de doctrina y t√©cnicas al Fiscal General- para tratar todas las dudas existentes sobre la competencia de la Audiencia Nacional en el caso.

Algunos fiscales se preguntan por qu√© Maza no consult√≥ a la Junta de Fiscales para tratar las dudas sobre la competencia de la Audiencia

"Los exconsellers tendr√°n que enfrentarse casi seguro a la sedici√≥n y, desde luego, a la malversaci√≥n de fondos p√∫blicos, pero ni de broma a la rebeli√≥n" puntualiza un fiscal desde dentro de la Fiscal√≠a, para quien es obvio que Jos√© Manuel Maza solo ha consultado con "lo que llama su equipo, es decir, los que m√°s o menos le iban a decir lo que √©l necesitaba o√≠r". Y con todo y con eso, "entre ese equipo los hay que le han explicado por qu√© no es rebeli√≥n, por qu√© no debe estar el tema en la Audiencia Nacional ‚Äìveremos si termina ah√≠- y todo lo que ello entra√±a" puntualizan las mismas fuentes.

Tanto el prestigioso jurista como el fiscal ‚Äìque por razones obvias prefieren mantener el anonimato- coinciden con un catedr√°tico de Derecho Constitucional, excelente conocedor de la vida catalana. Los tres consultados, en voz baja y con sonrisa triste e incr√©dula, coinciden en la respuesta cuando se les comenta que el Fiscal General asegura que a √©l, el Gobierno no le ha dicho ni sugerido nada.

"Eso no se lo cree ni √©l. No ha dado un paso as√≠, adelante, sin consultar al Gobierno, eso lo sabemos muy bien todos aquellos que conocemos el trasfondo de la Justicia.

La √∫nica raz√≥n posible, que explica est√° decisi√≥n de enviar a prisi√≥n al Govern en pleno, es que Rajoy y los suyos tienen datos, incluso sondeos y muchas presiones, que los dem√°s no conocemos. Est√°n convencidos de que en Catalu√±a hay que dar una lecci√≥n y a Maza le han dicho tira para adelante. Ni prisi√≥n con fianza ni nada. Son militantes de aquella triste sentencia de Espartero, de que a Catalunya hay que bombardearla cada 50 a√±os para darle un escarmiento", argumenta el jurista.

"¬øC√≥mo se puede ser tan brutos? Esto no es lo que se hab√≠a pactado", dice un diputado pr√≥ximo a Pedro S√°nchez

"El Gobierno cree que con esta mano dura, m√°s el miedo a las consecuencias econ√≥micas que se est√°n viendo, el 21 de diciembre el triunfo del independentismo no esta tan asegurado como ahora parece" remacha el experto en Derecho. Una teor√≠a que ha hecho llevarse las manos a la cabeza en el PSOE: "¬øC√≥mo se puede ser tan brutos? Le han hecho la campa√±a al independentismo. Esto no es lo que se hab√≠a pactado", comenta un diputado pr√≥ximo a Pedro S√°nchez.

En cuanto al comportamiento que vaya a tener el Tribunal Supremo en los pr√≥ximos d√≠as, las fuentes consultadas aseguran que mantendr√° la distancia ya marcada con respecto a la Audiencia. "Los magistrados saben que la rebeli√≥n no se sostiene. Y una parte de ellos espera que el caso de Junqueras y los ex onsejeros termine tambi√©n en el Supremo" sostienen.
TITLE: ¬øPor qu√© decimos jueza Lamela en lugar de fiscal Maza?

TEXT:
For some travelers, saving up for a simple week-long vacation is a challenge. For this family of nine, however, budgeting for travel is a way of life.

Greg and Rachel Denning sold their home in Utah back in 2007. They had four kids at the time and packed them into a car for a road trip to Costa Rica, where they lived for a year.

‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt OK with just a humdrum existence,‚Äù Greg told HuffPost. ‚ÄúWe got married and were living the script of ‚Äòget a mortgage, get a job, then retire and do cool things.‚Äô Then we thought, ‚ÄòThere are other ways to experience life, and we can each have our own unique dream.‚Äô We realized we‚Äôve got to live an epic story and try to make a difference in the world.‚Äù

Ten years later, Greg and Rachel now have seven kids and have visited 33 countries as a family, living in 13 of them along the way.
TITLE: This Family Of 9 Travels The World On $5,000 A Month

The ‚ÄúBrexit effect‚Äù is restricting business investment in the economy, the Governor of the Bank of England has said.
Mark Carney said on Sunday that while the economy was ‚Äúgrowing‚Äù it really should be ‚Äúbooming‚Äù.
On Monday, the head of the CBI will attack the negotiations as currently resembling ‚Äúa prime-time soap opera‚Äù.

TEXT:
The ‚ÄúBrexit effect‚Äù is restricting business investment in the economy, the Governor of the Bank of England has said.

Mark Carney said on Sunday that while the economy was ‚Äúgrowing‚Äù it really should be ‚Äúbooming‚Äù.

‚ÄúBrexit uncertainty is reinforcing something that started in 2008. We actually think that productivity is going to pick up over the course of the next couple of years but not to the same degree as in the past and it is that Brexit effect,‚Äù he told ITV‚Äôs Peston on Sunday programme.

Carney said businesses were ‚Äúwaiting to see the nature of the deal with the European Union‚Äù that the Theresa May ended up striking.

‚ÄúSince the Referendum what we have seen is that business investment has picked up but it has hasn‚Äôt picked up to any of the extent one would have expected given how strong the world, is how easy financial conditions are, how high profitability is and how little spare capacity they have so it should really be booming and it is just growing,‚Äù he said.

Carney‚Äôs comments came ahead of the next round of Brexit talks which are due to start this week.

On Monday, the head of the CBI will attack the negotiations as currently resembling ‚Äúa prime-time soap opera‚Äù.

Paul Drechsler will tell the meeting of business leaders there needs to be a ‚Äúa single, clear strategy‚Äù for Brexit.

‚ÄúBrexit is only 508 days away. But for many businesses, their alarm clocks are set even earlier than that. They‚Äôre set to the moment they will actually enact their contingency plans,‚Äù he will say.

‚ÄúFor 10% of business the alarm has already rung, and they‚Äôve begun moving staff or slowing recruitment. Without a transitional deal, when EU leaders gather in Brussels for the March summit, a total of 60% of businesses will have done the same2. The clock is ticking.‚Äù

Drechsler will add: ‚ÄúAt the moment, I‚Äôm reminded of a prime-time soap opera, with a different episode each week. First Lancaster House, then article 50, the European Council, two dinners with Juncker ‚Äì and no doubt many exciting instalments to follow.‚Äù
TITLE: Mark Carney Says 'Brexit Effect' Has Stopped Economy From 'Booming'

SUMMARY:
Apple‚Äôs iPhone X officially went on sale this morning and despite the initially muted queues for the iPhone 8, it appears as though the days of people camping for days to buy a smartphone have returned.
Here‚Äôs what the critics have been saying about the iPhone X:Apple iPhone X Specs Unsurprisingly, this is Apple‚Äôs most advanced iPhone ever.
The most notable feature of the iPhone X is that it has a stunning 5.8-inch OLED edge-to-edge display that covers the entire front of the device.
Powering the iPhone X is Apple‚Äôs most advanced chip yet, the A11 bionic chip.
While the display is impressive it‚Äôs the company‚Äôs face-scanning technology that has us intrigued.
TEXT:
Apple‚Äôs iPhone X officially went on sale this morning and despite the initially muted queues for the iPhone 8, it appears as though the days of people camping for days to buy a smartphone have returned.

Apple

That being said, Apple‚Äôs ¬£1,000 smartphone might actually justify this return to the days of gadget hysteria thanks to its stunning display and a revolutionary new facial scanning system that can unlock the phone.

HuffPost UK

Called Face ID, the system uses what Apple calls a ‚ÄòTrue Depth‚Äô camera on the front of the phone to create a 3D map of a person‚Äôs face using thousands of tiny infrared dots. By creating this complex 3D image, the phone is able to detect a person‚Äôs face even when they have a scarf on or sunglasses. Here‚Äôs what the critics have been saying about the iPhone X:

Apple iPhone X Specs Unsurprisingly, this is Apple‚Äôs most advanced iPhone ever. The most notable feature of the iPhone X is that it has a stunning 5.8-inch OLED edge-to-edge display that covers the entire front of the device.

Bloomberg via Getty Images

Apple‚Äôs calling it a Super Retina display and it sports both the True Tone technology found on the iPad Pro and has a drastically increased 2K resolution that supports HDR video content. Powering the iPhone X is Apple‚Äôs most advanced chip yet, the A11 bionic chip. While the display is impressive it‚Äôs the company‚Äôs face-scanning technology that has us intrigued.

Apple
TITLE: iPhone X Release: Best Deals, What The Reviews Are Saying And More

SUMMARY:
WASHINGTON ‚Äî In a surprising move, the White House has signed off on a lengthy report by more than a dozen federal agencies that reaches a conclusion about climate change that President Donald Trump and his team refuse to acknowledge: The crisis is real, and humans are to blame.
"It is extremely likely that human activities, especially emissions of greenhouse gases, are the dominant cause of the observed warming since the mid-20th century," the report states.
"In addition to warming, many other aspects of global climate are changing, primarily in response to human activities.
In a series of posts to Twitter, Katharine Hayhoe, a co-author and director of the Climate Science Center at Texas Tech University, said the report confirms what scientists have known for decades.
"Much of what we've learned in recent years suggests changes could be more extensive, more rapid, and more damaging than we thought," she wrote.
TEXT:
WASHINGTON ‚Äî In a surprising move, the White House has signed off on a lengthy report by more than a dozen federal agencies that reaches a conclusion about climate change that President Donald Trump and his team refuse to acknowledge: The crisis is real, and humans are to blame.

The planet has entered the warmest period "in the history of modern civilization," with global average air temperatures having increased by 1.8 degrees Fahrenheit over the last 115 years, according to the findings.

"It is extremely likely that human activities, especially emissions of greenhouse gases, are the dominant cause of the observed warming since the mid-20th century," the report states. "In addition to warming, many other aspects of global climate are changing, primarily in response to human activities. Thousands of studies conducted by researchers around the world have documented changes in surface, atmospheric, and oceanic temperatures; melting glaciers; diminishing snow cover; shrinking sea ice; rising sea levels; ocean acidification; and increasing atmospheric water vapor."

In a series of posts to Twitter, Katharine Hayhoe, a co-author and director of the Climate Science Center at Texas Tech University, said the report confirms what scientists have known for decades.

"Much of what we've learned in recent years suggests changes could be more extensive, more rapid, and more damaging than we thought," she wrote.
TITLE: U.S. Government Report Says Humans Cause Climate Change

SUMMARY:
Receiving any extra money is always a good thing and it gets even better if it comes in the form of a 13th cheque or a December bonus.
He gives his top three tips to wisely spend the additional money -- for the lucky ones who receive it.
Don't spend it now, before it even comesMulima cautioned that some consumers buy things on credit now -- in the hope that they will recover these through their 13th cheque or their December bonus.
Prioritise debtHe advised that a portion of the 13th cheque or bonus be used to service debt.

TEXT:
Receiving any extra money is always a good thing and it gets even better if it comes in the form of a 13th cheque or a December bonus.

However, the festive season is known to be a time when even the more financially savvy among us tend to overspend, but it doesn't have to be that way.

"Janu-worry will only end if we are disciplined before and during December," said debt counsellor, Stephen Mulima.

"Many South Africans are in over their heads with debt and if we are not responsible when we get extra money, then we won't solve the problem of debt."

He gives his top three tips to wisely spend the additional money -- for the lucky ones who receive it.

1. Don't spend it now, before it even comes

Mulima cautioned that some consumers buy things on credit now -- in the hope that they will recover these through their 13th cheque or their December bonus.

"The truth is there are always competing priorities. December comes, then other things seem to be more important," he explained to HuffPost SA. When this happens, a consumer cannot "repay" the things they promised themselves to and end up in more debt come the new year.

Mulima advises that people budget for the money and wait until they receive it, before spending it.

2. Prioritise debt

He advised that a portion of the 13th cheque or bonus be used to service debt.

"If you are under financial pressure or are late with paying back some creditors, use some of the additional money to relieve yourself financially. In this way you'll get through December and into the new year with a lighter load of debt."

Mulima said consumers must ask themselves what is more important, "having nice times while in debt" or "having peace in less debt."

3. Immediately save a portion of the money

The debt counsellor said people overspend in December without having adequately planned for January expenses such as school uniform, stationery, petrol and food to last through the month. "We see this year after year."

This leaves them susceptible to borrowing and getting further into debt to cover these expenses.

"If it means opening an account to save a portion of the money, or joining a saving scheme that pays out only in January, do that," he advised.

"There are always temptations but good money habits require discipline."

Don't forget to enjoy yourself

"It's money you have worked hard for and it is the festive season, so don't forget to enjoy it, only be responsible," said Mulima.
TITLE: Don't Spend Your 13th Cheque Before It Even Arrives

SUMMARY:
Sie hinterlie√ü Hannah und ihren Geschwistern emotionale Briefe, in denen sie sich von jedem ihrer Kinder verabschiedete.
Obwohl sie zuerst mit sich haderte, ver√∂ffentlichte die junge Frau den Abschiedsbrief der Mutter in den sozialen Medien, um der Welt zu zeigen, ‚Äúwas f√ºr eine Person meine Mutter war.

TEXT:
Im Alter von 55 Jahren verstarb Hannah Summers Mutter an Nierenkrebs

Nun teilt die junge Frau den Abschiedsbrief der Mutter, mit einer wichtigen Botschaft

Die ganze Geschichte seht ihr im Video oben

Die 18-j√§hrige Hannah Summers aus dem amerikanischen Indiana hat mit einem Tweet Hunderttausende Twitter-Nutzer ber√ºhrt. Ihre Botschaft ist simpel, aber ber√ºhrend: Sch√§tzt eure Eltern.

Die Vorgeschichte dazu ist traurig. Vor wenigen Tagen starb Hannahs Mutter Peggy im Alter von 55 Jahren an Nierenkrebs. Sie hinterlie√ü Hannah und ihren Geschwistern emotionale Briefe, in denen sie sich von jedem ihrer Kinder verabschiedete.

Obwohl sie zuerst mit sich haderte, ver√∂ffentlichte die junge Frau den Abschiedsbrief der Mutter in den sozialen Medien, um der Welt zu zeigen, ‚Äúwas f√ºr eine Person meine Mutter war. Sie war stets besorgter um andere als um sich selbst und war so eine gro√üartige Mutter f√ºr alle ihre Kinder.‚Äù

In dem Brief an Hannah schrieb die Mutter demnach: ‚ÄúEs tut mir so leid. Ich habe versucht, diese furchtbare Krankheit zu √ºberwinden, aber ich denke, Gott hatte andere Pl√§ne f√ºr mich.‚Äù

"Ich bin immer noch genauso stolz auf dich, wie ich es immer war"

Mutter Peggy erinnerte ihre Tochter daran, dass sie noch viele Menschen in ihrem Leben habe, die sie lieben und mit denen sie in dieser schweren Zeit reden solle. Sie riet ihr, sich mit Menschen zu umgeben, die an die selben Dinge glauben. ‚ÄúAber vergiss nicht, dass ich immer noch bei dir bin‚Äù, schrieb sie weiter. ‚ÄúUnd ich bin immer noch genauso stolz auf dich, wie ich es immer war.‚Äù

Au√üerdem richtete sie auch Worte an ihre zuk√ºnftigen Enkelkinder. ‚ÄúFalls du eines Tages Kinder haben solltest, stelle sicher, dass sie wissen, wie sehr ich auch sie liebe und wie gerne ich sie kennengelernt h√§tte.‚Äù

Zum Schluss gab sie ihrer Tochter noch mit auf den Weg, jeden Tag zu leben, als w√§re es ihr letzter. Man wisse nie, wann dieser sei.

Der HuffPost erz√§hlte die 18-J√§hrige, dass es f√ºr sie sehr schwer war, den Brief zu lesen. Trotzdem habe sie sich getr√∂stet gef√ºhlt.

Sie hat eine wichtige Nachricht

Mit ihrem Tweet, der den Brief der Mutter beinhaltet, erreichte die Sch√ºlerin Hunderttausende Menschen und erhielt √ºber 1000 Antworten.

An all diese Menschen hat Hannah eine wichtige Nachricht: ‚ÄúNehmt das als Anlass eure Eltern heute etwas fester zu dr√ºcken. Seht sie nicht als selbstverst√§ndlich an. Denn wir wissen alle nicht, wie lange wir sie bei uns haben werden.‚Äù

(sk)
TITLE: Tochter teilt Abschiedsbrief ihrer krebskranken Mutter - und hat eine bewegende Nachricht an alle

SUMMARY:
Si on ventile les chiffres par r√©gions, on voit que 58 % des Qu√©b√©coises et Qu√©b√©cois sont d'accord avec l'id√©e de soumettre les m√©dias en ligne aux m√™mes r√®gles que les autres m√©dias.
En vertu de quel principe les g√©ants am√©ricains du streaming sont-ils exempt√©s de payer la taxe sur les produits et services alors que tous les contribuables la paient?
En effet, en vertu de quel principe les g√©ants am√©ricains du streaming sont-ils exempt√©s de payer la taxe sur les produits et services alors que tous les contribuables la paient?
Dans une lettre ouverte parue dans le Devoir, Pierre-Karl P√©ladeau faisait √©tat que ¬´ le Groupe est une source de revenus soutenus pour les artistes, les artisans et les producteurs ind√©pendants, il stimule les investissements dans le secteur, accro√Æt la comp√©titivit√© sur les march√©s internationaux et favorise directement et indirectement la croissance des exportations.
En tant que peuple nous devons nous questionner : est-ce que nous voulons voir notre industrie culturelle en perte de vitesse ?
TEXT:
En marge de la consultation de la ministre du Patrimoine sur la politique culturelle canadienne, un sondage Angus Reid r√©alis√© il y a un peu plus d'un an, soit en juin 2016, indiquait qu'une majorit√© de Canadiens (56 %) ne voulait pas que les m√©dias en ligne soient soumis aux m√™mes r√®gles du CRTC que les m√©dias traditionnels, alors que 44 % √©taient en d√©saccord.

Si on ventile les chiffres par r√©gions, on voit que 58 % des Qu√©b√©coises et Qu√©b√©cois sont d'accord avec l'id√©e de soumettre les m√©dias en ligne aux m√™mes r√®gles que les autres m√©dias. Voil√† une autre illustration des deux solitudes.

Lorsqu'on lit que les citoyens du Canada utilisent Internet plus que dans tout autre pays dans le monde et que la moiti√© des jeunes adultes (18 √† 34 ans) sont abonn√©s √† Netflix, nous souscrivons au fait que ces multinationales doivent √™tre soumises aux m√™mes r√®gles de taxation que tous les citoyens qui paient leur TPS.

En vertu de quel principe les g√©ants am√©ricains du streaming sont-ils exempt√©s de payer la taxe sur les produits et services alors que tous les contribuables la paient?

En effet, en vertu de quel principe les g√©ants am√©ricains du streaming sont-ils exempt√©s de payer la taxe sur les produits et services alors que tous les contribuables la paient? Cette exemption est un privil√®ge qui cr√©e une concurrence d√©loyale, dont nos diffuseurs et cr√©ateurs culturels paient le prix.

Dans le cas qui nous pr√©occupe, il ne s'agit pas de simplement de ¬´ taxer pour taxer ¬ª et d'ajouter au fardeau fiscal des contribuables. L'enjeu est beaucoup plus important et m√©rite qu'on s'y attarde, sans quoi nous ne parlerons plus bient√¥t de culture, mais d'acculturation.

Ces g√©ants, qui ne jouent pas selon les m√™mes r√®gles, p√©nalisent nos cr√©ateurs, nos diffuseurs et contribuent peu √† peu √† la destruction de notre identit√© culturelle.

La culture, c'est l'√¢me d'un peuple. Malheureusement, plusieurs ignorent les effets d√©vastateurs et pervers de voir les Netflix de ce monde nous faire consommer des produits culturels √©trangers, sans jamais avoir √† r√©investir pour favoriser l'√©panouissement de notre culture. Ces g√©ants, qui ne jouent pas selon les m√™mes r√®gles, p√©nalisent nos cr√©ateurs, nos diffuseurs et contribuent peu √† peu √† la destruction de notre identit√© culturelle.

En 2016, au Qu√©bec, les productions cin√©matographiques et t√©l√©visuelles repr√©sentaient √† elles seules 32 400 emplois directs et d√©riv√©s, une baisse de 4,1 % par rapport aux donn√©es pr√©c√©dentes. De m√™me, si cette industrie contribuait √† 1,9 milliard de dollars au PIB du Qu√©bec, il s'agit d'une baisse de 3,8 % par rapport √† l'ann√©e pr√©c√©dente.

Prenons simplement l'exemple du Groupe TVA. Avec ses quelque 1 500 employ√©s, c'est plus de 600 millions $ qui sont investis chaque ann√©e dans l'√©conomie qu√©b√©coise et canadienne. Dans une lettre ouverte parue dans le Devoir, Pierre-Karl P√©ladeau faisait √©tat que ¬´ le Groupe est une source de revenus soutenus pour les artistes, les artisans et les producteurs ind√©pendants, il stimule les investissements dans le secteur, accro√Æt la comp√©titivit√© sur les march√©s internationaux et favorise directement et indirectement la croissance des exportations. Cet √©cosyst√®me est menac√© alors que nous voulons continuer √† investir dans notre culture : 93 % de la programmation de TVA est en contenu original. ¬ª

La menace est bien r√©elle, comme en t√©moignent ces r√©centes donn√©es rapport√©es par le Globe and Mail dans son √©dition du 21 octobre 2017. Selon le quotidien, une enqu√™te de Convergence Research Group r√©v√®le que 38 % des francophones au Qu√©bec sont abonn√©s √† un m√©dia du streaming, dont 28 % √† Netflix contre seulement 10 % au Club Illico de Qu√©becor, 6 % √† Tou.tv Extra de Radio-Canada et 2 % √† CraveTV de Bell Media.

En tant que peuple nous devons nous questionner : est-ce que nous voulons voir notre industrie culturelle en perte de vitesse ? Voulons-nous assister √† la folklorisation de nos s√©ries t√©l√©vis√©es, de notre musique ? Ou voulons-nous simplement imposer la TPS aux Netflix de ce monde ?



Ce billet de blogue a √©galement √©t√© publi√© sur le site de L'aut'journal.
TITLE: Netflix et les cultures canadienne et qu√©b√©coise

What‚Äôs Working: Purpose + Profit, will highlight cutting edge organizations and inspiring leaders who are finding sustainable solutions to many of the world's toughest issues.
From the rise of benefit corporations (b-corps) and impact investing to social entrepreneurs and innovators, this section will feature news articles, profiles, blogs and other editorial content focused on what we can and are doing to create purposeful enterprises that are benefiting people, communities and society-at-large without sacrificing profit.

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTNEW DELHI -- The National Human Rights Commission has issued a notice to the Uttar Pradesh government over the death of 26 people in a blast at an NTPC plant in Rae Bareli.
It said there was need to ensure that such tragedies do not recur.
The notice has been sent to the chief secretary of the state.
A detailed report is expected from the government within six weeks, the rights panel said.
At least 26 persons died after a massive explosion in one the boilers at the state-run power giant's Unchahar plant yesterday.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

NEW DELHI -- The National Human Rights Commission has issued a notice to the Uttar Pradesh government over the death of 26 people in a blast at an NTPC plant in Rae Bareli.

Expressing its concern over the incident, the Commission said in a statement today that a "high-level probe into the matter is immediately required to ascertain the negligence and errors, if any, behind the incident, which involves the right to life".

It said there was need to ensure that such tragedies do not recur.

The notice has been sent to the chief secretary of the state. A detailed report is expected from the government within six weeks, the rights panel said.

At least 26 persons died after a massive explosion in one the boilers at the state-run power giant's Unchahar plant yesterday.
TITLE: NHRC Issues Notice To UP Government Over NTPC Blast

Il mandato di arresto europeo √® stato loro notificato, poi Puigdemont e i suoi 4 ex ministri sono stati rilasciati con la condizionale su cauzione.
Ora la palla passa al giudice istruttore, che entro 24 ore decider√† se i cinque dovranno tornare in carcere.

TEXT:
Il giudice belga si √® rifiutato di eseguire il mandato di arresto europeo a carico dell'ex presidente catalano Carles Puigdemont e dei suoi quattro ex ministri.

Il portavoce della procura belga Gilles Dejemeppe ha confermato che i cinque ricercati dalle autorit√† spagnole si sono presentati spontaneamente in commissariato e sono state presi in custodia alle 9:17.

Il mandato di arresto europeo √® stato loro notificato, poi Puigdemont e i suoi 4 ex ministri sono stati rilasciati con la condizionale su cauzione.

Ora la palla passa al giudice istruttore, che entro 24 ore decider√† se i cinque dovranno tornare in carcere. Se il giudice decider√† di procedere allora il caso "passer√† al tribunale di prima istanza, che dovr√† decidere entro 15 giorni" sull'esecutivit√† del mandato.

Le decisioni sono sottoposte ad appello, dalle parti in causa e anche in questo caso sono previsti 15 giorni per una decisione del giudice. In teoria, anche dopo l'arresto, il procedimento potrebbe durare da 60 a 90 giorni, come aveva spiegato ieri l'autorit√† belga.
TITLE: Puigdemont e quattro ex ministri rilasciati su cauzione

TEXT:
His costume sparked a huge backlash on social media, with David having now responded to the controversy‚Ä¶ and it seems he‚Äôs in no rush to apologise to those he offended.

Instead, David shared a screengrab of a mock text message from the North Korean dictator, which read: ‚ÄúHi Dave, Loved the Halloween outfit mate! Wet meself laughing. Don‚Äôt see what all the fuss was about.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe made a more cruel kind of comedy than I‚Äôd do now. Society has moved on a lot since then and my own views have evolved. Now I think it‚Äôs lazy for white people to get a laugh just by playing black characters.‚Äù

Admitting he‚Äôd do things differently were the shows to be made in 2017 , Matt said: ‚ÄúBasically, I wouldn‚Äôt make that show now. It would upset people.

The controversy over David‚Äôs costume arose just weeks after his former co-star from ‚ÄòLittle Britain‚Äô and ‚ÄòCome Fly With Me‚Äô Matt Lucas spoke out about their shows‚Äô inclusion of blackface and use of white actors to portray comedy characters of other races, which often heavily relied on racial stereotypes.

2. Attraction Jules and Matisse aren‚Äôt the only winners who faced a backlash, though, with Attraction‚Äôs victory being met with a lukewarm reception from some critics, due to the fact they‚Äôre originally from Hungary (The Sun wrote at the time: ‚ÄúTo us it makes a mockery of the show‚Äôs premise if foreign acts enter, let alone win.‚Äù)



Simon Cowell brushed off the controversy, though, insisting: ‚ÄúI see it as a testament to how we are as a country. We want everyone to do well, no matter where they are from. It‚Äôs a positive not a negative.‚Äù

3. Susan Boyle Ken McKay/Rex/ITV



However, by the time she made it through to the live finals, producers were accused of exploiting a vulnerable woman, with reports repeatedly suggesting she was struggling to cope with the media attention surrounding her.



Writing in the Susan Boyle‚Äôs audition in the third series of ‚ÄòBritain‚Äôs Got Talent‚Äô made her an overnight sensation, eventually shooting her to worldwide fame the world over.However, by the time she made it through to the live finals, producers were accused of exploiting a vulnerable woman, with reports repeatedly suggesting she was struggling to cope with the media attention surrounding her.Writing in the Daily Mail , Simon Cowell has later said: ‚ÄúLooking back on it all, it has become clear to me that we didn't handle the situation with Susan as well as we could have. Yet to be honest, when I analyse exactly what happened, I don't know that I could have done it any differently.‚Äù

4. Hollie Steel And on the subject of exploiting those in a vulnerable position, 10-year-old Hollie Steel‚Äôs performance in the ‚ÄòBGT‚Äô semi-finals back in 2009 made the headlines, when she broke down in tears during a performance of ‚ÄòEdelweiss‚Äô, asking if she could start it all again.



Although Simon Cowell later allowed her to perform again at the end of the show, it was a memorably uncomfortable moment for ‚ÄòBGT‚Äô viewers, who questioned whether children should be allowed to take part in such a high-pressure competition.

5. Ariscandra Libantino The subject of featuring young children on the show reared its head again in 2013, when Arisxandra‚Äôs performance of ‚ÄòOne Night Only‚Äô was criticised by some viewers, who suggested a song about a one night stand probably wasn‚Äôt the appropriate choice for an 11-year-old girl.

6. David Walliams And His Golden Buzzer



However, David was Each year, the judges are given one chance to put fast-track an act through to the semi-finals by hitting the golden buzzer, which has given memorable ‚ÄòBGT‚Äô moments to acts like Paddy and Nico, Revelation Avenue and Callum Scott.However, David was met with a backlash from viewers when he made the unpopular decision to put through Christian Spridon, after his *ahem* unique take on Tom Jones‚Äôs ‚ÄòSex Bomb‚Äô.

7. Kelly Brook‚Äôs Brief Stint On The Panel Ken McKay/Rex/Shutterstock Simon Cowell is no stranger to hiring and firing TV judges at the drop of a hat, but one star who was not happy with being given the boot was Kelly Brook, who later hit out at the show when she was sacked after just six days.



Claiming she was‚Äúrelieved‚Äù to have been let go early, she added: ‚Äú[Simon] was hours late. We would have to start at 9am and he wouldn't get there until 1pm. It was disrespectful to me, Amanda Holden and Piers Morgan. Throughout my career, if I have a call time of 9am, I'll be there at 8.30am ready to go. Simon didn't work like that, it was his party and he did it his way.



‚ÄúIt wasn't what I wanted to do anyway, I wanted to act. So when it didn't work out I wasn't bothered, it meant I could go back to doing what I really wanted to do."

8. Jennifer Lopez Puts On A Raunchy Show Ken McKay/Rex/Shutterstock When Jenny From The Block paid a visit to ‚ÄòBGT‚Äô in 2013, her skimpy on-stage costume and dance routine raised eyebrows among more conservative viewers, prompting complaints to Ofcom about whether the number was suitable for a family audience.



J-Lo later insisted: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm any racier than any other female pop artist. OK, I‚Äôll wear a sexy outfit, but I think it‚Äôs more because my body shape‚Äôs a little different to other body shapes, so that‚Äôs not very fair.‚Äù

10. Doctor Gore After viewers complained to Ofcom, the broadcasting regulator eventually ruled that ‚ÄòBGT‚Äô had breached their code by showing one of the gruesome illusionist‚Äôs more graphic numbers way back in the show‚Äôs first series.

11. Marc M√©tral And Wendy Jules and Matisse weren‚Äôt the only animal act who caused a stir in 2015, with ventriloquist Marc M√©tral being accused of mistreating his dog by making her wear a mask around her muzzle as part of their routine.
TITLE: David Walliams Brushes Off Racism Accusations After Kim Jong-un Halloween Controversy

SUMMARY:
Myanmar State Counselor Aung San Suu Kyi smiles as she walks from a military helicopter after arriving at Sittwe airport on November 2, 2017, following a visit to Maungdaw in Myanmar's Rakhine State.
Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, has faced heavy international criticism for not taking a higher profile in responding to what U.N. officials have called "ethnic cleansing" by the army.
Suu Kyi met a group of Muslim religious leaders, said Chris Lewa, of the Arakan Project monitoring group, citing Rohingya sources.
Myanmar?s Immigration Minister has expressed support for a controversial two-child limit on a Muslim minority group that opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi and the United Nations call discriminatory and a violation of human rights.
More than 4,000 crossed at different points on the river on Wednesday, Major Mohammed Iqbal, a Bangladesh security official in the southern district of Cox's Bazar, told Reuters.
TEXT:
Myanmar State Counselor Aung San Suu Kyi smiles as she walks from a military helicopter after arriving at Sittwe airport on November 2, 2017, following a visit to Maungdaw in Myanmar's Rakhine State.

ADVERTISEMENT

SITTWE, Myanmar - Myanmar's de facto leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, on Thursday urged people "not to quarrel" as she visited Rakhine State for the first time since a military crackdown that drove more than 600,000 Rohingya Muslims to flee the country.

Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace Prize winner, has faced heavy international criticism for not taking a higher profile in responding to what U.N. officials have called "ethnic cleansing" by the army.

Myanmar has rejected the accusations of ethnic cleansing, saying its security forces launched a counter-insurgency operation after Rohingya militants attacked 30 security posts in northern Rakhine on Aug. 25.

On Thursday, amid heightened security, Suu Kyi boarded a military helicopter at Sittwe, the capital of Rakhine State, to be taken to Maungdaw, one of the districts worst hit by the violence.

Suu Kyi met a group of Muslim religious leaders, said Chris Lewa, of the Arakan Project monitoring group, citing Rohingya sources.

"She only said three things to the people - they should live peacefully, the government is there to help them, and they should not quarrel among each other."

"She only said three things to the people - they should live peacefully, the government is there to help them, and they should not quarrel among each other," Lewa said, quoting information from a religious leader who was present.

Rohingya began fleeing predominantly Buddhist Myanmar for neighbouring Bangladesh in late August to escape violence in the wake of a military counter-insurgency operation launched after Rohingya militants attacked security posts in Rakhine State.

Muslim children are seen at a refugee camp outside of Sittwe May 16, 2013. Myanmar?s Immigration Minister has expressed support for a controversial two-child limit on a Muslim minority group that opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi and the United Nations call discriminatory and a violation of human rights. Picture taken May 16, 2013. To match Interview MYANMAR ROHINGYA/ REUTERS/Soe Zeya Tun (MYANMAR - Tags: SOCIETY POLITICS)

A U.S. State Department delegation will be in Bangladesh on Friday and Saturday to discuss the humanitarian crisis and human rights concerns stemming from the crisis in Rakhine state.

The delegation will be led by Simon Henshaw, acting assistant secretary of state for the Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration, the department said in a statement.

On Wednesday, Reuters photographers saw thousands of desperate Rohingya wade through shallows and narrow creeks between islands of the Naf river to reach neighbouring Bangladesh as the exodus begun two months ago was far from over.

Some had small boats or pulled makeshift rafts to get to Bangladesh on the river's western bank, but most walked, children cradled in their arms and the elderly carried on their backs, with sacks of belongings tied to staves on their shoulders.

Reaching the far side, some women and older people had to be pulled through the mud to reach dry land atop steep banks.

More than 4,000 crossed at different points on the river on Wednesday, Major Mohammed Iqbal, a Bangladesh security official in the southern district of Cox's Bazar, told Reuters.
TITLE: Aung San Suu Kyi Visits Rahkine For First Time Since Exodus Of 60,000 Rohingya Muslims

TEXT:
IRMA - C'√©tait une des promesses embl√©matiques prononc√©es par Emmanuel Macron dans la foul√©e du passage de l'ouragan Irma: le "retour √† la normale" dans les √©coles de Saint-Martin d'ici la fin des vacances de la Toussaint. Son premier ministre Edouard Philippe avait alors promis de venir se rendre compte sur place du respect de cette promesse.

Deux mois plus tard, le chef du gouvernement et son ministre de l'Education Jean-Michel Blanquer sont attendus ce dimanche 5 novembre √† Saint-Martin o√π la totalit√© des √©l√®ves de la partie fran√ßaise de l'√Æle devraient retourner √† l'√©cole √† partir de lundi. "100% des √©l√®ves inscrits et pr√©sents dans l'√Æle pourront √™tre scolaris√©s", assure Michel Sanz, inspecteur d'acad√©mie et directeur acad√©mique adjoint de Saint-Barth√©lemy et Saint-Martin.

Sur le papier, la promesse gouvernementale est donc tenue m√™me s'il est difficile de parler de "retour √† la normale". Au total, 18 √©tablissements scolaires sur 21 (16 √©coles et 5 lyc√©es-coll√®ges) ont √©t√© touch√©s par l'ouragan et ses vents √† plus de 350 km/h, qui ont d√©vast√© l'√Æle le jour de la rentr√©e de septembre. Depuis, le retour √† l'√©cole s'est fait de mani√®re progressive. Un quart des √©l√®ves a pu reprendre le chemin des classes trois semaines apr√®s Irma, et d'autres √©coles ont rouvert peu √† peu. Officiellement, depuis le 16 octobre, tous les √©l√®ves peuvent retourner dans leur √©cole, coll√®ge ou lyc√©e d'origine, sauf dans six √©tablissements: trois √©coles maternelles, deux √©l√©mentaires et un coll√®ge.

Rotation et partage des locaux

Pour les √©l√®ves de ces √©tablissements, un "plan d'action" a √©t√© imagin√© avec un syst√®me de rotation et un partage in√©dit des locaux encore sur pied. A titre d'exemple, les √©l√®ves de l'√©cole maternelle Simeonne Trott seront ainsi accueillis √† l'√©cole maternelle Evelina Halley tandis que ceux du coll√®ge Soualiga √©tudieront √† la cit√© scolaire Robert Weinum.

"C'est le principe de deux √©coles en une. De 7h √† midi, l'√©tablissement recevra ses √©l√®ves et ses professeurs. Et de 12h30 √† 17h30, ce sont les enfants et les enseignants d'un √©tablissement voisin sinistr√© qui seront sur les lieux. Et ce, cinq jours par semaine", explique Michel Sanz. Selon l'inspecteur d'acad√©mie, un enseignement "normal", toutes mati√®res confondues, sera dispens√©. La volont√© est de rattraper peu √† peu le retard. "Il faudra vraisemblablement (...) modifier le calendrier des prochaines vacances scolaires afin de les raccourcir, notamment pour les √©l√®ves de Terminale", indique-t-il.

Objectif: faire en sorte que les examens de fin d'ann√©e scolaire se d√©roulent dans des conditions normales et aux dates pr√©vues.

Des enseignants toujours absents?

Une partie des quelques 6089 √©l√®ves inscrits avant le passage d'Irma devrait toutefois poursuivre leur scolarit√© en dehors de Saint-Martin. Selon Michel Sanz, 10 √† 15% des √©l√®ves sont partis du territoire "notamment en Guadeloupe et en (m√©tropole). Pour ceux qui sont en Guadeloupe, nous avons une vision assez claire de leur situation et de leur lieu d'affectation". Dans l'hexagone, plusieurs familles r√©fugi√©es se sont plaintes d'avoir √©t√© abandonn√©es dans des h√¥tels. Elles ont finalement √©t√© relog√©es "dans un centre d'h√©bergement unique" o√π les enfants devaient √™tre scolaris√©s.

Reste la question des enseignants, dont certains ont quitt√© le territoire apr√®s le passage de l'ouragan sans indiquer s'ils seraient pr√©sents ce lundi. Aucun chiffre n'a filtr√© sur le nombre de professeurs ayant repris du service. Sauf situations particuli√®res, tous les enseignants que comptait l'√Æle sont attendus lundi.

Mais ce vendredi, la ministre des Outre-mer, Annick Girardin, s'est dite "choqu√©e" par les d√©parts de certains professeurs et a √©voqu√© de possibles sanctions. "J'estimais qu'√† partir du moment o√π on avait prot√©g√© sa famille (...) les enseignants apr√®s quelques jours ou quelques semaines de sas, devaient √™tre pr√©sents, puisqu'ils sont pay√©s, sur Saint-Martin (...) faire autre chose!", a-t-elle d√©nonc√© sur RTL. "Je suis une fonctionnaire, j'estime qu'il y avait un devoir d'√™tre pr√©sent. Pour moi, c'est de l'abandon de poste pour ceux qui ne sont pas revenus", a-t-elle ajout√©.

"Beaucoup d'enseignants sont partis apr√®s l'ouragan, mais beaucoup sont rentr√©s", d√©dramatise le d√©l√©gu√© interminist√©riel charg√© de la reconstruction de Saint-Barth et Saint-Martin Philippe Gustin.

Verdict ce lundi.

Ottawa compte l√©galiser la marijuana d√®s le 1er juillet 2018 et plusieurs provinces et territoires planchent toujours sur les r√®gles qui encadreront la vente, la distribution et la consommation de la substance.
C'est notamment le cas de la Colombie-Britannique, o√π une consultation publique sur le sujet a pris fin cette semaine.

TEXT:
La nouvelle r√©glementation li√©e √† la l√©galisation de la marijuana devra tenir compte de l'impact de cette d√©cision sur les lieux de travail et clarifier les droits des employeurs comme ceux des employ√©s, selon certains groupes issus du monde des affaires.

Ottawa compte l√©galiser la marijuana d√®s le 1er juillet 2018 et plusieurs provinces et territoires planchent toujours sur les r√®gles qui encadreront la vente, la distribution et la consommation de la substance. C'est notamment le cas de la Colombie-Britannique, o√π une consultation publique sur le sujet a pris fin cette semaine.

Anita Huberman, chef de la direction de la chambre de commerce de Surrey, affirme que les petites et moyennes entreprises ont besoin de conseils de la part des gouvernements provinciaux et f√©d√©ral sur comment trouver l'√©quilibre entre le respect de la vie priv√©e des employ√©s et la s√©curit√© au travail.

¬´Quels sont les droits et les responsabilit√©s des employeurs par rapport √† un employ√© sous l'influence du cannabis? a-t-elle demand√©. Comment un employeur est-il cens√© g√©rer ce type de situation sans compromettre ses activit√©s et son lieu de travail?¬ª

Selon Mme Huberman, la chambre de commerce souhaite que le gouvernement britanno-colombien modifie la loi r√©gissant les normes du travail dans la province afin d'encadrer pr√©cis√©ment la consommation de marijuana.

Actuellement, la loi ne comprend pas de dispositions √† ce sujet. Mais la r√®glementation de WorkSafeBC, la commission des accidents du travail de la Colombie-Britannique, interdit aux travailleurs atteints d'une d√©ficience physique ou mentale d'accomplir des t√¢ches qui pourraient pr√©senter un danger pour eux-m√™mes ou les autres.

La r√©glementation dit aussi que les employeurs ne peuvent pas permettre √† une personne de rester sur le lieu de travail si sa capacit√© √† travailler est compromise par l'alcool, une drogue ou toute autre substance qui pourrait mettre quelqu'un en danger.

Ces r√®gles s'appliquent aux lieux de travail en Colombie-Britannique, mais celles li√©es √† la l√©galisation de la marijuana devraient √™tre standardis√©es pour l'ensemble du pays, a soutenu Anita Huberman.

¬´Dans chaque province, sur chaque territoire, nous voulons √™tre certains que cela est fait correctement¬ª, a-t-elle expliqu√©, ajoutant que cr√©er des r√®gles ad√©quates pourrait exiger davantage de temps que le permet la date d'√©ch√©ance √©tablie par Ottawa.

Alors que le monde des affaires exprime ses inqui√©tudes concernant la l√©galisation prochaine de la marijuana, les syndicats ne se sont pas encore prononc√©s sur la question.

Paul Finch, le tr√©sorier du syndicat des employ√©s de la fonction publique et du gouvernement de la Colombie-Britannique (BCGEU), a d√©clar√© que l'organisme avait soumis des recommandations √† la province sur la mani√®re dont la vente de la marijuana devrait √™tre encadr√©e, mais n'avait pas pris position concernant la marijuana au travail.
TITLE: Le monde des affaires r√©clame des r√®gles claires sur la l√©galisation du cannabis

SUMMARY:
ADVERTISEMENTStruggling against an orgy of shouting, clapping, and singing, the solemn weight of history dissolves in the deep shadows of the Gol Gumbaz.
This flux characterises Bijapur, a palimpsest notable for the legacies of the monumental Adil Shahs.
From the Baran Kaman to the Taj Bauri, from Ibrahim Rauza to Gagan Mahal, the past speaks in Bijapur.
In almost a century since, as the Palmyra lies devastated, the built legacy of Bijapur is at risk of an oblivion given the splintering of civic belonging and urban development.
It is ours, a shared task: it is a challenge to make the past one with the future.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

Struggling against an orgy of shouting, clapping, and singing, the solemn weight of history dissolves in the deep shadows of the Gol Gumbaz. A royal tomb, the Gumbaz is sublimely grave in a way only maqbaras can be. Yet, after half a millennium it is also the sanctuary of a motley public. Despite its sepia magnificence, it is reinvented daily and is many things and places simultaneously.

And why not? Buildings, after all, do have a life of their own. They breathe and suffer, and are reborn with the communities who live in and around them. They change with the people who come to them as much, perhaps, as people are changed by their experiences of them. This infusion of character is constant and dynamic, and so the original creative intent becomes one amongst an unending matrix of meanings which emerge from brick and mortar.

This flux characterises Bijapur, a palimpsest notable for the legacies of the monumental Adil Shahs. The long shadows of memory and the tangible history of built form make the boundaries of past and present sfumato with constant use. From the Baran Kaman to the Taj Bauri, from Ibrahim Rauza to Gagan Mahal, the past speaks in Bijapur. It whispers of ambition, the seductions of power strange and terrible, desire and aspiration immortalised in stone. Born of vanity and vision, it symbolises a fusion of form, time, and space not only in terms of what was but also of what can be.

How do we imagine ‚Äî spatially, economically, and affectively ‚Äî the contours of such a fusion though? Who belongs to a city, and to whom do its edifices, not just its monuments but also buildings and infrastructure, belong? The law shelters the business of conservation from the commerce and traffic of daily life. Our conservation apparatus seems designed to institute alienation, and rarely does a neighbourhood, community, or people claim trusteeship over a building. We care about our homes, the houses we live in, but find it difficult to think of our cities as home, to care for the songs and shadows they surround us with.

The personal, therefore, is exiled from the communal, and the voice of memory and affect is unable to find a niche under the arch of history. In turning deaf to these voices, in seeing our past not as vibrantly alive but as delicately dead, we perform a grave disservice to our future. The Jami Masjid in Bijapur, for example, belongs both to the community of worshipers, as to the conservation apparatus which serves to memorialise it as a beacon of dakhini architecture. These meanings are not necessarily contrary, but that they often can be is a story local not just to Bijapur but to scores of cities across the subcontinent.

What is needed, then, is a marriage of interpretations and practice. Writing in 1889, Henry Cousens, then Superintendent of the Archaeological Survey of India (Western Circle), related that 'Bijapur has been called the Palmyra of the Dekhan'. In almost a century since, as the Palmyra lies devastated, the built legacy of Bijapur is at risk of an oblivion given the splintering of civic belonging and urban development. The manifold significance of the past is often in its ability to overwhelm, to instil a reverential awe which prompts interrogation and introspection. As we cloister these works and stories of our ancestors behind higher walls and turn blindly towards the future, we risk becoming harsher, meaner, and poorer.

Our heritage belongs to all of us. We cannot privilege one meaning and practice, without irrevocably losing the layered richness which grounds us organically to our communities and cities. The processes of use and interpretation have to be contextual, and it is through constant conversation alone that this erosion can be checked. How, for instance, do we make Taj Bauri relevant to the potable needs of residents without losing sight of the public generosity which informed its making? How do we reinvent Gol Gumbaz as a rendezvous point for a citizenry starved of safe public spaces? Can Baran Kaman become the breathing emblem of ambition which soars, and fails, and yet lives? The challenge at hand is to birth a future which sustains as much from the past as it loops back to it, where growth will aspire to be not from but with a common legacy. This challenge is monumental in itself, for it is not specific to Bijapur. It is ours, a shared task: it is a challenge to make the past one with the future.

Anubhav Pradhan is an Urban Research Fellow with the Indian Institute for Human Settlements. The views expressed here are his own.
TITLE: Notes From Bijapur: Why Its Architectural Legacy Is At The Risk Of Oblivion

SUMMARY:
Tom Moyane, SARS commissioner .
The Hawks have confirmed that an investigation into the second-in-command SARS executive and alleged money-launderer Jonas Makwakwa is ongoing.
SARS is not aware of any misconduct pertaining to his job at SARS he may have committed Sandile Memela, SARS spokesperson.
Meanwhile, Finance Minister Malusi Gigaba on Friday wrote to SARS Commissioner Tom Moyane asking for a copy of the Hogan Lovells report.
Meanwhile, Finance Minister Malusi Gigaba on Friday wrote to SARS Commissioner Tom Moyane asking for a copy of the Hogan Lovells report.
TEXT:
Tom Moyane, SARS commissioner . . . he has kept the report on the investigation into his deputy Jonas Makwakwa's alleged misconduct under lock and key.

The Hawks have confirmed that an investigation into the second-in-command SARS executive and alleged money-launderer Jonas Makwakwa is ongoing. He was this week returned to a crucial job at the under-performing revenue authority after a year's suspension.

SARS spokesman Sandile Memela said the executive would not be suspended again following the Hawks confirmation that an investigation is still in progress.

SARS will not suspend Jonas Makwakwa pending this investigation. SARS is not aware of any misconduct pertaining to his job at SARS he may have committed Sandile Memela, SARS spokesperson.

Makwakwa was red-flagged by the money-laundering authorities for suspicious deposits worth millions of rands into his personal accounts made over six years.

Between him and his wife, Kelly-Ann Elskie, who also works at SARS, the two made deposits worth about R1.6-million into their accounts.

Both are on fixed salaries and SARS various integrity and ethical codes of conduct do not allow staff to undertake other work.

"SARS will not suspend Jonas Makwakwa pending this investigation. SARS is not aware of any misconduct pertaining to his job at SARS he may have committed," Memela says.

One of those recommendations was that disciplinary action should be taken against Makwakwa for non-disclosure of external interests. Law firm Hogan Lovells chairperson, Lavery Modise.

But Hogan Lovells, the law firm which carried out an independent investigation into the allegations against Makwakwa, said it had recommended that disciplinary action is taken against him.

"One of those recommendations was that disciplinary action should be taken against Makwakwa for non-disclosure of external interests. SARS subsequently followed its own internal disciplinary procedures which included charges relating to Makwakwa's breach of his suspension conditions and the failure to disclose. A hearing was convened and chaired by an independent senior counsel, Advocate Terry Motau SC. The findings of that internal enquiry acquitted Makwakwa of all charges," Hogan Lovell's chairperson Lavery Modise said in a statement on Friday.

Meanwhile, Finance Minister Malusi Gigaba on Friday wrote to SARS Commissioner Tom Moyane asking for a copy of the Hogan Lovells report.

Citing confidentiality provisions in the Financial Intelligence Centre Act, SARS will not release the full Hogan Lovells report nor the findings of the internal inquiry by Motau. "Let us allow other processes, if any, which are underway from other law enforcement authorities to proceed," said Memela.

Meanwhile, Finance Minister Malusi Gigaba on Friday wrote to SARS Commissioner Tom Moyane asking for a copy of the Hogan Lovells report. Moyane has kept the report under lock and key and refused to give a copy to the former finance minister Pravin Gordhan or to National Treasury.

Finance Minister Malusi Gigaba is flanked on his right by treasury director-general Dondo Mogajane and on his left by his deputy Sfiso Buthelezi and SARS commissioner Tom Moyane during Gigaba's Medium-term budget speech in Parliament.

Makwakwa is a key character in Jacques Pauw's book "The President's Keepers". On Friday, SARS announced that it was considering suing Pauw and the publisher's for contravening secretive tax laws which prohibit revealing information even in the public interest. Pauw traces Makwakwa's alleged money-laundering in detail and he also reveals that the executive may have played a role in making the estimated tax liability of R1-billion of Jen-Chih "Robert" Huang, a well-known Taiwanese crony of President Jacob Zuma and his nephew Khulubuse, go away.

SUMMARY:
1 singles on various Billboard charts and become an icon in the music industry.
‚ÄúI just constantly felt pushed into a box.‚ÄùAtlantic Records Kelly Clarkson says it has taken 15 years to be ‚Äúallowed‚Äù to release new album Meaning of Life.
Though conceding she, too, feels the burden of celebrity, the country music legend told Clarkson: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just a different type of personality.
When he sought to resume his career in country music, though, the stigma of being a gay artist was off-putting to many.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs changing now,‚Äù Clarkson said, but at the time being out was not acceptable in country music.
TEXT:
Kelly Clarkson has scored a trio of Grammys, more than 100 cumulative No. 1 singles on various Billboard charts and become an icon in the music industry. Yet from the beginning, the first-ever American Idol says, record labels and executives have tried to define who she is as both a person and musician.

‚ÄúHonestly, you can look at my previous records and you can hear a suppressed individual,‚Äù Clarkson told Party Foul Radio with Pollo & Pearl. ‚ÄúI just constantly felt pushed into a box.‚Äù

Atlantic Records Kelly Clarkson says it has taken 15 years to be ‚Äúallowed‚Äù to release new album Meaning of Life.

Throughout her career, Clarkson‚Äôs struggle for creative liberation has been tabloid fodder. She dropped Idol‚Äôs 19 Management team, then went toe-to-toe with former industry giant Clive Davis to gain greater freedom in her sound. Sometimes there were victories, she said; other times, she had to ‚Äúcompromise.‚Äù

A deciding factor in her need to ‚Äúbend‚Äù to corporate pressure was the band and team supporting her. Had she pushed back too much, she told listeners of Podomatic‚Äôs No. 1 LGBTQ podcast, the label would ‚Äúsit on‚Äù her music and prevent touring, presenting a financial burden for those with whom she has worked with for nearly a decade.

‚ÄúYou carry this weight on you to keep everyone afloat,‚Äù Clarkson confessed. ‚ÄúI feel everything. It‚Äôs annoying.‚Äù

The superstar recalled a conversation years ago with her equally famous mother-in-law Reba McIntyre. Though conceding she, too, feels the burden of celebrity, the country music legend told Clarkson: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre just a different type of personality. You take on everything.‚Äù

Fortunately, it appears Clarkson‚Äôs ‚Äúdevastating‚Äù battle for artistic authenticity is behind her. Now signed to Atlantic Records, she dropped eighth album Meaning of Life Oct. 27. Not only does she feel it‚Äôs her best work to date, it‚Äôs also proven to be a relief.

‚ÄúWhen you are that type of person ‚Äì an emotional person, in a good way ‚Äì it‚Äôs really wonderful to be part of a project that‚Äôs 100-percent you, 100-percent your personality and no one is holding you back,‚Äù Clarkson said.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre supporting you being you,‚Äù she said of her experience with Atlantic. ‚ÄúFifteen years later, this is my first time experiencing that!‚Äù

Atlantic‚Äôs belief in both Clarkson ‚Äì whose eleven Top 10 hits, three No. 1 singles and trio of chart-topping albums make her one of the industry‚Äôs most bankable stars ‚Äì and the album are obvious. Of 14 tracks on Meaning of Life, Clarkson co-wrote four. The rest bear the sonic stamp of a veritable music industry who‚Äôs who.

WATCH: Pollo Del Mar‚Äôs Track-By-Track Review of Meaning of Life

Lead single ‚ÄúLove So Soft‚Äù alone combines powerhouses Mozella (Miley Cyrus‚Äô ‚ÄúWrecking Ball‚Äù), Priscilla Renea (co-writer of Fifth Harmony‚Äôs ‚ÄúWorth It‚Äù) and Jesse Shatkin (Sia‚Äôs ‚ÄúAlive‚Äù). Elsewhere are the fingerprints of hip-hop producers The Monarchs (Nicki Minaj, Justin Bieber), Grammy nominee Mick Schultz (Jeremih‚Äôs ‚ÄúBirthday Sex‚Äù) and Greg Kurstin, the Grammy-winning genius behind Adele‚Äôs ‚ÄúHello.‚Äù

Saying she previously has ‚Äúnever worked with people who would allow‚Äù an album like Meaning of Life, the Texan indicated the reasons stemmed largely from industry decisions on what kind of artist she should be. However, in the interview ‚Äï recorded Oct. 11, National Coming Out Day ‚Äì Clarkson related the story of Nashville-based songwriter Shane McAnally, whose sexual identity altered his path to stardom.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a phenomenal writer; he‚Äôs had like a bajillion No. 1s now,‚Äù Clarkson pointed out. ‚ÄúBack in the day, when he was someone‚Äôs assistant somewhere, shuffling coffee around, he got, ‚ÄòYou can‚Äôt make it as a country singer if they know you‚Äôre gay.‚Äô‚Äù

In 1999, McAnally signed to Curb Records. After marginal success as a solo artist, he relocated to Los Angeles, where he came out. When he sought to resume his career in country music, though, the stigma of being a gay artist was off-putting to many. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs changing now,‚Äù Clarkson said, but at the time being out was not acceptable in country music.

‚ÄúHe had to go a different way, and in the end, it‚Äôs worked out for him,‚Äù said Clarkson of McAnally, who channeled his considerable talents into writing hits for other.

Now Shane McAnally is a multiple-time Grammy and Academy of Country Music Award-winner who has written No. 1 country singles for everyone from Kenny Chesney and Keith Urban to Miranda Lambert and former Hootie & The Blowfish frontman Darius Rucker.

He was named the 2014 ACM Songwriter of the Year and won two Grammys for work on Kacey Musgraves‚Äô breakthrough Same Trailer Different Park. He appears on-track for another blockbuster year as Sam Hunt‚Äôs ‚ÄúBody Like a Back Road,‚Äù written by McAnally, crossed into the Top 10 at pop radio and is the biggest country single of 2017. He is presently at work on a Broadway musical based on the TV classic ‚ÄúHee Haw.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs insane all the stuff he‚Äôs accomplishing,‚Äù Clarkson gushed about the man who contributed two songs to her chart-topping 2015 album Piece By Piece.

‚ÄúBut what‚Äôs sad about that for me ‚Äì as a friend who‚Äôs watching ‚Äì is he could have sang all that shit himself,‚Äù she lamented. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs an amazing singer, an amazing performer, but nobody could get past [his being gay].‚Äù
TITLE: Kelly Clarkson Felt 'Suppressed,' Says Top Country Star's Career Changed When He Came Out

Er ist dann wieder viel unterwegs und nicht zu Hause bei Lebensgef√§hrtin Miriam G√∂ssner (27) und T√∂chterchen Matilda, die gerade mal wenige Wochen alt ist.
Dem frischgebackenen Papa f√§llt das nicht leicht.
Und es tut weh, nicht zu Hause zu sein.
Sein neues Leben als PapaFelix Neureuther hat bereits Erfahrung in Kindersachen - holen Sie sich hier sein Kinderbuch "Auf die Piste, fertig, los!"
Das ist mir wichtiger als jede sportliche Herausforderung", sagt Neureuther.
TEXT:
F√ºr Ski-Star Felix Neureuther (33) beginnt in K√ºrze die Olympia-Saison. Er ist dann wieder viel unterwegs und nicht zu Hause bei Lebensgef√§hrtin Miriam G√∂ssner (27) und T√∂chterchen Matilda, die gerade mal wenige Wochen alt ist. Dem frischgebackenen Papa f√§llt das nicht leicht. "Ja, das ist absolut hart. Und es tut weh, nicht zu Hause zu sein. Ich vermisse die beiden nat√ºrlich, denke sehr oft an sie", erz√§hlt er im Interview mit der "Welt am Sonntag".

Sein neues Leben als Papa

Felix Neureuther hat bereits Erfahrung in Kindersachen - holen Sie sich hier sein Kinderbuch "Auf die Piste, fertig, los!"

Seit der Geburt seiner Tochter haben sich seine Priorit√§ten verschoben. "Wenn man Papa ist, geht man sicherlich nicht mehr jedes Risiko ein, sch√§tzt Herausforderungen auf und neben der Piste anders ein. Ich bin schon nachdenklicher geworden, das Vatersein hat mich ver√§ndert, das habe ich bereits jetzt nach den wenigen Wochen bemerkt", so Neureuther weiter. Das Skifahren spiele weiterhin eine gro√üe Rolle in seinem Leben, doch Tochter Matilda ist klar die neue Nummer eins.

Das Ski-Ass habe "verdammtes Gl√ºck", dass Miriam G√∂ssner "voll hinter mir und dem Sport steht". "Ich m√∂chte aber keinesfalls die Momente verpassen, wenn die Kleine anf√§ngt zu krabbeln oder zu laufen. Das ist mir wichtiger als jede sportliche Herausforderung", sagt Neureuther. Da er G√∂ssner das Stillen nicht abnehmen k√∂nne, sorge er daf√ºr, dass seine Lebensgef√§hrtin am Abend "auch mal ein oder zwei Stunden fr√ºher ins Bett gehen kann - dann schunkle ich die Kleine in den Schlaf. Das ist wunderbar". Der Spitzensportler geht in seiner Vaterrolle f√∂rmlich auf.

"Vater zu sein, ist einfach alles - auch eine v√∂llig neue und riesige Verantwortung f√ºr mich. Es ist das Sch√∂nste, das es gibt", schw√§rmt der 33-J√§hrige. Er habe "ein bisschen Respekt" vor dieser neuen Verantwortung, denn er wolle nichts falsch machen. Und eines w√ºnscht er sich besonders f√ºr Matilda: "Unsere Tochter soll auf jeden Fall ganz normal aufwachsen - so wie ich damals".
TITLE: Felix Neureuther: Sein neues Leben als Papa

SUMMARY:
This week, one of oldest figures in politics, Mangosuthu Buthelezi, announced that he will not be contesting the Inkatha Freedom Party leadership at the IFP's next conference.
Meanwhile, ANC Treasury Zweli Mkhize took the hot seat at #702Townhall, as part of his campaign for the ANC presidency.
MANGOSUTHU BUTHELEZI IS STEPPING ASIDE: Inkatha Freedom Party leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi will not be contesting the next IFP conference.
ZWELI MKHIZE BEING CLEAR ABOUT UNITY: ANC presidential candidate Zweli Mkhize was invited to the #702TownHall to answer questions about the way he plans to lead the ANC, should he win in December.
EATING RIGHT CAN SAVE YOUR LIFE: Studies done on diets showcase how some diets might actually be bad for you.
TEXT:
This week, one of oldest figures in politics, Mangosuthu Buthelezi, announced that he will not be contesting the Inkatha Freedom Party leadership at the IFP's next conference. Meanwhile, ANC Treasury Zweli Mkhize took the hot seat at #702Townhall, as part of his campaign for the ANC presidency.

We also had the opportunity to sit down with business owner Nonku Ntshona, who gave us insight into some of the challenges she faces in a male-dominated industry, and as the new month kicks in, we looked into how emotional eating can affect a person.

1. MANGOSUTHU BUTHELEZI IS STEPPING ASIDE: Inkatha Freedom Party leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi will not be contesting the next IFP conference. Buthelezi has been the leader of the party since 1975. Here is a look at his life... READ MORE.





2. BUILDING A PATH FOR WOMEN: Nonku Ntshona, Managing Director of Nonku and Associates, is taking on the challenges of being a female in the quantity surveying industry, and she's making it work. READ MORE.

3. ZWELI MKHIZE BEING CLEAR ABOUT UNITY: ANC presidential candidate Zweli Mkhize was invited to the #702TownHall to answer questions about the way he plans to lead the ANC, should he win in December. READ MORE.

4. EATING RIGHT CAN SAVE YOUR LIFE: Studies done on diets showcase how some diets might actually be bad for you. We sat down with Ashley Gibbon from Dieticians at Work, to help us understand the fad diets out there and how they can affect you. READ MORE.

5: ANELE MDODA BRINGS BACK THE LAUGHS: Anele Mdoda, the host of "Real Talk With Anele" on SABC3, recently started shooting the third season of her show. We had an opportunity to sit down with her and pick her brain on a few things.
TITLE: Editor's Choice: HuffPost's Best Videos Of The Week That Was

TEXT:
Prime Minister Justin Trudeau deliver remarks at a Liberal party fundraiser at the Laurier Club donor appreciation reception in Toronto on Nov. 2, 2017.

It was a picturesque November morning when a fresh-faced, gender-balanced Liberal cabinet walked the tree-lined pathway toward Rideau Hall to take their oaths of office.

On Saturday, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and his Liberal team officially mark two years of power.

But after a string of failed policy rollouts (and a certain finance minister's French-villa amnesia), the Liberals sure could use the "sunny ways" Trudeau famously resurrected in his victory speech.

On this episode of HuffPost Canada's politics podcast, Follow Up, Ottawa bureau chief Althia Raj runs through the promises kept and broken with Liberal strategist Greg MacEachern, former NDP national director Karl B√©langer, and prime minister Stephen Harper's former policy adviser Rachel Curran, two years into the government's mandate ‚Äî and halfway to the general vote in 2019.

TITLE: Trudeau Government Anniversary: Wading Through The Liberals' Field Of Dreams

SUMMARY:
Women look into the Intensive care unit in the Baba Raghav Das hospital in Gorakhpur district, India August 14, 2017.
REUTERS/Cathal McNaughtonADVERTISEMENTThe Morning Wrap is HuffPost India's selection of interesting news and opinion from the day's newspapers.
Off The Front PageAfter drawing severe flak for documenting his relationships, actor Nawazuddin Siddiqui announced that he had decided to withdraw his recently released book, An Ordinary Life: A Memoir.
Indoor air pollution was linked to over 1.24 lakh deaths across India in 2015, a report published in Lancet stated.
OpinionDineshwar Sharma, the state's interlocutor, should be cautious about his priorities in Kashmir.
TEXT:
Women look into the Intensive care unit in the Baba Raghav Das hospital in Gorakhpur district, India August 14, 2017. REUTERS/Cathal McNaughton

ADVERTISEMENT

The Morning Wrap is HuffPost India's selection of interesting news and opinion from the day's newspapers. Subscribe here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

Essential HuffPost

A mother with two healthy children lives in mortal dread in Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh, fearing for their lives due to a deadly disease sweeping over the region. Betwa Sharma finds digs deeper into their troubles.

A year after 8 SIMI activists escaped from the Bhopal Central Jail and were killed in an encounter, lawyers representing the kin of those killed have said that several questions surrounding the encounter still remain unanswered.

Former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and onetime business associate Rick Gates were indicted by a federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy and money laundering in connection with an intensifying investigation into Russian meddling in the 2016 presidential election.

Main News

The Supreme Court on Monday decided to constitute a five-judge Constitution Bench to hear petitions from November against the validity of the Aadhaar scheme

Bureaucratic bottlenecks, long-winded procedures, commercial and technical wranglings, coupled with the lack of requisite political push and followthrough, have ensured that no major 'Make in India' project in the defence segment has actually kicked off in the last three years.

Narendra Modi is striking a chord with his home state's grassroots BJP workers with his phone, a weapon that Congress vice president Rahul Gandhi may miss in his arsenal in the battle for Gujarat.

Off The Front Page

After drawing severe flak for documenting his relationships, actor Nawazuddin Siddiqui announced that he had decided to withdraw his recently released book, An Ordinary Life: A Memoir.

The Reserve Bank of India has objected to a draft law dealing with bankruptcy in financial institutions, saying some of its provisions could undermine the authority of other regulatory bodies.

Indoor air pollution was linked to over 1.24 lakh deaths across India in 2015, a report published in Lancet stated. This count was higher than deaths caused by pollution emanating from coal power plants (80,368 fatalities) and other industries (95,800 fatalities).

Opinion

Dineshwar Sharma, the state's interlocutor, should be cautious about his priorities in Kashmir. His concerns about online propaganda might be valid but it is only one of the multiple reasons ailing the state, and most of them are rooted in the real world itself, writes Abhishek Saha in the Hindustan Times.

If the bureaucracy is not empathetic towards those who are slow to respond, it will be very damaging, Yugank Goyal writes in The Hindu in light of the death of an 11-year-old who died of starvation in Jharkhand because her family's ration card wasn't linked to their Aadhaar.

The Hadiya case shows that freedom to marry who one wants must be recognised as a fundamental right, argues Tahir Mahmood in The Indian Express.

Also on HuffPost
TITLE: The Morning Wrap: Living Among The Dead; Nawazuddin Siddiqui Withdraws Memoir
